summary: Paul Merson reignited his feud with Andros Townsend when he tweeted a dig after Townsend only appeared for the last seven minutes of Tottenham’s 0-0 draw at Burnley. Their dispute began when Merson questioned Townsend’s place in the England squad, but he later acknowledged his mistake after Townsend scored a memorable equalizer against Italy. Townsend hit back at Merson on Twitter, reminding him of his earlier criticism. Although Merson conceded he was wrong after the England goal, he soon took another shot at Townsend online, suggesting any reconciliation between the two was short-lived.

Chelsea have made a formal offer for 22-year-old FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto, who would join Vitesse Arnhem on loan if the transfer goes ahead. Muto, who recently graduated from Keio University with an economics degree, has 11 Japan caps and scored 16 goals in 37 appearances for FC Tokyo. Although a £4million move has been discussed, Muto says he has not yet decided whether to join Chelsea. FC Tokyo president Naoki Ogane insists Chelsea’s interest is unrelated to the club’s new sponsorship deal with Yokohama Rubber. Muto has continued his strong form this season with three goals in four games, helping FC Tokyo to third place in the J-League.

A large-scale study found that babies given antibiotics in their first six months of life were more likely to be overweight or obese by age two, with boys especially prone to putting on weight (and growing slightly taller). Repeated prescriptions before age two further increased this risk. Researchers suggest that antibiotics may kill beneficial gut bacteria, leading to increased food absorption or appetite. They urge careful antibiotic use in infancy, noting potential links to eczema and digestive problems and warning about antibiotic overuse contributing to resistance. The findings highlight a possible role of early antibiotic exposure in the global childhood obesity epidemic.

A Buckingham Palace guard slipped on a manhole cover and fell during the Changing of the Guard, dropping his rifle and hitting his bearskin on his sentry box. The incident, caught on camera by tourist David Meadwell, happened before a large crowd of onlookers. The soldier quickly got back on his feet but appeared embarrassed, while his colleagues continued as usual. Metal protectors on the soles of his boots are believed to have contributed to the slip. Despite the guards’ ceremonial role, they are fully operational soldiers, and the Ministry of Defence declined to comment on the mishap.

A&E Networks are remaking the landmark 1977 miniseries “Roots” for a 2016 broadcast on A&E, Lifetime, and History. The new adaptation will draw more from Alex Haley’s novel, “Roots: The Saga of an American Family,” and aims to be both “original” and “contemporary.” LeVar Burton, who portrayed Kunta Kinte in the original, is co-executive producer. Involving consultations with African and African-American history scholars, the project seeks to introduce Kunta Kinte’s story to a new generation in a cultural environment shaped by events such as President Obama’s historic election, an Oscar for “12 Years a Slave,” and ongoing racial tensions in many U.S. cities.

Christopher Lawler, a former royal footman, alleges that on his first day working at Clarence House in 1978, several male staff members pinned him down and attempted to force him into a sexual act. He left the job immediately and claims to have been threatened to remain silent. Years later, after hearing about investigations into historical abuse, he contacted palace officials again, but his complaints were initially ignored. The matter was eventually passed to Scotland Yard, and a former aide—now in his eighties—was questioned but denied involvement. The Royal Household has pledged to cooperate fully with the ongoing police investigation.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, created a rap video set to “The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air” theme to announce their pregnancy. The video, filmed in just five takes and posted on YouTube (where it garnered over 1.7 million views), humorously chronicles discovering they were expecting sooner than they anticipated. They reveal the sonogram at the end, and noted that another video might follow after learning the baby’s gender. Jesse, who is descended from Oregon pioneer Joseph Lafayette Meek, previously appeared in a video that captured his reaction to Melissa’s initial news. The couple’s main goal was to share the announcement with family and friends who live far away; they were surprised by the viral response. A similar “Fresh Prince” pregnancy announcement was made by a couple in Pennsylvania the prior year.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O’Hara in Gone With the Wind sold for $137,000 at a Heritage Auctions event featuring more than 150 items from the film. Originally slate blue-gray, the outfit faded to light gray over time. It was part of James Tumblin’s extensive collection of 300,000 Gone With the Wind pieces; he bought the dress for $20 after finding it discarded at the Western Costume Company. Other major sales included Leigh’s straw hat for $52,500, Clark Gable’s suit for $55,000, and a black bonnet worn by both Leigh and Olivia De Havilland for $30,000. The 1939 film, adapted from Margaret Mitchell’s 1936 novel, famously featured Hattie McDaniel, who became the first African-American actor to be nominated for and win an Oscar.

A two-year-old boy plunged 10–12 feet into the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo’s cheetah exhibit after his mother allegedly held him over the railing. The child, who was promptly rescued by his parents, sustained minor bumps and bruises but was not approached by the cheetahs. Multiple eyewitnesses reported seeing the child “dangled” over the barrier, and zoo officials plan to press child endangerment charges against the family. The boy was taken to MetroHealth Medical Center in stable condition, and the exhibit was briefly closed.

A speed camera in Handsworth, Birmingham—previously enforcing a 30mph residential speed limit—has been found repositioned so that it faces a house’s front door. It has been inactive for over two years, as all fixed-location cameras in the West Midlands were switched off in March 2013 due to obsolete technology. Since then, mobile camera units, remaining fixed motorway cameras, and patrol officers have enforced speed limits. Birmingham City Council, aware of the camera’s unusual orientation, plans to investigate and may remove it entirely. The camera in question will not be reactivated or included in a new digital pilot program being developed for selected sites. The homeowners were unavailable for comment.

Usain Bolt, a six-time Olympic gold medalist, has confirmed his participation on Jamaica’s team for the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2–3. Bolt stated he is healthy and ready to run, highlighting Jamaica’s strong relay tradition and commitment to making the country proud. Garth Gayle of the Jamaica Athletics Administrative Association expressed excitement about Bolt’s availability, promising fans “sprint magic” on race days. The full Jamaican team list will be announced soon.

Neymar and Dani Alves attended Barcelona’s basketball El Clasico victory over Real Madrid alongside Neymar’s sister, Rafaella. Although Barcelona won 85–80, Real Madrid remained top of the Euro League division by points difference. Neymar had just helped Brazil beat Chile 1–0 in a physical encounter at the Emirates Stadium. Before the international break, Barcelona’s football team had defeated Real Madrid to go four points clear in La Liga. Barcelona next faces Celta Vigo as they continue competing for a treble of trophies.

Italy is experiencing a surge in migrants from Africa and the Middle East attempting to reach Europe via the Mediterranean, leading to large-scale rescue efforts by the Italian Coast Guard. Over just four days (Friday to Monday), 8,480 people were rescued, and on Monday, help was requested from 20 boats in distress. A claim that 400 migrants went missing when a vessel carrying 550 capsized cannot be confirmed by Italian authorities, who have yet to find evidence of such an incident. According to the International Organization for Migration, more than 10,000 migrants arrived in Italy during the first quarter of 2015, with around 2,000 rescued during the first weekend of April alone. Many migrants are traveling through Libya, with at least 480 having died so far this year, often due to bad weather and overcrowded or abandoned vessels.

Alexis Sanchez chose Arsenal last summer, spurning Liverpool and other top clubs, though the exact reason for his decision is unclear. Arsene Wenger acknowledges Liverpool’s interest, noting they might have seen Sanchez as part of negotiating Luis Suarez’s move to Barcelona. Sanchez has made a strong impact at Arsenal, already scoring 19 goals, and Wenger praises his work-rate and ability to energize the team. Ahead of a key match against Liverpool, Wenger also downplayed speculation linking him to Raheem Sterling, while acknowledging the good job Brendan Rodgers has done despite losing Suarez and injuries to Daniel Sturridge.

Sir Bradley Wiggins, a four-time Olympic champion and the 2012 Tour de France winner, will attempt to break cycling’s hour record on June 7 at London’s Olympic Velodrome. He aims to surpass the current mark of 52.491km, set by Australia’s Rohan Dennis in February—an achievement revitalized by the UCI’s new regulations. Wiggins, who just ended his Team Sky career at the Paris-Roubaix one-day race, will prepare by competing in the first Tour de Yorkshire before focusing on his hour-record bid. Tickets go on sale April 19, and the event will be broadcast live on Sky Sports. This pursuit is also part of his return to track racing, where he hopes to earn a British record eighth Olympic medal at the 2016 Rio Games.

Serena Williams labored to defeat Sara Errani in Sunday’s Fed Cup match, acknowledging it as an “eye-opener” for her clay-court readiness. Despite eventually winning 4-6, 7-6(3), 6-3, Williams and Alison Riske lost the deciding doubles to Errani and Flavia Pennetta, relegating the U.S. team to World Group II. Williams, who has won 19 career Grand Slam titles—including two French Opens—admitted she was still playing as if on a hard court and vowed to adjust for the clay season. U.S. captain Mary Joe Fernandez remains optimistic, noting their depth in the top 100 and aiming to return to the elite group next year.

River Plate’s vice president, Matias Patanian, has expressed a strong desire to re-sign Radamel Falcao, who originally joined River at age 15 and went on to score 34 goals in 90 appearances for the club. Falcao, currently on loan at Manchester United from Monaco, has struggled in the Premier League this season, netting only four times. River Plate admits that a deal might be difficult, but they remain open to bringing the Colombian forward back, especially given his recent success in international matches, where he equaled Colombia’s all-time scoring record with 24 goals. It is unclear whether Manchester United will exercise their option to keep him permanently or if he will return to Monaco, potentially paving the way for a River Plate move.

Ella Henderson, a 2012 X Factor finalist known for her powerful voice and long flowing hair, has become the official face of Batiste’s 2015 “Ready For It” campaign—her first brand collaboration. The 19-year-old singer appears in campaign imagery showcasing different hairstyles against a vibrant city backdrop and features in a TV advertisement set to her single “Mirror Man.” Managed by Crown Talent & Media Group, Henderson expressed enthusiasm for working with the UK’s top dry shampoo brand, which she says she uses regularly. The partnership was arranged by the MILES agency, with both parties highlighting the natural fit between the artist and Batiste.

Officer Pablo Torres fatally shot 26-year-old Aaron Siler on March 14 after a vehicle and foot chase in Kenosha, Wisconsin, during which Siler allegedly armed himself with a weapon. Torres, who is currently on leave while the state investigates, was also involved in a separate shooting ten days prior when he shot and wounded a suicidal, knife-wielding 66-year-old man; that earlier shooting was ruled justified.

Controversy arose when a police association-funded billboard appeared featuring Torres and his dog thanking the community for support. Siler’s family and friends deemed it disrespectful, likening it to a “thank you for killing Aaron.” The Kenosha Professional Police Association stated the billboard was meant only to show gratitude for public backing. The investigation into Siler’s death remains ongoing.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed and three militants were slain in clashes near Iran’s southeastern border with Pakistan, reportedly involving the militant group Jaish al Adal. Iranian officials say the attackers entered from Pakistan, which has condemned the incident as an act of terrorism and pledged to investigate. Jaish al Adal, an anti-Iranian Sunni Muslim group operating in Pakistan’s Balochistan region, has claimed responsibility for similar deadly attacks in the past and often retreats over the border after carrying them out. Iranian authorities have repeatedly criticized Pakistan for allegedly failing to control the militants, while Pakistan has requested evidence and promised to apprehend any perpetrators who cross into its territory.

Japan’s Defense Minister Gen Nakatani recently stated in parliament that the Air Self Defense Force has never encountered a UFO from outer space, in response to questions from ex-wrestler-turned-lawmaker Antonio Inoki. Inoki, known for his prominent wrestling career—including a match against Muhammad Ali—as well as his unorthodox political and diplomatic efforts, claimed to have personally seen a UFO but was unsure about aliens’ existence. Previous Japanese officials, such as a former defense minister in 2007, have also publicly considered legal implications of potential extraterrestrial encounters under Japan’s pacifist constitution.

A man at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport in China, identified as 35-year-old passenger Jin Pai, was injured while standing on a toilet rim to avoid contact with the seat. The porcelain fixture toppled and shattered, causing deep cuts to his leg and buttocks that required dozens of stitches. Although he initially told friends he had been squatting, he later claimed to police that the toilet was poorly made and broke when he was sitting. Police and airport officials deemed it an accident but reminded passengers that the toilets are meant for sitting, not standing.

Kevin Rebbie, 56, of Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested after a 15-year-old girl discovered a hidden camera in her bathroom. Prosecutors allege Rebbie had sexually abused the girl from ages 9 to 13 and filmed both her and others over several years, amassing 41 videos that included children showering and close-up images of their genitalia. Rebbie admitted to filming multiple juveniles, specifically targeting the now 15-year-old victim. He faces charges including aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, sexual abuse of children, and invasion of privacy; his preliminary hearing is set for May 1, and he is being held on $500,000 bail.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama has created a series of images featuring fathers leaping energetically beside their teenage daughters. The daughters, casually dressed, face the camera with a smile or neutral expression, while their fathers—clad in sharp business suits—jump into the air in humorous, dramatic poses, sometimes revealing a pained expression due to their age. These photos, which appear in a book whose title loosely translates to “Daughter and Salary Man,” offer a glimpse of fathers momentarily escaping their usual serious roles to display a playful, heroic side. Though few details about the origin or deeper intent of this project are provided, the portraits have sparked considerable online interest, partly because they feature the families in front of notable Japanese landmarks.

Kevin Pietersen’s hopes of an England recall have been renewed following the sacking of managing director Paul Downton, who initially dropped Pietersen after England’s whitewash Ashes defeat in Australia. As the county championship season approaches, Pietersen joined Surrey’s team photo shoot at the Kia Oval, appearing relaxed and joking with teammates. He is returning to county cricket in an effort to force his way back into the England set-up, beginning Surrey’s campaign against Glamorgan on April 19, with a university match scheduled beforehand.

Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt, struggling against relegation, dismissed their Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week. He was initially sacked due to a poor run, reinstated the next day by owner Angelo Massone, but was dismissed again following a 2-0 loss to FC Botosani. The former Inter Milan and Parma right back, who earned 25 caps for Brazil, became Ceahlaul’s third coach this season in January. The club, six points from safety in 16th place, has named Serbian Vanya Radinovic as his replacement.

Radamel Falcao joined Manchester United on a season-long loan from Monaco but has struggled to replicate his previous form, scoring only four goals. With United unlikely to pay the £46 million needed for a permanent transfer, Nabil Dirar—Falcao’s former Monaco teammate—feels Falcao must now regret leaving. Although Falcao was not happy in Monaco, remaining there would have allowed him game time and Champions League involvement, which Dirar believes Falcao may be missing.

A man described as “very tall” robbed the Union Street dairy in east Christchurch on Saturday around 12:30pm, wearing a distinctive cartoon mask and a bright orange sweatshirt. He grabbed the cash register—throwing it to the ground before escaping with its drawer—and stole roughly NZ$1,500. The dairy owner’s daughter fled the store screaming “robber!” No weapons were shown, and the police, who are still searching for the suspect, urge anyone with information to call Crimestoppers or contact them online.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was first arrested on March 19 for an inappropriate relationship involving kissing and sexual touching with a 15-year-old student. Soon after her release on bail, a second 15-year-old came forward alleging he had sex with Granado on two consecutive nights in January. She was arrested again, posted bail a second time, and is now on administrative leave, barred from working with students or entering school property. The school learned of both incidents through internal reports, and police confirmed rumors of a second victim. It remains unclear how Granado will plead to these new charges.

A large crocodile in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, was filmed calmly swimming through a marina with a local bike shop owner’s pet dog clamped in its jaws. Witness Tim Weston, a New Zealander visiting the area, noted that the crocodile held onto the dog for hours, attracting shocked onlookers. The footage has been viewed more than half a million times, prompting horrified reactions on social media. Puerto Vallarta, built among mangroves, is home to American Crocodiles that can grow up to six meters long; they are commonly spotted in the local sanctuary and on nearby golf courses.

Steve Bruce remains confident that Hull City can avoid relegation despite a 2-0 defeat at Southampton, which leaves them only two points above the drop zone. Although his initial target was ten wins, Hull have managed just six so far, prompting Bruce to suggest that eight or nine victories might suffice. He attributes their struggles partly to injuries, citing the lengthy absences of key players including Mohamed Diame, James Chester, Michael Dawson, Nikica Jelavic, and Robert Snodgrass. Despite facing difficult upcoming fixtures against Liverpool, Arsenal, Tottenham, and Manchester United, Bruce insists his team can survive if they stay positive. Southampton’s win moved them up to fifth in the table, but manager Ronald Koeman plans to address the penalty-taking dispute between Sadio Mane and James Ward-Prowse to ensure team rules are respected.

Teacher Ian Guffick altered pupils’ SATs exam scripts at Mitton Manor Primary School in Tewkesbury by allowing them—and himself—to change answers after the official exam session had ended. A subsequent investigation led to the entire school’s 2014 results being annulled. Guffick admitted to unacceptable professional conduct and expressed remorse, but maintained he was only asking students to make answers more legible. Nevertheless, the National College for Teaching and Leadership panel found his actions dishonest and banned him from teaching for at least two years, with the option to appeal within 28 days.

Manchester United goalkeeper Anders Lindegaard has struggled for playing time since arriving in 2010, making just 19 league appearances and sitting behind David de Gea and Victor Valdés in the pecking order. Off the pitch, however, he enjoys a high-profile relationship with Swedish model Misse Beqiri—whom he married in a romantic beach wedding in Mauritius—and the couple have a son together. Although Lindegaard was told he could leave United and was linked with FC Midtjylland, no transfer materialized. Meanwhile, Beqiri, who has Albanian roots, regularly posts her modeling work online, and the pair often share updates about their life on Instagram.

At a Sotheby’s auction, the 13 oversized letters once atop Yankee Stadium failed to attract any genuine bids despite an estimate of $300,000–$600,000. The only bid was a $260,000 paddle-raise by a Sotheby’s employee to spur interest. These ten-foot-tall letters, installed in 1976 and removed in 2008, are owned by Yankee Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson, who purchased them on a whim and has since realized their immense size. Jackson expressed hope that a new generation would appreciate the iconic signage. In contrast, a late 1960s New York Mets bullpen car, estimated at $20,000–$30,000, sold for $112,500 during the same auction.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers spoke to Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe to remind them of their professional responsibilities following the emergence of images showing the pair using nitrous oxide and a shisha pipe. Although Rodgers confirmed neither player would be disciplined, he emphasized the importance of awareness and responsibility in an elite sports environment.

As the team prepares for the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, Rodgers has Steven Gerrard available after his three-match suspension but remained noncommittal about immediately reinstating him. Rodgers stressed his focus on guiding Liverpool to an FA Cup final, stating that past near-misses—such as the recent Capital One Cup semi-final defeat and last season’s title race—can be a source of motivation for future success.

Mesut Ozil returned to London after helping Germany secure a 2–0 Euro 2016 qualifying win over Georgia and posted a photo of himself relaxing at home with his dog. He missed Arsenal’s last match against Newcastle due to illness, amid rumors—dismissed by Arsene Wenger—that he was seen in a Berlin nightclub. Since recovering from injury earlier in the season, Ozil has produced four assists and scored three goals, and he says he is now well-suited to English football’s busy schedule. Having cost Arsenal £42.5 million in 2013, he is expected to be involved in the upcoming Premier League encounter with Liverpool.

Barcelona president Josep Maria Bartomeu has reiterated the club’s support for manager Luis Enrique, underscoring that they have no plans to replace him and are “very happy” with his performance. Enrique, who took charge last summer on a two-year deal, is close to winning La Liga and guiding the team in contention for three trophies. Despite speculation about his future, Bartomeu emphasized Enrique’s contract runs until 2016. Over the weekend, Barcelona comfortably defeated Valencia 2–0 with early and late goals from Luis Suarez and Lionel Messi.

Jordan Henderson, Liverpool’s vice-captain, has agreed a new long-term contract running until 2020, reportedly worth around £100,000 per week. He becomes the third key player under Brendan Rodgers to extend his deal, following Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho. Originally signed from Sunderland for £16 million in 2011, Henderson has shown marked improvement, contributing 13 assists and seven goals this season. With Steven Gerrard departing for LA Galaxy, Henderson is a leading candidate to succeed him as captain. Meanwhile, talks over Raheem Sterling’s new contract are set to resume at the end of the season.

Filipe Luis, who signed a three-year contract at Chelsea last July, is determined to remain at the club despite interest from Atletico Madrid. He has struggled to secure a regular left-back role but remains happy at Stamford Bridge. After featuring for Brazil in recent friendlies, he now focuses on Chelsea’s title run-in. Manager Jose Mourinho demands full concentration from the squad, emphasizing the need to stay focused through the nine challenging games remaining in the Premier League season.

Nathan Hughes, a Wasps No. 8, was initially given a three‐match ban for a “reckless” collision in which his knee accidentally struck George North’s head, leaving North unconscious. Despite accepting there was no intent, a disciplinary panel had upheld the suspension. However, following widespread criticism and fresh evidence at appeal, the ban was overturned as the appeal panel found no foul play had occurred. The incident was North’s third head injury in two months, and he was advised to rest for at least a month. Hughes, who missed his team’s Champions Cup quarter‐final during the ban, is now free to play again.

Wildfires in southeastern Siberia, started by farmers burning grass, spread due to strong winds and destroyed villages. Smoke from these fires was transported by atmospheric winds across the Pacific Ocean to the Pacific Northwest, creating unusually vibrant reddish sunsets in Washington, Oregon, and British Columbia. The intense red hue results from smoke particles filtering out shorter wavelengths of light, allowing reds and oranges to remain visible, especially during sunrise and sunset when sunlight travels through more atmosphere. As the smoke disperses, the air quality improves and the dramatic red sunsets fade.

Becky Schoenig of St. Louis had her month-old 2015 Ford Fusion stolen from her driveway, then recovered on April 1 with red rims, red side detailing, and orange accents on the steering wheel. Rather than being upset, she shared her gratitude on Facebook—though she is having the interior professionally cleaned to remove cigarette and marijuana odors. Schoenig, who owns The Hot Pot restaurant, also created a smoothie named “The Sexton on Wheels” to honor Mick Sexton, the man who located her car and alerted police. Her friends describe her as vibrant, happy, and eager to bring laughter to others.

Manchester City’s players each stand to lose £500,000 in bonuses if the club fails to qualify for the Champions League, reflecting their incentivized contracts designed to satisfy financial fair play. Currently fourth in the Premier League, City are only four points ahead of Liverpool after losing to Manchester United, and qualification is critical since the first three finishers qualify automatically while the fourth must win a playoff. Overall, around £12 million in squad bonuses hinge on reaching Europe. Manager Manuel Pellegrini admits City’s form has declined sharply since starting 2015 level with Chelsea, with multiple defeats and exits in the FA Cup and Champions League. Failure to secure a top-four finish could also hamper City’s ability to attract high-profile players like Paul Pogba, while United’s Louis van Gaal remains confident of drawing top talent to Old Trafford.

Manchester United’s Under-18 side beat Manchester City 1–0 in a “mini-derby” at Altrincham’s Moss Lane, watched by around 1,000 free-entry spectators. Thirteen of the 22 starters were English, with 10 hailing from Manchester. Callum Gribbin’s curling free-kick provided the only goal, while Marcus Rashford squandered two good opportunities. United manager Paul McGuinness arranged this fixture at a proper stadium, mimicking senior match conditions, and deployed a formation seen in first-team games. Injury-hit City pushed for an equalizer but were denied, leaving United close behind Middlesbrough in the Under-18 Premier League end-of-season playoffs. The match showcased talented local players on both teams and highlighted their potential for future senior-level opportunities.

Joe Hart, who earned his 50th England cap during the 1-1 draw with Italy, praised Gianluigi Buffon as a “legend of the game” for reaching 147 international appearances. Hart, ten years younger than the 37-year-old Italian, called Buffon an inspiration for his longevity and dedication. Hart also expressed pride in achieving his own milestone and aims to continue representing both club and country, building on his national team caps.

Chipotle is partnering with Postmates to offer delivery in 67 cities, entering the $70 billion delivery market. Customers will face a nine-percent service charge, plus delivery fees starting at $5, based on distance and demand. Chipotle had resisted offers from third-party services before, but now joins several national chains—such as Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald’s, and Burger King—in exploring or expanding delivery options. The chain’s popularity is underscored by visits from public figures including presidential candidates Marco Rubio and Hillary Clinton.

Bill and Denise Richard, whose 8-year-old son Martin was the youngest victim of the 2013 Boston Marathon bombings, published a plea in The Boston Globe urging that prosecutors abandon the death penalty for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev. Despite acknowledging the gravity of Tsarnaev’s crimes and describing the death of their son and injuries to their daughter, the parents believe a death sentence would result in lengthy appeals, forcing them to continually revisit their trauma. Instead, they favor life in prison without the possibility of release and without the right to appeal. They note they speak only for their family and wish to prevent prolonged anguish for themselves and their two surviving children. Tsarnaev was recently found guilty on all 30 charges, and the sentencing phase is set to begin.

A mystery billionaire spent around £400 million to convert a Boeing 747—normally seating up to 600 passengers—into a highly customized private jet. The plane features multiple lounges, a spacious dining area complete with a kitchen and private chef, and an “aeroloft” offering eight full beds. A master suite, additional bedrooms, and a conference room reflect the owner’s desire for both luxury and business capabilities. The décor throughout mirrors a top-tier hotel rather than a traditional aircraft cabin, with opulent furnishings, expansive seating areas, and porthole-style windows. This lavish refit was designed by Greenpoint Technologies over three years, resulting in one of the most luxurious private planes ever built.

SpaceX successfully launched a Falcon 9 rocket Tuesday from Cape Canaveral, sending the uncrewed Dragon spacecraft with over 4,300 pounds of supplies—such as research gear and an espresso machine—to the International Space Station. However, the attempt to land the rocket’s first stage on a droneship failed when the booster landed hard and tipped over. This was SpaceX’s second try at a barge landing; a previous January attempt also met with a crash. The company’s overall goal is to cut costs by reusing rockets, and after several weeks at the station, Dragon will return to Earth with over 3,000 pounds of cargo, splashing down in the Pacific. This is SpaceX’s sixth cargo mission to the ISS, and the launch followed a weather-related delay the previous day.

Priscilla Presley will serve as a witness at the inaugural wedding in Las Vegas’s new Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel, located at the Westgate Hotel (formerly the Las Vegas Hilton, where Elvis performed 830 sold-out shows). She teamed up with NBC’s Today show for a contest in which one Elvis-obsessed couple wins the “ultimate wedding” on April 23, including a free reception, hotel stay, airfare, and tickets to the Elvis Experience show. Priscilla emphasized a “first-class” ceremony—no Elvis impersonators—and has helped shape the chapel, which is part of the first permanent Graceland exhibit outside Memphis. Couples enter by submitting a video or photos and a statement on why they deserve to be the first to marry there.

Liverpool vice-captain Jordan Henderson believes the team can catch Manchester City in the Premier League after a 2-0 win over Newcastle. Both Henderson and Simon Mignolet made their 47th appearances of the season in that match, tying the top total across Europe’s major leagues so far. Despite recent poor results against Manchester United and Arsenal, Liverpool are now only four points behind City. Raheem Sterling opened the scoring early, and Joe Allen capitalized on a defensive mistake to secure victory. Allen admitted Newcastle might have deserved a penalty but was relieved to score his first Anfield goal and help the team regain form in the top-four race.

Roma secured a vital 1-0 home victory over Napoli, ending a four-month winless run at the Stadio Olimpico. Miralem Pjanic found the net in the 25th minute, calmly slotting home after a swift counter-attack involving Juan Iturbe and Alessandro Florenzi. Goalkeeper Morgan De Sanctis then preserved the narrow lead with a series of outstanding saves, particularly in the second half against Dries Mertens and Manolo Gabbiadini.

With the win, Roma moved four points ahead of city rivals Lazio in second place, following seven matches without a home triumph. Napoli, meanwhile, extended their own winless streak to five games, remaining fifth in the standings.

Increased security measures were implemented due to a previous incident involving a Napoli supporter, and 1,000 police officers were present. However, no significant disturbances occurred. Roma were missing the injured Francesco Totti and Gervinho, but managed to secure an important three points as they continue their push for Champions League qualification.

Doncaster Rovers have endured a lackluster League One season, entrenched in mid-table with little excitement. Their recent home fixture against Fleetwood Town, whose play-off hopes had all but vanished, ended in a goalless draw that produced minimal on-field action. The match highlights on Doncaster’s YouTube channel ran just 27 seconds—14 of which showed actual play—reflecting the drab encounter of kickoff, a goal kick, and the final whistle.

A man, identified as Roland Giroux, has developed a close bond with his blood parrot cichlid. After removing two other aggressive fish from its tank, he began hand-feeding and gently stroking the cichlid, which soon responded by willingly returning for massages. The fish remains still and appears to enjoy being touched, even becoming frustrated when it is not played with daily. Giroux spends about 15 minutes a day interacting with his pet, which is a hybrid of the midas and redhead cichlids first bred in Taiwan around 1986.

Ben Stokes is highlighted as a fiery, aggressive cricketer whose passion must be carefully managed so it translates into productive performances. The passage recalls his past injury at Kensington Oval (caused by punching a locker) and his recent confrontation with Marlon Samuels, after which coach Peter Moores advised him on controlling his responses. England values Stokes’s energy and skill, recognizing that while he must remain competitive, he needs to channel his aggression sensibly. There is some debate over team selection—specifically whether to include an extra spinner—but England ultimately wants Stokes and fellow all-rounder Chris Jordan to gain experience, seeing them as key long-term assets.

Wales’ Euro 2016 qualifier against Belgium on June 12 is a 33,000 sell-out at Cardiff City Stadium. Both teams lead Group B on 11 points, with Belgium on top by goal difference. Wales’ 3-0 win in Israel boosted hopes of their first major finals since 1958. Despite the Millennium Stadium’s larger capacity, UEFA rules and player preference kept the match at the smaller Cardiff venue. The Football Association of Wales confirmed overwhelming demand for the tickets following Wales’ strong performance.

England Under-17 coach John Peacock has named his squad for the upcoming UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria, where the team will defend its title after qualifying with a 100 percent record. Placed in Group D alongside Holland, Italy, and the Republic of Ireland, England will open against Italy on May 7 in Burgas, followed by Holland on May 10 and Ireland on May 13. Notable call-ups include Chelsea’s Jay DaSilva and Ike Ugbo, Arsenal’s Chris Willock (called up for the first time) and Stephy Mavididi, and Liverpool duo Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold, who both return after missing the Elite Round of qualifiers. The squad features emerging talent from several Premier League clubs and seeks to build on last year’s championship success.

Manchester City are looking to sign 14-year-old Anderlecht midfielder Evangelos Patoulidis, who is highly rated and has also drawn interest from Arsenal and Barcelona. He previously declined a move to Barcelona at age 12 to continue his studies, and now City have begun compensation talks with Anderlecht’s chairman, Roger Vanden Stock, as manager Manuel Pellegrini plans for the club’s future.

A 33-year-old transgender escort named Vanessa Santillan, originally from Mexico, was found dead at a flat in Fulham, London, at the end of March. She had suffered fatal injuries to her head and neck, consistent with strangulation and beating. A 23-year-old man was arrested in connection with her death and later bailed, pending further questioning. The police have appealed for anyone who had contact with Santillan in the hours before her death to come forward. Santillan had been working as a transgender escort in London and had previously worked in Paris and Miami. Her website indicated she was visiting from Miami and expressed her love for London and Paris in the weeks before her death.

Dawn, who had suffered seven miscarriages and was saving £500 for a gravestone for her buried baby Daniel James, discovered that £207 of this fund was missing. She suspected long-term friend and convicted burglar Jamie, who shared a home with Dawn and her partner. On The Jeremy Kyle Show, a lie detector test confirmed Jamie had indeed taken the money. Dawn felt deeply betrayed, as the stolen amount delayed her plans to properly mark Daniel James’s resting place with a headstone.

ISIS released more than 200 Yazidis—mostly women, children, and some ill or elderly—who had been captured when ISIS overran Yazidi towns in northern Iraq. Arab tribal leaders helped coordinate the release, though the exact number varies between 217 and 228. The Yazidis, an ancient Kurdish-descended minority, have long faced persecution, with ISIS killing hundreds and reportedly enslaving and raping captives. When ISIS took the town of Sinjar, many Yazidis fled into nearby mountains, creating a humanitarian crisis. In response, an international coalition provided airdrops, rescues, and airstrikes against ISIS in Iraq and Syria. Approximately 500,000 Yazidis live in northern Iraq, accounting for less than 1% of Iraq’s population.

Harry Kane has enjoyed a remarkable breakthrough season at Tottenham, earning a place in Roy Hodgson’s England side and nominations for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Year awards. A clever new animation by Copa90 showcases some of his standout goals—like his long-range strike against Chelsea, a headed finish against Arsenal, and his scoring debut for England. Titled “Harry Kane – PFA Player of the Year?”, the video highlights his prolific form and goal celebrations, released just before the awards ceremony in which he competes against top contenders such as Eden Hazard and Alexis Sanchez.

Jamie Carragher supports Brendan Rodgers as Liverpool manager despite a third consecutive season without a trophy and a likely finish outside the top four. Carragher believes new players have not fully settled, but that with the right signings, Liverpool can improve next season. He emphasizes that Rodgers should remain in charge and focus on strengthening the team. Carragher also received a Beacon Award for his charitable efforts on Merseyside, where his 23 Foundation provides coaching and support in underprivileged areas.

James Hayward, a four-year-old boy, had his brightly colored plastic nerf gun confiscated by security at East Midlands Airport before a family flight to Lanzarote. Security officers deemed the toy a prohibited item, frisked James, and took the gun—actions the boy’s father called “ludicrous” and “over-zealous.” Although the airport offered to mail the toy back, the family declined due to time constraints. Upon returning home, they purchased a replacement toy online. East Midlands Airport defended its decision by citing government regulations that prohibit items resembling real weapons.

A man from Humpty Doo, Northern Territory—identified only as Rich—posted a Gumtree ad seeking a girlfriend or wife with specific requirements. He wants someone who loves pets, is fit, attractive, a good cook, “great in bed,” and can be both outdoorsy and a “princess.” Rich, 31, describes himself as athletic, heavily tattooed, financially successful, and “well endowed.” He doesn’t drink, smoke, or use drugs and offers potential benefits like accommodation, a gym membership, and possibly a company car. Former partners need not apply. Daily Mail Australia was unable to contact him.

FA chairman Greg Dyke seeks to raise the required number of home-grown players in Premier League squads from eight to twelve and redefine “home-grown” as three years of training in England before age 18, rather than 21. Although the proposals face Premier League opposition, five former England managers—Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven-Goran Eriksson, and Steve McClaren—have endorsed Dyke. In a letter, they argue that blocking these changes will harm England’s national team progress and note that only 81 of 220 Premier League starters in a recent round were England-eligible. They cite emerging talents like Ross Barkley, Raheem Sterling, and Harry Kane to prove that young English players can thrive if given more opportunities.

Demelza Poldark, who was barely showing her pregnancy in the previous episode, rapidly advances to eight months pregnant and then gives birth within minutes in the next installment. Ross Poldark, played by Aidan Turner, is shown adoring his new baby daughter, confirming his devotion to Demelza. Viewers have noticed the abrupt timeline, with some joking on Twitter that in “Poldark,” a pregnancy can be over in just ten minutes. This mirrors a similar rush in a previous storyline involving Elizabeth. Despite the sudden progression, fans remain captivated by the romance between Ross and Demelza.

Leicester City, who remain bottom of the Premier League but just three points from safety after two consecutive wins, are preparing to host Swansea. Manager Nigel Pearson credits the recent 3-2 victory at West Brom—including a late winning goal from Jamie Vardy—for boosting the team’s survival hopes. However, Pearson insists his players must stay focused on their own performances rather than worrying about other struggling teams. He warns against overconfidence and emphasizes that maintaining control of their destiny will be crucial in their bid to avoid relegation.

Varvara, a North Pacific gray whale, set a new mammal migration record by traveling nearly 14,000 miles from her feeding grounds near Russia’s Sakhalin Island to Baja, Mexico, surpassing the previous 10,190-mile mark held by a humpback whale. Researchers at Oregon State University noted that her route covered three major breeding areas for eastern gray whales, suggesting Varvara, once thought to be a western gray whale, may actually be an eastern gray—a finding that could mean the already small western gray whale population (believed to be about 150) is even lower.

A stretch of seabed along the Shiretoko Peninsula in eastern Hokkaido, Japan, rose up to 50 feet above the water overnight. Geologists attribute the sudden change to a nearby landslide caused by melting ice and snow, which pivoted the underwater area to the surface. Measuring roughly 1,000–1,640 feet in length and about 100 feet in width, the new landmass appeared with no warning; residents heard no sounds or tremors. Local officials say it likely isn’t related to any earthquakes, and they do not expect the risen coastline to expand further. Marine organisms remain attached to the newly exposed land.

Gregory van der Wiel denies any intention to leave Paris Saint-Germain, expressing happiness with the club, city, and teammates. He acknowledges his recent disagreement with manager Laurent Blanc about being dropped for the Chelsea match, but stresses he remains committed and ready to play. Despite rumors linking PSG with Barcelona’s Dani Alves, van der Wiel insists he wants to stay and sign a new contract.

Carlos Tevez wishes to leave Juventus this summer, even though his contract runs until 2016. Boca Juniors’ president Daniel Angelici has confirmed they are close to reacquiring him, but first Tevez must formally end his agreement with the Italian club. Tevez began his career with Boca’s youth academy in 1996 and has frequently said he intends to finish his career there. Juventus, while reluctant to lose their top scorer, have accepted his intention to depart and are already seeking replacements. Argentina manager Tata Martino recognizes Tevez’s desire to return to Boca but emphasizes it has no impact on his national team prospects.

Bayern Munich overturned a two-goal first-leg deficit to defeat Porto 6–1 and advance to the Champions League semi-finals. During the match, Pep Guardiola tore the left leg of his trousers in the excitement, briefly revealing his underwear and prompting him to joke about needing a new pair. Bayern’s dominant performance featured goals by Thiago Alcantara, Jerome Boateng, Thomas Muller, Xabi Alonso, and two from Robert Lewandowski, leaving Porto overwhelmed and securing Bayern’s place among Europe’s final four.

Ten people, including four children, were involved in a three-vehicle crash on the Brisbane Valley Highway near Fernvale. Four patients with more serious injuries (two adults and two children) were airlifted to the Princess Alexandra Hospital. Six others, including an infant and two young girls, were taken to Ipswich Hospital with minor injuries or for assessment. Emergency services freed a trapped individual using hydraulic cutting equipment. The highway was closed for several hours with diversions in place south of Fernvale.

Arsenal’s Mesut Ozil has shown off a new Apple Watch ahead of his team’s crucial Premier League match against Chelsea. Ozil likened it to the device used by Michael Knight in the TV show “Knight Rider.” He is expected to start Sunday’s game, with Arsenal aiming to close a 10-point gap on league leaders Chelsea. The Gunners also welcome back Jack Wilshere following a lengthy injury absence. Club legend Ray Parlour believes Wilshere can become a key player if he manages to stay fit, contrasting his situation with the injury struggles of Abou Diaby.

Referee Mark Clattenburg will take charge of Sunday’s Manchester derby at Old Trafford, having previously sent off three Manchester-based players this season—including City’s Vincent Kompany on international duty and United’s Tyler Blackett and Luke Shaw in Premier League matches. Kompany’s dismissal leaves him suspended for Belgium’s upcoming game against Wales. Despite accusations of favoring Manchester United, Clattenburg has issued just two Premier League red cards in total this season—both to United players. The derby comes at a pivotal time: United have won five straight league matches, overtaking City by one point, and the result could impact who finishes second behind Chelsea. Clattenburg will be assisted by Simon Beck, Jake Collin, and fourth official Jonathan Moss.

Bob Katter accused the Queensland Government of assuming Billy Gordon—recently expelled from the Labor Party over domestic violence allegations and a concealed criminal history—would simply resign, likening that assumption to treating him as a “little black puppet on a string.” Katter, who is of Lebanese descent, referenced his own experiences of racism to defend his terminology, sparking criticism on social media. Despite the backlash, Katter maintained that his remarks were meant to highlight underlying racial bias. He cited previous federal independents, warning that Gordon should not become a “puppet” of the government but remain genuinely independent. Gordon, meanwhile, has chosen to stay in parliament as an independent, jeopardizing the government’s narrow majority.

Nineteen-year-old Dayna Dobias from Downers Grove, Illinois, was born with cerebral palsy and faces bullying and misconceptions about her abilities. Despite this, she has created dancing videos—including one set to Taylor Swift’s “Shake It Off”—to show she is “just the same as everyone else,” even if she does things differently. Dayna hopes to break stereotypes, inspire others, and encourage people to look beyond her disability. She also speaks at local schools, demonstrating her determination and capability—doctors once said she might never walk, yet she now confidently dances and leads a life similar to other nineteen-year-olds.

Orlando City have shown interest in signing Manchester United forward Javier Hernandez, whose loan spell at Real Madrid has been unproductive. Known to have a large Latin-American fanbase and led on the field by captain Kaka, the Florida MLS franchise believes Hernandez would be a popular and commercially valuable addition. However, several European clubs—including Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, Everton, Wolfsburg, AC Milan, Lazio, and Inter Milan—are also keen on acquiring Hernandez, and United are reportedly willing to sell him for around £8 million.

Separately, Manchester United have made a revised contract offer to 19-year-old Andreas Pereira. The highly rated midfielder has attracted attention from European clubs such as Paris Saint-Germain, Juventus, PSV Eindhoven, and Feyenoord after rejecting United’s initial offer. He was on the bench for United’s match against Aston Villa.

A group of at least three suspects attempted to carjack a man at a 76 Station in South Los Angeles around 12:15am on Saturday. During an argument at the pump, they doused his white Dodge Charger in gasoline—while two passengers were inside—and set it on fire. Although the vehicle’s front end was destroyed, no one was injured. The Los Angeles County Fire Department is investigating the incident as arson, and the suspects remain at large. Surveillance footage is being used to assist the investigation.

Charles Manuel, a chiropractor from Lamoni, Iowa, surrendered his license after admitting he accepted sex as payment for services and performed exorcisms on patients. As part of an agreement with the Iowa Board of Chiropractic, he cannot seek reinstatement for at least 10 years and must show that the circumstances surrounding his misconduct—namely bartering sex for treatment and advising patients to discontinue prescribed medication—are resolved before resuming practice. Despite these serious charges, Manuel received high patient satisfaction ratings on HealthGrades.com, where he had three positive reviews.

A U.S. RC-135U reconnaissance plane was flying in international airspace over the Baltic Sea north of Poland when a Russian SU-27 intercepted it. U.S. officials described the interception as "unsafe and unprofessional" due to the Russian jet’s aggressive maneuvers and high speed. Russia claimed the U.S. plane was headed toward its border with its transponder off, which U.S. officials deny. The United States plans to file a formal diplomatic complaint about the incident. This mirrors a similar complaint last year when another Russian SU-27 flew dangerously close to a RC-135U.

An FBI agent’s sniper rifle was stolen overnight from the agent’s car parked at the Marriott Springhill Suites in Salt Lake City, just days before President Obama’s visit. The rifle was inside a hard case chained and padlocked in the vehicle, but thieves broke the rear passenger-side window, apparently used a rope and another vehicle’s momentum to rip the case free, and escaped with the weapon. Other items, including a gear bag and clothing, were also taken; some were later found at a nearby hotel. The sniper rifle remains missing, and the theft was reported to the Secret Service before the president’s arrival. The hotel, located near the state’s FBI office, had no surveillance cameras. Police say they are unsure whether the agent’s car was specifically targeted.

Luigi Costa, aged 71, is accused of killing his neighbor, Terrence Freebody, in Canberra in July 2012 by stomping on his head, cutting his throat, and stabbing him multiple times. A forensic psychiatrist, Professor Paul Mullen, testified that Costa’s deteriorating mental condition—primarily dementia exacerbated by alcohol—likely caused confusion and an inability to understand his actions or their consequences. Evidence discussed included fluctuating moods in emergency calls and a trail of faeces, suggesting Costa’s disoriented state. Prosecutors questioned whether Costa was feigning memory loss, but Professor Mullen stood by his assessment. Costa’s mental state at the time of the incident is crucial to determining whether a not guilty verdict is possible.

Everton faced another penalty issue when Ross Barkley, rather than proven penalty-taker Leighton Baines, took (and missed) a 10th-minute spot-kick against Burnley. Manager Roberto Martinez defended Barkley’s decision, saying players can decide based on confidence if Romelu Lukaku is unavailable. Baines, who has a strong penalty record, was willing to let Barkley step up. Though Barkley’s effort was saved, Everton still won 1-0 thanks to Kevin Mirallas’s goal. Martinez praised Barkley for showing responsibility, recalling a previous penalty controversy in January when Mirallas took the ball from Baines and missed.

Two Holland America Line passengers were found dead in their stateroom on the ms Ryndam in what appears to be a murder-suicide. The discovery occurred at 11:30 a.m. on Thursday while the ship, which departed Tampa on March 29 for a 14-day Southern Caribbean cruise, was docked in San Juan, Puerto Rico. Cruise line staff immediately notified authorities, including the FBI, which is now investigating. The deceased were discovered by cleaning staff who had knocked on the cabin door.

Patrick Kluivert, formerly a Holland forward and Louis van Gaal’s assistant, guided Curacao to the second round of 2018 World Cup CONCACAF qualifying with a 4-3 aggregate win over Montserrat. After winning the first leg 2-1, Curacao drew 2-2 in the return match, with Charlton Vicento scoring the crucial equalizer in the 87th minute. They will next face Cuba in June. Kluivert, whose mother is from Curacao, was a World Cup semifinalist as a player in 1998 and as an assistant coach in 2014.

Esteban Cambiasso, an Argentinian midfielder with a highly decorated career at clubs including Real Madrid, Inter Milan, and River Plate, believes helping Leicester City avoid relegation will feel like winning a trophy. Despite Leicester sitting bottom of the Premier League and being seven points adrift with only eight games left, Cambiasso remains optimistic, emphasizing that there is still a quarter of the season to fight for survival. He joined Leicester on a one-year deal and quickly became a key player, but his future beyond this season is uncertain. Nonetheless, Cambiasso is enjoying life in the East Midlands, stating that both he and his family are happy, and he remains focused on securing enough points to keep Leicester in the Premier League.

Gemma, a 23-year-old mother of two children by different fathers, handed both infants over to her mother Debbie when each was four months old. Debbie stepped in to raise them after social services threatened to remove the children, citing Gemma’s persistent drinking, partying, and drug use (including MKat). Debbie also accuses Gemma of stealing an iPad intended for one child, which Gemma denies, though admits to prior theft. Because of Gemma’s continued behavior and apparent lack of concern for the children, Debbie is prepared to ban her from visiting and assumes sole responsibility for raising her grandchildren, who now call Debbie “mum” rather than Gemma.

Chelsea took the lead against Manchester United at Stamford Bridge after Eden Hazard scored following a tackle on Radamel Falcao by John Terry. The ball broke free to Cesc Fabregas, who found Oscar; Oscar’s back-heel then set up Hazard. During Sky Sports’ halftime analysis, pundits Graeme Souness, Thierry Henry, and Jamie Redknapp unanimously agreed Terry’s tackle was a foul—Souness noting an “elbow in the back,” Henry saying he would want a foul in that position “all day long,” and Redknapp concluding the challenge “shouldn’t have gone unpunished.”

Lady Antebellum singer Hillary Scott’s tour bus caught fire on Interstate 30 near Dallas. Scott, her husband, the tour manager, and the driver all evacuated safely after a rear tire blew out. Flames engulfed the back of the bus, destroying nearly everything except Scott’s Bible. Band members Charles Kelley and Dave Haywood were not on board. Lady Antebellum is scheduled to perform at the 50th Academy of Country Music Awards on Sunday.

Dr. Adrian Quarterman from Dundee University is developing satellites equipped with mirrors and semiconductors to harvest sunlight, convert it into laser energy, and beam it back to Earth—potentially making solar power viable even in places like Scotland and quickly restoring power in disaster zones. Although popular culture depicts lasers as destructive, these beams would be far less powerful than sci-fi versions and unlikely to pose a major threat; however, Quarterman acknowledges the importance of controlling who operates such technology. Separately, Tokyo researchers propose a laser on the International Space Station to push tiny pieces of space debris into Earth’s atmosphere to burn up—again not powerful enough to serve as a weapon.

Stephen Munden, a 54-year-old with learning difficulties and a documented obsessive interest in young girls, was detained under the Mental Health Act following his conviction for sexually touching a three-year-old. He vanished from a psychiatric hospital near Hook, Hampshire, on Tuesday evening, prompting a police manhunt. Munden, who may have shaved his beard, is described as about 5ft 8ins with a heavy build. Previously, he had been found in possession of indecent images of children and was discovered with children’s clothing, books, and dolls. He denied deliberately touching the toddler, but a court deemed his move from non-contact to contact offences significant, resulting in the hospital order. Authorities urge anyone with information on Munden’s whereabouts to contact them immediately.

A Los Angeles judge ordered V. Stiviano to return over $2.6 million in gifts that Donald Sterling had purchased for her with marital funds. Shelly Sterling sued Stiviano, accusing her of exploiting wealthy older men and pointing to luxury cars, a $1.8 million duplex, and smaller items as improperly funded by the couple’s money. Stiviano claimed she never took advantage of Donald Sterling, who was ousted from the NBA after leaked audio revealed his racist comments about African-Americans, including Magic Johnson. The court ruling pleased Shelly Sterling’s side, which said it set a precedent that an “injured spouse” may recover gifts given to a third party.

Thierry Henry criticizes Arsenal’s recent transfer activities and insists they need four key signings—a goalkeeper, center back, defensive midfielder, and top striker—to challenge for the Premier League. Speaking on Sky Sports, he highlights Chelsea’s example of recruiting top-quality players like Courtois, Matic, Fabregas, and Costa. Henry specifically questions whether Olivier Giroud, despite his 14 league goals, can lead Arsenal to the title, suggesting that Arsenal must bring in a higher-caliber striker to succeed.

A young woman described extensive abuse by former Bega Cheese boss Maurice Van Ryn, who has pleaded guilty to multiple sex offences, including persistent sexual abuse of a child. She revealed in court that, as a child, she did not initially recognize his behavior as illegal, and kept silent for years until learning of his arrest. She testified about her severe emotional and psychological struggles as a result of the abuse, including depression, suicidal thoughts, hospitalizations for self-harm, and ongoing fears related to future relationships. The court hearing is continuing.

Serge Gnabry, a 19-year-old Arsenal midfielder, spent over a year sidelined by a serious knee injury, having last featured for the first team in March 2014. After impressing previously, his progress was halted by this setback. Recently, he completed two full matches for Arsenal’s Under-21 side, including a 1-0 loss to Reading, and reports feeling “better and better” as he nears a long-awaited first-team return.

Jacob Phillips, a 23-year-old accountant, died after falling 70 feet from a cliff in Penarth, South Wales. He and two friends had taken a taxi home from a night out but did not have enough money for the fare. Attempting to evade payment, they ran from the cab, and Phillips vaulted a fence in the dark without realizing a steep drop lay ahead. The following morning, his body was discovered at the base of the cliff by a dog walker. An inquest concluded his death was accidental, noting he was likely disoriented and unaware of the danger just beyond the fence. Phillips had studied accountancy at the University of Birmingham and worked for Liam Gallagher’s clothing label, Pretty Green.

Thousands of holidaymakers were affected by severe passport delays last summer, yet most received no compensation. Despite making a £42 million profit during the backlog, the Passport Office awarded managers bonuses of up to £3,500. Ministers refused to offer a blanket refund for extra fees paid to expedite documents or for trips missed, approving only 2,191 compensation claims (with an average payout of £92) out of the thousands affected. The Home Affairs Committee, led by Keith Vaz, was astonished by the low compensation figure—especially as the Passport Office turned a large surplus. Many travelers, like a couple who lost £1,500 on a missed trip, had their claims rejected. The Passport Office admits its complaint database failed, making it unclear how many total claims were denied.

A semi-detached house in Horfield, Bristol—largely unchanged since the 1930s—is up for auction with a guide price of £200,000 to £250,000. Original features include stained-glass windows, a wood-panelled hallway, mint-green and black bathroom, and 1930s kitchen cupboards. The home also retains oil-fired central heating, a brick open-face fire, and vintage tins of produce on a hallway shelf. While some updates, like double glazing, have been made, the property still needs considerable renovation. Auctioneers believe it could be a “collector’s paradise” or perfect for antiques enthusiasts, though the cost of updating may deter developers. The house will be auctioned on April 30 at the County Ground in Bristol.

Colin Kaepernick began his NFL career as a backup to Alex Smith on the San Francisco 49ers. He took over as starting quarterback in the middle of the 2012 season after Smith suffered a concussion, remained the starter for the rest of that season, and led the 49ers to their first Super Bowl appearance since 1994, ultimately losing to the Baltimore Ravens.
Soul Food is a 1997 American comedy-drama film produced by Kenneth "Babyface" Edmonds, Tracey Edmonds, and Robert Teitel, and released by Fox 2000 Pictures.

Anne Rice was born in New Orleans, spent her early life there, then moved to Texas and later San Francisco. Route 495 in Hudson County, New Jersey, is a 3.45-mile freeway connecting the New Jersey Turnpike (I-95) at Secaucus exits 16E and 17 to New York State Route 495 via the Lincoln Tunnel in Weehawken, providing access to Midtown Manhattan.
Telemundo is an American Spanish-language terrestrial television network owned by Comcast through NBCUniversal Telemundo Enterprises.

Damon Albarn grew up in East London and Essex, meeting Graham Coxon at the Stanway School, where together they formed Blur. Blur’s debut album "Leisure" came out in 1991 to mixed reviews. In 2001, a self-titled album by one of Albarn’s bands debuted worldwide, incorporating alternative rock, trip hop, hip hop, electronica, dub, reggae, and pop influences. Albarn’s first solo album, "Everyday Robots," co-produced by Richard Russell, was released on 28 April 2014, featuring collaborations with Brian Eno, Natasha Khan, the Leytonstone City Pentecostal Mission Church Choir, and sampled rants by Lord Buckley.
Mogadishu, also referred to by local names such as Muqdisho or Hamar, is the capital and most populous city of Somalia, housing many of the country’s key national institutions.
“Happiness in Slavery” is a song by the American industrial rock band Nine Inch Nails, featured on their debut EP, Broken (1992).
Andrew Kevin Walker is an American screenwriter, born on August 14, 1964, who has received a BAFTA nomination.

Both the 2007 film and the TV series “Shooter” center on the character Bob Lee Swagger, a skilled Force Recon veteran and expert marksman. In the film, Mark Wahlberg’s Swagger is framed for murder by a rogue private military company. In the TV series, Ryan Phillippe’s Swagger is lured out of exile to thwart a plot to kill the president.
"House" (also known as "House, M.D.") is an American television medical drama that aired on the Fox network for eight seasons, from November 16, 2004, to May 21, 2012.

Charles Manson was found guilty in 1971 of first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder for the deaths of seven people, including actress Sharon Tate, carried out by his followers under his instruction. He also received first-degree murder convictions for the deaths of Gary Hinman and Donald “Shorty” Shea. After he was charged, commercial recordings of songs written and performed by Manson were released.

Sean Penn, born August 17, 1960, is an American actor, filmmaker, and political activist who began his career with a television appearance on Little House on the Prairie (1974), directed by his father. After his film debut in Taps (1981) and roles in the 1980s (such as Fast Times at Ridgemont High), he received critical acclaim for crime dramas including At Close Range, State of Grace, and Carlito’s Way. His breakthrough as a leading actor came with Dead Man Walking (1995), earning him his first Academy Award nomination and the Best Actor Award at the Berlin Film Festival. Additional Oscar nominations followed for Sweet and Lowdown (1999) and I Am Sam (2001), and he ultimately won Best Actor Oscars for Mystic River (2003) and Milk (2008).

Don Bradman, known as “The Don,” was an Australian cricketer recognized as the greatest batsman ever. Born on 27 August 1908 and passing away on 25 February 2001, he maintained his influence for thirty years after retiring by serving as an administrator, selector, and writer.

L.A. Reid has held top executive roles across major record labels, serving as chairman and CEO of Epic Records (a Sony Music division), president and CEO of Arista Records, and chairman and CEO of Island Def Jam Music Group.

Brad Wilk is chiefly recognized as the drummer for Rage Against the Machine (1991–2000, 2007–2011) and Audioslave (2001–2007). He began his career with Greta in 1990 and co-founded Rage Against the Machine with Tom Morello and Zack de la Rocha in August 1991. As of 2016, he plays in Prophets of Rage alongside Commerford, Morello, Chuck D, B-Real, and DJ Lord. Separately, the passage notes that "Rage" is the name of a German heavy metal band formed in 1984 by Peter “Peavy” Wagner.

"The Millers" was a multi-camera series that aired on CBS from October 3, 2013, to July 18, 2015, running 34 episodes over two seasons. It was cancelled on November 14, 2014, four episodes into its second season.

This passage describes two individuals named Ann Richards. The first is Dorothy Ann Willis Richards (1933–2006), a Democrat who served as Texas’s 45th governor (1991–1995). She rose to prominence as state treasurer, delivering the keynote address at the 1988 Democratic National Convention, and was known for her outspoken feminism and sharp wit. She was defeated for re-election in 1994 by George W. Bush, and she was the second woman to serve as Texas governor. The second Ann Richards (1935–1982) was an American jazz singer and the wife of pianist Stan Kenton.
Drake Bell independently released an EP titled “A Reminder” in 2011.

"Boardwalk" is a 1979 American drama film written by Stephen Verona and Leigh Chapman and directed by Verona. Janet Leigh (1927–2004), born Jeanette Helen Morrison, was an American actress, singer, dancer, and author who wrote four books between 1984 and 2002, including two novels.

Simón José Antonio de la Santísima Trinidad Bolívar y Palacios, called “El Libertador,” was a Venezuelan military and political leader (born 24 July 1783, died 17 December 1830). He was instrumental in securing independence from Spanish rule for Venezuela, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Panama.

The passage describes the Bermuda Triangle, also called the Devil’s Triangle, as a loosely-defined area in the western North Atlantic Ocean where multiple aircraft and ship disappearances have reportedly occurred under mysterious circumstances.

Colin Kaepernick started in the NFL as Alex Smith’s backup. Partway through the 2012 season, he replaced Smith after an injury and led the San Francisco 49ers to their first Super Bowl appearance since 1994 (losing to the Baltimore Ravens). In the following 2013 season, his first full year as starter, Kaepernick helped the 49ers advance to the NFC Championship Game, where they lost to the Seattle Seahawks.
“Marnie” is a 1964 American psychological thriller film directed by Alfred Hitchcock.

Advertising is a form of marketing communication that presents an openly sponsored, nonpersonal message aimed at promoting a product, service, or idea. It differs from personal selling by not targeting individuals directly. Advertising can be delivered via traditional media (newspapers, magazines, television, radio, outdoor ads, direct mail) and newer digital channels (search engines, blogs, websites, text messages).
"Private Lives" is a 1930 comedy of manners in three acts by Noël Coward, and it is also the title of a 1931 American Pre-Code comedy film directed by Sidney Franklin.

Maurice Harold Macmillan, 1st Earl of Stockton (10 February 1894 – 29 December 1986), was a British Conservative politician and statesman who served as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 10 January 1957 until 19 October 1963.

Aristotle was an ancient Greek philosopher and scientist, born in Stagira, Chalkidice (384–322 BC). He joined Plato’s Academy in Athens at around 17 or 18 years old, studying there until he was about 37 (c. 347 BC). After Plato’s death, he left Athens and, at the request of Philip II of Macedon, began tutoring Alexander the Great in 343 BC.

David Mordechai Packouz, born February 16, 1982, is an American former arms dealer, musician, inventor, and entrepreneur. He created the guitar pedal drum machine known as the BeatBuddy and currently serves as CEO of the music technology company Singular Sound.

Magic Johnson, a point guard for the Los Angeles Lakers for 13 seasons, won championships in both high school and college before being drafted first overall in 1979. He won an NBA title and Finals MVP in his rookie season, then secured four more championships throughout the 1980s. After retiring due to protests from fellow players, Johnson returned in 1996 for 32 games before retiring for good. Beyond basketball, he was named one of America’s most influential Black businessmen by Ebony in 2009, maintaining numerous business ventures and serving as a part-owner of the Lakers for a time.

Tenacious D is a comedy rock duo formed in Los Angeles in 1994, composed of Jack Black and Kyle Gass. They have released three albums—Tenacious D (2001), The Pick of Destiny (2006), and Rize of the Fenix (2012). The band rose to prominence in 1997 through their self-titled TV series and by supporting major rock acts.

James VI and I (1566–1625) was King of Scotland from 1567 and became King of England and Ireland in 1603, ruling both realms under a personal union while each retained its own parliament, laws, and judiciary. He sought a single parliament for Scotland and England, largely succeeded in his aims in Scotland, but faced significant challenges in England, including the 1605 Gunpowder Plot and ongoing tensions with the English Parliament.

Big Brother 2017 (Big Brother 18) is the eighteenth series of the British reality show, hosted by Emma Willis and narrated by Marcus Bentley. Marcus Bentley, born on 4 October 1967, is a British actor, broadcaster, and voice-over artist best known for narrating Big Brother in the UK since 2000. He provided additional continuity announcements for Channel 4 until July 2011, when he continued his Big Brother narration on Channel 5. His distinctive Geordie accent has made him one of Britain’s most recognizable voices.

The Free State of Saxony is a landlocked federal state in eastern Germany. It borders the German states of Brandenburg, Saxony-Anhalt, Thuringia, and Bavaria, as well as Poland and the Czech Republic. Spanning 18,413 km² and home to four million people, Saxony ranks tenth in area and sixth in population among Germany’s sixteen states. Its history stretches back over a millennium. Saxony is also notable as one of Germany’s northernmost wine-producing regions—along with Saale-Unstrut—both located in the former East Germany.
East End Park was once a major league baseball park in Cincinnati’s East End, and “In the End” is a song by the American rock band Linkin Park.
Mel B. Brown’s solo career began when she released the single “I Want You Back” with Missy Elliott on Virgin Records.
Noah Cyrus is the youngest daughter of Billy Ray Cyrus and the younger sister of Miley Cyrus and Trace Cyrus.

Mohra (1994) is an Indian action thriller film directed by Rajiv Rai, starring Akshay Kumar, Sunil Shetty, Raveena Tandon, and Naseeruddin Shah, with Paresh Rawal, Gulshan Grover, Raza Murad, and Sadashiv Amrapurkar in supporting roles. Released on 1 July 1994, it became the second highest-grossing Indian film that year and received nine Filmfare nominations. Originally, Divya Bharti was cast for the female lead, completing several scenes before her untimely passing, after which Raveena Tandon took over. The film is also noted for its chart-topping soundtrack.
“Hourglass” refers both to a song by the British electronic duo Disclosure and to the fourteenth studio album by singer-songwriter James Taylor.

Shane Black, born December 16, 1961, is an American screenwriter, director, producer, and actor. He gained prominence by writing the 1987 action film "Lethal Weapon," and he made his directorial debut in 2005 with "Kiss Kiss Bang Bang."
“A View to a Kill,” released in 1985, is the fourteenth film in the James Bond series and marks Roger Moore’s seventh and final performance as the iconic MI6 agent.

Papua is Indonesia’s largest and easternmost province, occupying most of western New Guinea. Formerly known as Irian Jaya (and earlier as West Irian or Irian Barat), it once encompassed all of Indonesian New Guinea.
Augustus likely died of natural causes, but some unsubstantiated rumors suggest that his wife, Livia, may have poisoned him.

Jennifer Lopez began her music career in 1999 with the album “On the 6,” led by the chart-topping “If You Had My Love.” In 2001, she became the first woman to have a number-one album and film in the same week (with the album “J.Lo” and movie “The Wedding Planner”). Her relationship with Ben Affleck shaped her third album “This Is Me…Then” (2002), although the couple’s notoriety overshadowed the film “Gigli” (2003). Lopez then married Marc Anthony, found box-office success with “Shall We Dance?”, and gave birth to twins in 2008. After a temporary downturn, she reemerged in 2011 as an “American Idol” judge, releasing the smash hit “On the Floor,” one of the best-selling singles of all time.

A working animal is typically a domesticated animal kept and trained by humans to perform tasks such as guiding, providing traction (e.g., draft horses or logging elephants), or assisting with milking and herding. In rare instances, wild animals may be trained for work or entertainment, but they usually lack the dependability and mild temperament of true domesticated working animals.

“Billboard Dad” is a 1998 American direct-to-video comedy film directed by Alan Metter, featuring Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen. “Top Latin Albums” is published by Billboard magazine and is described as the most important chart for Spanish-language, full-length albums in the U.S. music market. Meanwhile, “Regional Mexican Albums” is a genre-specific Billboard chart published weekly in the United States.

Vedam (English: Chant) is a 2010 Telugu-language Indian drama film, written and directed by Radhakrishna Jagarlamudi. It stars Allu Arjun, Manoj Manchu, Anushka Shetty, Manoj Bajpayee, Saranya Ponvannan, Deeksha Seth, Lekha Washington, and Siya Gautham.

Men in Black II (stylized as MIIB) is a 2002 American science fiction action comedy film featuring Tommy Lee Jones, Will Smith, Lara Flynn Boyle, Johnny Knoxville, Rosario Dawson, Tony Shalhoub, and Rip Torn.

Sancho Panza is a fictional character from the 1605 novel Don Quixote by Spanish author Don Miguel de Cervantes Saavedra. As Don Quixote’s squire, he provides commentary—referred to as “sanchismos”—that blend broad humor, ironic Spanish proverbs, and earthy wit.
The passage describes "The Adventures of Pluto Nash" as a 2002 Australian-American science fiction action comedy film featuring Eddie Murphy in a dual role and directed by Ron Underwood.
"Hedda Gabler" had its world premiere on 31 January 1891 at the Residenztheater in Munich, with playwright Henrik Ibsen present for the occasion.
Brazzers is a Montreal-based pornographic production company, known by the pronunciation [ˈbræzərz].
Timothy Simon Roth, born on 14 May 1961, is an English actor and director.

Juventus Football Club, known as Juve, is an Italian football club from Turin, Piedmont, founded in 1897 by young Torinese students—including its first president, Eugenio Canfari, and his brother Enrico. It is the second-oldest active club in Italy, behind Genoa (1893), and has worn its distinctive black and white striped kit since 1903.
