Today, the team plays its home matches at the 41,507-seat Juventus Stadium.

Viola Davis took on supporting and minor roles in the late 1990s and early 2000s, appearing in films like Kate & Leopold (2001) and Far from Heaven (2002), as well as in the television series Law & Order: Special Victims Unit.

Jenna Jameson, born Jenna Marie Massoli on April 9, 1974, is an American entrepreneur, webcam model, and former pornographic film actress, widely regarded as “The Queen of Porn.” She began her adult film career in 1993 after working as a stripper and glamour model.
The New Orleans Pelicans are a National Basketball Association team competing in the NBA’s Western Conference Southwest Division.

Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event held from 1983 to 2000, first by the National Wrestling Alliance (NWA) and later by World Championship Wrestling (WCW). It was initially broadcast on closed-circuit television before moving to pay-per-view. From the 1960s to the 1980s, Jim Crockett Promotions (JCP) held major wrestling events on Thanksgiving and Christmas, often at the Greensboro Coliseum. Within the Starrcade series, the 1985 event was the third annual show under the NWA and JCP, the 1987 event was the fifth, and the 1997 edition was the fifteenth annual pay-per-view.

Jack Ryan Falahee, an American actor born on February 20, 1989, is known for portraying Connor Walsh in the ABC legal drama "How to Get Away with Murder" and Benjamin Stringfellow in the PBS historical drama "Mercy Street."

Seohyun (Seo Ju-hyun, born June 28, 1991) is a South Korean singer and actress who first debuted in August 2007 with the girl group Girls’ Generation—one of South Korea’s best-selling and most popular girl groups worldwide—and later its subgroup TTS. She has also performed in stage musicals such as Moon Embracing the Sun, Gone with the Wind, and Mamma Mia. On January 17, 2017, Seohyun released “Don’t Say No,” her debut extended play, becoming the third Girls’ Generation member to make a solo debut.

The passage describes the Apple II, an 8-bit home computer designed chiefly by Steve Wozniak. It was among the first mass-produced microcomputers, introduced in 1977 by Apple Computer (now Apple Inc.). Steve Jobs contributed by overseeing the machine’s foam-molded plastic case, while Rod Holt developed the power supply. The Apple II series—often stylized as “Apple ][” or “Apple //”—became a family of home computers noted for their success and popularity. Additionally, the passage identifies Steve Wozniak (born in 1950), known as “Woz,” as an American inventor, electronics engineer, programmer, philanthropist, technology entrepreneur, and Apple Inc. co-founder.

A&E, formerly called the Arts & Entertainment Network, is an American cable and satellite television channel. It serves as the flagship property of A&E Networks, which is jointly owned (50% each) by the Hearst Corporation and Disney–ABC Television Group (a subsidiary of the Walt Disney Company).

L.A. Reid is a music executive who has served as chairman and CEO of Epic Records, president and CEO of Arista Records, and chairman and CEO of the Island Def Jam Music Group. He also founded Hitco Music Publishing and co-founded LaFace Records.

The passage describes two films called “Veeram (Valour).” One is a 2014 Indian Tamil action film directed by Siva and produced by Vijaya Productions, and the other is a 2016 Indian epic historical drama written and directed by Jayaraj.

"Home for the Holidays" refers to two different films. The 1972 version is a made-for-television horror film directed by John Llewellyn Moxey, produced by Aaron Spelling, and starring Sally Field, Eleanor Parker, Julie Harris, Jessica Walter, and Walter Brennan; it premiered on ABC on November 28, 1972. The 1995 film stars Holly Hunter, Robert Downey Jr., Anne Bancroft, Charles Durning, Dylan McDermott, Geraldine Chaplin, Steve Guttenberg, Cynthia Stevenson, Claire Danes, Austin Pendleton, and David Strathairn.
Taran Hourie Killam, born April 1, 1982, is an American actor, comedian, and writer.
"The Sex Factor" is an online reality TV series produced by xHamster, featuring eight men and eight women competing to become porn stars.
John Hovig Dolmayan, born on July 15, 1973, is a Lebanese-born Armenian–American songwriter and drummer.
Island Records is a British-American record label that operates as a division of Universal Music Group (UMG).
Sikkim is a northeastern state of India, pronounced [ˈsɪkᵻm].
Christa McAuliffe began working as a social studies teacher at Concord High School in New Hampshire in 1983.
Ronald Bilius “Ron” Weasley is a fictional character featured in J.K. Rowling’s Harry Potter series.
"Reign Over Me" is a 2007 American drama film, written and directed by Mike Binder, produced by his brother Jack Binder, and released by Columbia Pictures on March 23, 2007.
Colin Rand Kaepernick, born November 3, 1987, is an American football quarterback who is currently a free agent.

In 2016, Sheryl Lee appeared in the film Café Society and reprised her role as Laura Palmer in the 2017 Twin Peaks revival. That same year, Sheryl Lee Ralph performed on Broadway as Madame Morrible in Wicked.
Matteo Renzi, born on January 11, 1975, is an Italian politician who served as Italy’s Prime Minister from February 2014 to December 2016.
"The Road to El Dorado" is a film that features Kevin Kline, Kenneth Branagh, Armand Assante, Jim Cummings, Edward James Olmos, Tobin Bell, and Rosie Perez.

Selena Gomez’s second studio album, “Revival,” was released in 2015 and debuted at number one on the Billboard 200. “Same Old Love,” along with “Good for You” and “Hands to Myself,” were the album’s first three singles, each topping the Mainstream Top 40 chart in the United States.
Weekly Idol is a show hosted by comedian Jeong Hyeong-don and rapper Defconn.

Heavy metal is a rock music genre that developed in the late 1960s and early 1970s, mainly in the United Kingdom and the United States. In the late 1970s, bands such as Iron Maiden and Saxon emerged as part of the new wave of British heavy metal, continuing and evolving the style.
Ashton Kutcher continued his career by starring in additional romantic comedies, including Guess Who (2005), A Lot Like Love (2005), What Happens in Vegas (2008), and No Strings Attached (2011).

Topman is part of the Arcadia Group, which also owns Burton, Miss Selfridge, Wallis, Evans, and Dorothy Perkins. It operates a chain of men’s clothing stores across the UK, appearing on nearly every High Street, and has outlets in six cities and towns in Ireland.

Wales experienced a dramatic shift from an agricultural society to an industrial nation during the Industrial Revolution, driven by the mining and metallurgical industries. Exploitation of the South Wales Coalfield in particular spurred rapid population growth.
Tool is a band that has won three Grammy Awards, performed worldwide tours, and produced albums topping the charts in multiple countries.
YouTube is an American video-sharing website based in San Bruno, California, and is ranked by Alexa Internet as the second most popular site in the world.
Sidse Babett Knudsen, born on 22 November 1968, is a Danish actress who works across theatre, television, and film.

Conrad Dunn began his screen career playing Francis “Psycho” Soyer in the 1981 film Stripes, which also served as one of the first significant film roles for John Larroquette, John Diehl, and Judge Reinhold.
Raees is a film that features Shah Rukh Khan, Mahira Khan, and Nawazuddin Siddiqui.
Asylum Records is an American record label established in 1971 by David Geffen and Elliot Roberts.
Trollhunters is an American computer-animated fantasy television series created for Netflix by Guillermo del Toro and produced by DreamWorks Animation and Double Dare You.

The passage describes the Armenian Genocide as the Ottoman government's systematic extermination of 1.5 million Armenians, primarily within the Ottoman Empire and later in its successor state, the Republic of Turkey. It also notes that other Christian minorities, including the Assyrians and Ottoman Greeks, suffered similar fates in what some historians regard as part of the same overarching genocidal campaign.
Marcus Morgan Bentley, born on October 4, 1967, is a British actor, broadcaster, and voice-over artist.

William Jefferson Clinton, born on August 19, 1946, served as the 42nd President of the United States from 1993 to 2001. His first inauguration took place on January 20, 1993, at the West Front of the U.S. Capitol in Washington, D.C.

Danny Boyle, born on 20 October 1956, is an English director, producer, screenwriter, and theatre director known for films such as Shallow Grave, Trainspotting, The Beach, 28 Days Later, Sunshine, Slumdog Millionaire, 127 Hours, and Steve Jobs. The Beach (2000), one of his works, is an adventure drama film adapted from a 1996 novel by Alex Garland, with the screenplay written by John Hodge.
Over the course of its first week online, “the dress” image generated over 10 million tweets, with widespread discussion centered on hashtags including #thedress, #whiteandgold, and #blackandblue.
Major Bruce Middleton Hope Shand MC and bar (22 January 1917 – 11 June 2006) served as an officer in the British Army and was a recipient of the Military Cross and bar.
Advertising is a form of audio or visual marketing communication that is openly sponsored and nonpersonal, used to promote or sell products, services, or ideas.

“The Others” (2001) won eight Goya Awards—among them Best Film and Best Director—becoming the first English-language film to receive the Best Film Award at Spain’s Goyas without including any Spanish dialogue. It was also nominated for six Saturn Awards (including Best Director and Best Writing for Alejandro Amenábar, and Best Performance by a Younger Actor for Alakina Mann), ultimately winning three: Best Horror Film, Best Actress for Nicole Kidman, and Best Supporting Actress for Fionnula Flanagan.

Ralph Fults was a Depression-era outlaw and escape artist, born on January 23, 1911, and died on March 16, 1993. He was associated with Raymond Hamilton, Bonnie Parker, and Clyde Barrow of the Barrow Gang.

The passage describes the 14th Dalai Lama, Tenzin Gyatso (born Lhamo Thondup on July 6, 1935), as the current Dalai Lama. Selected in 1937 as the reincarnation of the 13th Dalai Lama and formally recognized in 1939, he was born in Taktser village in Amdo, Tibet. Following the 1959 Tibetan uprising, he fled to India, where he continues to live as a refugee.

“Miracle at St. Anna” follows four Buffalo Soldiers of the 92nd Infantry Division who, in World War II, find refuge in a small Tuscan village. The story unfolds as a flashback narrated by one survivor in 1980s New York, highlighting the bond formed between the soldiers and the local residents.
Caroline Bouvier Kennedy, born on November 27, 1957, is an American author, attorney, and diplomat who served as the United States Ambassador to Japan from 2013 to 2017.

“Home for the Holidays” (1995) is noted for its prominent cast, featuring Holly Hunter, Robert Downey Jr., Anne Bancroft, Charles Durning, Dylan McDermott, Geraldine Chaplin, Steve Guttenberg, Cynthia Stevenson, Claire Danes, Austin Pendleton, and David Strathairn.
Anne Rice was born in New Orleans, where she spent most of her early years before moving to Texas and subsequently relocating to San Francisco.
Stephen Hillenburg was born in Lawton, Oklahoma, and raised in Anaheim, California. As a child, he became fascinated with the ocean and also developed an interest in art.

Many religious traditions practice a mendicant lifestyle, such as Catholic mendicants, Hindu ascetics, dervishes in Sufi Islam, and various monastic orders in Jainism and Buddhism. A “monk,” from Greek monachos (meaning “single” or “solitary”), is someone who lives a religiously ascetic life—either alone or in a community—often dedicating themselves to serving others or withdrawing from mainstream society for prayer and contemplation.
“The Mod Squad” is an American crime drama TV series that aired on ABC from 1968 to 1973.
"The Dark Tower" is an upcoming American movie that blends science fantasy, western, action, and horror genres, and it is directed and co-written by Nikolaj Arcel.

Arizona is a southwestern U.S. state, the sixth largest and 14th most populous of the 50 states. It became the 48th state on February 14, 1912, making it the last of the contiguous states to join the Union. About one-quarter of its land is made up of Indian reservations for 27 federally recognized Native American tribes, including the Navajo Nation, which is the largest in both the state and the country, with more than 300,000 citizens. The state is known for its significant Native American population.
Smriti Mandhana, born on 18 July 1996, is an Indian cricketer representing the Indian women’s cricket team.

Emma Charlotte Duerre Watson, born on 15 April 1990, is a French-British actress, model, and activist. She was born in Paris, brought up in Oxfordshire, attended the Dragon School, and received acting training at the Oxford branch of Stagecoach Theatre Arts.
Angela Bassett began her film career in the mid-1980s, following the completion of her bachelor of arts at Yale University and her master of fine arts from drama school.

The Congressional Space Medal of Honor is NASA's highest award, conferred by the U.S. President in Congress's name upon the NASA Administrator’s recommendation. It recognizes astronauts who demonstrate extraordinary achievements during NASA-authorized spaceflight. Frank Frederick Borman II, born March 14, 1928, is a retired United States Air Force Colonel.
The Saw franchise is a series of films that together earned over $873 million at the worldwide box office.
"Down with Love" is a 2003 romantic comedy film.
Paul Nicholls is an actor best known for portraying Joe Wicks in BBC's EastEnders and DS Sam Casey in ITV's Law & Order: UK.
"Colombiana" is a 2011 French action film co-written and produced by Luc Besson and directed by Olivier Megaton.
Rick Yune was part of the main cast of the Netflix original series "Marco Polo" until the show's cancellation on December 12, 2016.

Kentucky is recognized for horse racing, bourbon distilleries, coal, the historical site My Old Kentucky Home, automobile manufacturing, tobacco, bluegrass music, college basketball, and Kentucky Fried Chicken.
“Boyhood” was filmed from 2002 to 2013 and follows Mason Evans Jr. (portrayed by Coltrane) from ages six to eighteen, growing up in Texas with his divorced parents (played by Arquette and Hawke).
“Hush” is a 2016 film that was produced by Trevor Macy of Intrepid Pictures and Jason Blum under the Blumhouse Productions banner.

The Penibaetic System, also known as the Sistema Penibético or Cordillera Penibética, is the southernmost of three mountain range systems constituting the Baetic System in the southern Iberian Peninsula.

Bonobos is a men’s apparel brand offering suits, trousers, denim, shirts, shorts, swimwear, outerwear, and accessories. Topman is part of the Arcadia Group (which also owns Burton, Miss Selfridge, Wallis, Evans, and Dorothy Perkins) and operates a chain of men’s clothing stores across the UK and in main street outlets in six Irish cities and towns.
"Roar" is a song by American singer Katy Perry from her fourth studio album, Prism (2013). It was released as the lead single on August 10, 2013.
Saturn Corporation (also known as Saturn LLC) was established as a registered trademark on January 7, 1985, functioning as a subsidiary of General Motors.

The passage describes the systematic extermination of 1.5 million Armenians by the Ottoman government, known as the Armenian Genocide or Armenian Holocaust, which began in 1915 and primarily affected Ottoman citizens. It also notes that modern Turkey, as the successor to the Ottoman Empire, rejects the term "genocide" in reference to these events.

Muslims believe the Quran was verbally revealed by God to Muhammad through the angel Gabriel over about 23 years, beginning on 22 December 609 CE when Muhammad was 40, and ending in 632, the year of his death.

The passage describes the human brain as part of the central nervous system along with the spinal cord. It is composed of three major parts—the cerebrum (the largest portion), the brainstem, and the cerebellum. Beneath the cerebral cortex lie several crucial structures, including the thalamus, epithalamus, pineal gland, hypothalamus, pituitary gland, subthalamus, the limbic system (amygdala and hippocampus), the claustrum, the basal ganglia, the basal forebrain, and three circumventricular organs.
"T2 Trainspotting" is a 2017 British comedy drama film set around Edinburgh in Scotland.
AMGTV is an American family-oriented television network offering a range of content, including drama, sports, movies, entertainment, how-to, hunting and fishing, children’s shows, and other features.

Sir Donald George “Don” Bradman (1908–2001), often called “The Don,” was an Australian cricketer hailed as the greatest batsman ever. Despite becoming reclusive in later years, his views remained highly valued, and he was recognized as a national icon. In 2001, more than 50 years after his retirement, Prime Minister John Howard referred to him as “the greatest living Australian.”

Margaret Hilda Thatcher (1925–2013) was a British stateswoman who served as Prime Minister from 1979 to 1990 and led the Conservative Party from 1975 to 1990. She was the 20th century’s longest-serving British prime minister and the first woman to hold that role. Additionally, her 1975 leadership victory made her the first woman to lead a major UK political party.

Randy Mario Poffo, known by the ring name “Macho Man” Randy Savage, was an American professional wrestler and color commentator, born on November 15, 1952, and passing on May 20, 2011. He was best known for his work in the World Wrestling Federation (now WWE) and later in World Championship Wrestling (WCW).
Alice Cooper, born Vincent Damon Furnier on February 4, 1948, is an American singer, songwriter, and actor with a career spanning over five decades.

EA Black Box, originally named Black Box Games, was a video game developer founded in 1998 by former Radical Entertainment employees. Based in Burnaby, British Columbia, Canada, the company was later acquired by Electronic Arts (EA).

Baiae was an ancient mineral springs and coastal resort on the Gulf of Naples. Nearby Herculaneum, overshadowed by Mount Vesuvius, was destroyed by pyroclastic flows in 79 AD; its remains lie in Ercolano, Campania. The Naples area contains significant cultural sites, including the Palace of Caserta and the Roman ruins of Pompeii and Herculaneum. Around the world, numerous renowned ruins exist, spanning China, the Indus Valley, Judea, Africa (Zimbabwe), the Mediterranean (Greek, Egyptian, Roman), and the Americas (Incan and Mayan).

"No Country for Old Men" is a cat-and-mouse drama set in 1980 West Texas, featuring Tommy Lee Jones, Javier Bardem, and Josh Brolin. The story follows a Texas welder and Vietnam veteran. Tommy Lee Jones, who stars in this film as Sheriff Ed Tom Bell, has had numerous notable roles, including Woodrow F. Call in "Lonesome Dove," Agent K in the "Men in Black" series, the villain Two-Face in "Batman Forever," William Strannix in "Under Siege," a Texas Ranger in "Man of the House," and rancher Pete Perkins in "The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada" (which he directed). He also portrayed Colonel Chester Phillips in "Captain America: The First Avenger," CIA Director Robert Dewey in "Jason Bourne," and Warden Dwight McClusky in "Natural Born Killers."

Palo Alto is a charter city in the northwest corner of Santa Clara County, California, within the San Francisco Bay Area. Its name, derived from Spanish words meaning “tall tree,” reflects the literal meaning “stick” and colloquial meaning “tree” for “palo” and “tall” for “alto.”

Albert Lawrence Brooks (born Albert Lawrence Einstein on July 22, 1947) is an American actor, filmmaker, author, and comedian. The film Finding Dory was directed by Andrew Stanton, co-directed by Angus MacLane, and the screenplay was written by Stanton and Victoria Strouse.

Morse code is a method of text transmission using on-off signals in tones, lights, or clicks, designed so character length is inversely related to its frequency in English. It remains understandable under poor signal conditions and can be used by humans without a special decoder. It appears in amateur radio repeater identifications and, because it can be improvised using simple on-off signals, is a highly versatile emergency communication tool.
Alexandra Anna Daddario is an American actress, born on March 16, 1986.

A 6.5-magnitude earthquake struck northeastern Afghanistan on December 12, 2005, at 21:47 UTC. The quake occurred in the Hindu Kush region, an 800 km mountain range along the Afghan-Pakistan border that extends from central Afghanistan to northern Pakistan. Known historically as the Caucasus Indicus or Paropamisadae, the Hindu Kush features numerous high snow-capped peaks, with its tallest being Tirich Mir at 7708 m in Pakistan’s Chitral District.
Ripon College in Wisconsin had about 840 students in 2015, with most living on campus.

Fox Sports is a global brand for sports channels and media controlled or partly owned by Rupert Murdoch’s family. Murdoch served as Chairman and CEO of News Corporation—once the world’s second-largest media conglomerate—and, following its 2013 split, he and his family currently own both successor companies, News Corp and 21st Century Fox, through the Murdoch Family Trust.
Wildfang is an American clothing brand that specializes in women’s tomboy-style apparel.
Bessie Smith, born April 15, 1894 and died September 26, 1937, was an American blues singer.

Speech recognition is an interdisciplinary sub-field of computational linguistics devoted to creating methods and technologies that allow computers to convert spoken language into text, incorporating research from linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering.

Aleister Crowley, born Edward Alexander Crowley on 12 October 1875 and deceased on 1 December 1947, was an English figure renowned for his work as an occultist, ceremonial magician, poet, painter, novelist, and mountaineer.
"Poldark" is a British-American drama series that first aired on BBC One on March 8, 2015.
“Dilwale Dulhania Le Jayenge,” starring Shah Rukh Khan and Kajol, was released on 20 October 1995. The film was shot in India, London, and Switzerland between September 1994 and August 1995.

Timothy Simon Roth, born on May 14, 1961, is an English actor and director. Meanwhile, Tim Roth, born on December 6, 1975, is a guitarist, backing vocalist, and the only remaining founding member of the Canadian melodic death metal and progressive metal band Into Eternity.
Tatum O’Neal married professional tennis player John McEnroe in 1986, and they had three children together.

Sean Penn, who made his film debut in “Taps” (1981), gained recognition in the 1980s with roles like “Fast Times at Ridgemont High” (1982) and later in crime dramas such as “At Close Range” (1986), “State of Grace” (1990), and “Carlito’s Way” (1993). His performance in “Dead Man Walking” (1995) earned him his first Academy Award nomination and the Best Actor Award at the Berlin Film Festival. Further Oscar nominations came for “Sweet and Lowdown” (1999) and “I Am Sam” (2001), leading to Penn’s first Academy Award win for “Mystic River” (2003) and a second for “Milk” (2008). As a director, his fourth feature, “Into the Wild” (2007), received critical acclaim and two Academy Award nominations.

Earth’s primordial atmosphere and oceans were created by volcanic outgassing, but initially had almost no oxygen, rendering them toxic for most modern life. As the planet cooled, a solid crust and liquid surface water formed. Plate tectonics has continually shaped Earth’s oceans, continents, and life. Nowadays, human activity strongly influences the biosphere, affecting the atmosphere, ozone layer, greenhouse gas levels, soil quality, and water resources. Overall, water covers about 71% of Earth’s surface.
Nuuk, also called Godthåb and pronounced [nuːk], is Greenland’s capital and largest city, located within the municipality of Sermersooq.

"How to Train Your Dragon 2" is written and directed by Dean DeBlois. Its voice cast includes returning actors Jay Baruchel, Gerard Butler, Craig Ferguson, America Ferrera, Jonah Hill, Christopher Mintz-Plasse, T.J. Miller, and Kristen Wiig, plus new additions Cate Blanchett, Djimon Hounsou, and Kit Harington. Blanchett and Hounsou specifically voice Valka and Drago, respectively.

“Down with Love” refers both to a 2003 romantic comedy film and to a Taiwanese TV series. The film, directed by Peyton Reed and written by Eve Ahlert and Dennis Drake, stars Renée Zellweger, Ewan McGregor, Sarah Paulson, and David Hyde Pierce. It is styled as a pastiche of the Doris Day–Rock Hudson sex comedies, particularly “Pillow Talk,” “Lover Come Back,” and “Send Me No Flowers.” The TV series “Down with Love” was first broadcast on Taiwan’s China Television (CTV) from 31 January to 23 May 2010 (Sundays, 22:00–23:30) and on Gala Television (GTV) from 2 February to 30 May 2010 (Sundays, 20:00–21:30).
Paris (Paris Hilton’s album) incorporates reggae, soul, and pop rock elements in its production.

“Stripes” (1981) is an American buddy military comedy directed by Ivan Reitman and starring Bill Murray, Harold Ramis, Warren Oates, P.J. Soles, Sean Young, and John Candy. It marked some of the earliest major roles for John Larroquette, John Diehl, Conrad Dunn, and Judge Reinhold, while Joe Flaherty, Dave Thomas, Timothy Busfield, and Bill Paxton also appeared early in their careers.
Janelle Monáe Robinson, born on December 1, 1985, is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and model who is signed to her own Wondaland Arts Society and Atlantic Records.

Jewell is a singer best known for her track “Love or Lust” in Bill Duke’s film Deep Cover and for providing choruses on notable West Coast rap songs, notably Snoop Dogg's “Gin and Juice” and Dr. Dre’s “Let Me Ride.”

The University of Mississippi draws about 55% of undergraduate students (and 60% of the total student body) from within the state, while 23% of students identify as minorities. Additionally, it hosts international students from 90 different countries.
"The Mighty Ducks" was produced by The Kerner Entertainment Company and Avnet–Kerner Productions, and distributed by Walt Disney Pictures.

Johanna Braddy is an actress who played Jenny Matrix in the web series “Video Game High School” from 2012 to 2014, co-starred as Anna Martin in the 2015 Lifetime series “UnREAL,” and is currently starring as Shelby Wyatt in ABC’s “Quantico.”

Martin Van Buren served as the eighth President of the United States (1837–41). He was a key Democratic figure, previously acting as Andrew Jackson’s eighth Vice President (1833–37) and tenth Secretary of State (1829–31). Van Buren helped organize Jackson’s successful 1828 campaign and briefly served as Governor of New York to bolster Jackson’s election chances. After two months, he resigned the governorship to become Secretary of State. Following his role in resolving the Petticoat affair, Jackson appointed him as American minister to Britain in 1831.
Camden, New Jersey hosts Rutgers University–Camden, originally founded as the South Jersey Law School in 1926, and Cooper Medical School of Rowan University, which opened in 2012.

Michigan is a state in the Great Lakes and Midwestern regions of the United States. It ranks tenth in population and has the eleventh-largest total area (the biggest state east of the Mississippi River). As the only state composed of two peninsulas, it is a major destination for recreational boating. A U.S. state is a constituent political entity within the United States.

Penguin Books transformed publishing in the 1930s by offering affordable, high-quality paperbacks—sold for sixpence through Woolworths and other retailers—making both fiction and non-fiction widely accessible to the mass market.
The 2008 film “Australia” was produced in four Australian locations: Sydney, Darwin, Kununurra, and Bowen.

Billy Ray Cyrus is an American country singer, songwriter, actor, and philanthropist who played a major role in popularizing country music globally. “Excuse My French” is both the title of American rapper French Montana’s debut studio album and a 2014 Egyptian comedy film by director Amr Salama, inspired by his experiences at a public middle school in Egypt after returning from Saudi Arabia. The film initially faced censorship concerns due to its focus on religious discrimination, prompting script revisions to maintain its core message.
Derek Hough starred in the 2013 South Korean-American independent dance film “Make Your Move,” which was inspired by the story of Romeo and Juliet.

“Bad Romance” is a Lady Gaga song from her extended play The Fame Monster (2009). It was showcased at Alexander McQueen’s Paris Fashion Week show in October 2009 after a demo leak, then released with accompanying cover art. The single topped various charts worldwide and sold 12 million copies, placing it among the best-selling singles of all time. Separately, Bad Romance is also the title of a 2011 independent drama film (Les Mauvais Romans).

DreamWorks Animation has released 34 feature films, encompassing popular franchises such as Shrek (and its prequel-spinoff Puss in Boots), Madagascar, Kung Fu Panda, How to Train Your Dragon, and Trolls, as well as other hits including Monsters vs. Aliens (2009), Rise of the Guardians (2012), The Croods (2013), and Home (2015). The passage also notes that Trollhunters is an American computer-animated fantasy series, created by Guillermo del Toro for Netflix, and produced by DreamWorks Animation and Double Dare You.

Chris Eubank (born 1966) is a British former professional boxer who competed from 1985 to 1998. Chris Eubank Jr. (born 1989) is a British professional boxer who has held the IBO super-middleweight title since February 2017; he previously held the WBA interim middleweight title in 2015 and the British middleweight title in 2016. As of May 2017, Eubank Jr. ranks fifth at super middleweight (BoxRec), seventh at middleweight (The Ring), and eighth at middleweight (Transnational Boxing Rankings Board).

Sophia Anna Bush, born on July 8, 1982, is an American actress, director, spokesperson, and activist known for her roles in the films John Tucker Must Die (2006), The Hitcher (2007), and The Narrows (2008).

Rupert Murdoch currently serves as chairman and acting CEO of Fox News. He previously held full control as chairman and CEO of News Corporation—once the world’s second-largest media conglomerate—and later its successor companies, News Corp and 21st Century Fox, following a split in 2013. His younger son, James Rupert Jacob Murdoch, an Australian-British-American businessman, is CEO of 21st Century Fox and serves as chairman of Sky plc.
In 2013, Gal Gadot was the second-highest earning actress/model in Israel—behind Bar Refaeli but ahead of Esti Ginzburg and Shlomit Malka—primarily due to her acting roles.
Creedence Clearwater Revival (often shortened to Creedence or CCR) was an American rock band that performed during the late 1960s and early 1970s.
Calcaneal spurs are commonly identified through radiographic examinations (x-rays).
The South Wales Coalfield, known in Welsh as Maes glo De Cymru, is a large coal-rich region in south Wales, particularly in the South Wales Valleys.

The CONCACAF Champions League is an annual football competition for top clubs in North America, Central America, and the Caribbean, organized by CONCACAF. Originally launched in 1962, it was known as the CONCACAF Champions’ Cup.

Mary of Teck became queen mother in 1936 after her eldest son Edward took the throne following George V's death. She was dismayed when Edward abdicated later that same year to marry Wallis Simpson. Mary then supported her second son, Albert (George VI), throughout his reign until his death in 1952. She died in 1953, during the reign of her granddaughter, Queen Elizabeth II, before Elizabeth’s coronation.
Poseidon is a film that earned US$181,674,817 worldwide against a production budget of US$160 million.
The NAACP Image Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Drama Series was first presented in 1996, and Omar Epps and Joe Morton both hold the record for the most wins, with three each.

Human trafficking involves the exploitation of humans through forced labor, sexual slavery, or commercial sexual exploitation. The International Labour Organization (ILO) reports that forced labor alone generates about $150 billion in annual profits. As of 2014, an estimated 14.2 million people (68%) were exploited for labor, 4.5 million (22%) for sexual exploitation, and 2.2 million (10%) for state-imposed forced labor.
"Rio" is a film released in 2011, and it has a sequel titled "Rio 2," which premiered on April 11, 2014.

Two different individuals named Francis I are covered:  
• Francis I (Franz Stefan/François Étienne, 1708–1765), who served nominally as Holy Roman Emperor and Grand Duke of Tuscany, though his wife held the real power.  
• Francis I (François Ier, 1494–1547), the first King of France from the Angoulême branch of Valois, known for his large nose, chivalric reputation, and significant conflicts with Charles V. When direct confrontation failed, he forged a controversial alliance with the Ottoman Sultan Suleiman the Magnificent. The passage concludes by mentioning the Italian War of 1536–1538 between Francis I and Charles V.

Peking University, also known as PKU or Beida, is a major Chinese research university in Beijing and a member of the C9 League. Founded in 1898 as the Imperial University of Peking—replacing the ancient Taixue or Guozijian—it was China’s first modern national university and initially served as the highest educational authority. Today, it remains consistently ranked as the top higher education institution in mainland China.
Lemmy was recognized for his notable appearance (featuring his friendly mutton chops), his gravelly voice, and his distinctive style of bass playing.
Global warming poses significant human impacts by threatening food security through declining crop yields and forcing the abandonment of populated areas due to rising sea levels.

“Australia” (2008) is an Australian-American-British romantic historical adventure drama film directed by Baz Luhrmann and starring Nicole Kidman and Hugh Jackman. It is described as an epic historical romantic drama.
Michael Dwayne Vick, born June 26, 1980, is a former American football quarterback who spent 13 seasons in the NFL, primarily with the Atlanta Falcons and the Philadelphia Eagles.

Canadian folklore encompasses various forms of cultural expression, including songs, legends, jokes, rhymes, proverbs, weather lore, and superstitions, as well as traditional practices such as food-making and craft-making. Folklore also incorporates oral traditions like tales, proverbs, and jokes.
The First Motion Picture Unit produced over 400 propaganda and training films that were both informative and entertaining, and it also trained combat cameramen.

James Jones the author won the 1952 National Book Award for his debut novel, “From Here to Eternity,” which was quickly adapted for film and later became a television series. Meanwhile, James Jones the basketball player averaged 25 points per game as a senior, received Class 6A Player of the Year and First Team All-State honors, and went on to win three NBA championships (two with the Heat and one with the Cavaliers). Alongside LeBron James, he reached the NBA Finals seven straight times, finished third in three-point percentage in the 2007–08 season, and won the Three-Point Contest in 2011.
In 1999, the American Film Institute ranked Humphrey Bogart as the greatest male star of Classic American cinema.

Computer animation refers to the process of creating animated images. Trollhunters is an American computer-animated fantasy television series, created by Guillermo del Toro for Netflix and produced by DreamWorks Animation and Double Dare You.
Shane McMahon announced his resignation from WWE in 2009, and it officially took effect on January 1, 2010.

Tom Baker is an English actor best known for his role as the fourth Doctor in Doctor Who from 1974 to 1981—a longer tenure than any other actor—and for narrating the comedy series Little Britain. He has also provided narration for commercials, video games, audiobooks, and various television series.
Angelsberg is a small town located in the commune of Fischbach in central Luxembourg.

The passage states that the Hanford Site is engaged in a cleanup project but also hosts a commercial nuclear power plant (the Columbia Generating Station) as well as notable research facilities including the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory and the LIGO Hanford Observatory.

The White House Press Secretary is a senior official who serves as the spokesperson for the executive branch—particularly the President, senior staff, and policies. Appointed by and serving at the pleasure of the President, this position does not require Senate confirmation but remains prominent due to its frequent media briefings and public-facing role, despite not being part of the Cabinet.

Kentucky, nicknamed the “Bluegrass State,” is recognized for the bluegrass growing in its fertile pastures. The central Bluegrass Region encompasses major cities such as Louisville and Lexington. Kentucky is notably associated with horse racing, bourbon distilleries, coal, the historic My Old Kentucky Home, automobile manufacturing, tobacco, bluegrass music, college basketball, and Kentucky Fried Chicken.
“Broken Bridges” is a 2006 film starring Toby Keith, Lindsey Haun, Burt Reynolds, and Kelly Preston. Kelly Preston also starred in “The Cat in the Hat” and “Old Dogs.”
Kesha Rose Sebert, born on March 1, 1987, and formerly stylized as Ke$ha, is an American singer, songwriter, and rapper.
On May 5, 2017, two versions of “Despacito” were released: an electronic version produced by Major Lazer and Colombian DJ MOSKA, and an urban version produced by Sky.

Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event held by the NWA (later WCW) from 1983 to 2000. Initially shown on closed-circuit television, it began airing on pay-per-view in 1987 after the WWF created Survivor Series and demanded exclusive PPV rights on Thanksgiving. Early Starrcade events (1983–1986) were later added to the WWE Network in 2014 and received a TV-MA rating due to their violent content, particularly the “I Quit” match between Tully Blanchard and Magnum T.A. Starrcade (1997) was the fifteenth installment of the series.
Veeru Devgan is identified as an Indian stunt and action choreographer as well as a film director in Bollywood.
Star Trek: Discovery is the first Star Trek series developed specifically for its streaming service and the first new Star Trek series since Star Trek: Enterprise ended in 2005.

Terry Crews played as a defensive end and linebacker in the NFL for the Los Angeles Rams, San Diego Chargers, and Washington Redskins, and also in the World League of American Football with the Rhein Fire.

“Excuse My French” refers to both the debut album by rapper French Montana and a 2014 Egyptian comedy film directed by Amr Salama. The film is based on Salama’s personal experiences at a public middle school in Egypt upon returning from Saudi Arabia. Additionally, the passage mentions Benjamin Paul Ballance-Drew (known as Plan B or Ben Drew), a British hip hop artist, actor, film director, and producer.
A floppy disk is a thin, flexible magnetic storage medium encased in a rectangular plastic enclosure lined with fabric to remove dust, also known as a floppy, diskette, or simply disk.

Guatemala experienced chronic instability and civil strife starting in the mid-19th century. From 1960 to 1996, the country endured a bloody civil war between a U.S.-supported government and leftist rebels, which included military-led genocidal massacres of the Maya population.

Forceps are handheld, hinged instruments used to grasp and hold objects. Their plural form can be “forceps” or “forcipes.” Outside of medical contexts, they are commonly referred to by names like tweezers, tongs, pliers, clips, or clamps.
“The Closer” began its seventh and final season on July 11, 2011, following a sixth season in which it was ranked as the highest-rated drama on cable.

Dr. Jack Shephard is the main character in the ABC drama series "Lost," portrayed by Matthew Fox. The show aired from September 22, 2004, to May 23, 2010, spanning six seasons and totaling 121 episodes. Its first season averaged about 16 million viewers per episode.

Matthew David McConaughey (born November 4, 1969) is an American actor who has focused on dramatic roles since 2011. He has starred in films such as The Lincoln Lawyer, Bernie, Killer Joe, The Paperboy, Mud, Magic Mike, The Wolf of Wall Street, Dallas Buyers Club, Interstellar, The Sea of Trees, and Free State of Jones. The 2012 film Mud features McConaughey alongside Tye Sheridan, Jacob Lofland, Sam Shepard, and Reese Witherspoon.

Robert Palmer was a writer known for his book "Deep Blues," his music journalism at the New York Times and Rolling Stone, his production of blues recordings and the "Deep Blues" film soundtrack, and his clarinet work with the 1960s band The Insect Trust.

James Lincoln de la Mothe Borglum (1912–1986) was a sculptor, photographer, author, and engineer who assumed leadership of the Mount Rushmore National Memorial project upon the death of its original creator—his father, Gutzon Borglum—in 1941. Gutzon Borglum had designed the sculpture and directed its construction from 1927 until his passing in March 1941, after which Lincoln completed the work.

"Underdog" is a film directed by Frederik Du Chau and written by Joe Piscatella, Adam Rifkin, and Craig A. Williams. It features on-screen performances by Jim Belushi, Peter Dinklage, John Slattery, and Patrick Warburton, alongside voice talents from Jason Lee, Amy Adams, and Brad Garrett.

“The 100” follows a group of teens—Clarke Griffin, Bellamy Blake, Octavia Blake, Jasper Jordan, Monty Green, Raven Reyes, Finn Collins, John Murphy, and Wells Jaha—who are among the first people from a space habitat called “The Ark” to return to Earth after a devastating nuclear apocalypse. The series also centers on Dr. Abby Griffin (Clarke’s mother), Marcus Kane (an Ark council member), and Thelonious Jaha (the Ark’s Chancellor and Wells’s father).

The Concert for Bangladesh was a pioneering and influential humanitarian aid project, despite facing financial difficulties. It raised significant awareness and funds, and provided lessons that inspired future large-scale benefit events, notably Live Aid.
Mani Ratnam is an influential Indian filmmaker, credited by the media with revolutionizing the Tamil film industry and altering the profile of Indian cinema.

Stephen A. Douglas introduced the Freeport Doctrine during the second of the seven Lincoln-Douglas debates on August 27, 1858, in Freeport, Illinois. These debates, also called the Great Debates of 1858, were between Douglas, the Democratic incumbent, and Abraham Lincoln, the Republican contender for the U.S. Senate from Illinois. The debates in Freeport, Quincy, and Alton attracted large crowds, reflecting the widespread national concern over the issue of slavery.

"Easy A" (stylized as easy A) is a 2010 American teen comedy film directed by Will Gluck, written by Bert V. Royal, and featuring a cast led by Emma Stone, Stanley Tucci, Patricia Clarkson, Thomas Haden Church, Dan Byrd, Amanda Bynes, Penn Badgley, Cam Gigandet, Lisa Kudrow, and Aly Michalka.

Anne Rice, born Howard Allen Frances O'Brien on October 4, 1941, is an American author known for writing gothic fiction, Christian literature, and erotica. She began her career with the 1976 publication of “Interview with the Vampire” and started writing its sequels in the 1980s. Though her early reception was mixed, her popularity grew in the 1980s. She was married to poet and painter Stan Rice from 1961 until his death from brain cancer in 2002.

Camden is a city in Camden County, New Jersey, with a 2010 population of 77,344, making it the 12th most populous municipality in the state. At the start of the 20th century, its residents were primarily European immigrants. The passage also notes that a city is a large, permanent human settlement.
Bret Easton Ellis wrote the screenplay for the 2013 film "The Canyons," an original erotic thriller-drama directed by Paul Schrader. The film was critically derided.

The Lincoln–Douglas Debates, also called The Great Debates of 1858, were a series of seven debates between Republican Abraham Lincoln and incumbent Democratic Senator Stephen Douglas during the 1858 U.S. Senate race in Illinois. They took place in seven different towns across the state.

Homer is traditionally regarded by the ancient Greeks as the author of the Iliad and the Odyssey, key texts of Greek literature. Separately, The Thicket is a mystery/suspense novel by the American writer Joe R. Lansdale.
Christopher Scott Kyle was a United States Navy SEAL veteran and sniper, born on April 8, 1974. He was murdered by Eddie Ray Routh on February 2, 2013, at a shooting range near Chalk Mountain, Texas.

Audioslave was a four-piece rock band formed by singer/guitarist Chris Cornell (Soundgarden) and three members of Rage Against the Machine (RATM): guitarist Tom Morello, bassist Tim Commerford, and drummer Brad Wilk. Wilk, who began his career with Greta in 1990, co-founded RATM—consisting of Zack de la Rocha, Tim Commerford, Tom Morello, and Brad Wilk—in 1991. He performed with RATM (1991–2000, 2007–2011) and Audioslave (2001–2007), and as of 2016, he joined Prophets of Rage with Commerford, Morello, Chuck D, B-Real, and DJ Lord.

Janelle Monáe Robinson, born on December 1, 1985, is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and model. She is signed to her own imprint, Wondaland Arts Society, as well as Atlantic Records. In 2010, she released her debut full-length studio album, “The ArchAndroid,” a critically acclaimed concept album and sequel to her first EP, through Bad Boy Records.
“Winter’s Tale” is identified as a 1983 novel written by Mark Helprin.

Lake Providence is a town in northeastern Louisiana and serves as the parish seat of East Carroll Parish. The University of Mississippi has a student body with about 55% of undergraduates and 60% overall from Mississippi, 23% minority representation, and international students from 90 countries.
“Flaked,” a television series, was renewed for a six-episode second season in July 2016, with its premiere scheduled for June 2, 2017.

Aaron Burr served two terms in the New York State Assembly (1784–1785, 1798–1799), was New York State Attorney General (1789–1791), represented New York as a U.S. Senator (1791–1797), and ultimately became vice president.

The Soyuz rocket was developed to launch Soyuz spacecraft under the Soviet human spaceflight program, beginning with eight unmanned test flights and later conducting the first nineteen crewed missions. The Soyuz spacecraft themselves, designed by the Korolyov Design Bureau (now RKK Energia) in the 1960s, succeeded the Voskhod spacecraft and were originally built for Soviet lunar programs; they remain in service today.
Steve Ditko studied under Batman artist Jerry Robinson at the Cartoonist and Illustrators School in New York City.

Rage Against the Machine experienced growing tensions, causing frontman Zack de la Rocha to leave and leading to the band’s breakup. De la Rocha pursued a solo career, while the remaining members formed the rock supergroup Audioslave with Chris Cornell, releasing three albums before ending in 2007. That same year, Rage Against the Machine reunited and performed at the Coachella Festival. Their fourth studio album, “Renegades,” was released on December 5, 2000, by Epic Records.

The passage explains that the S&P BSE SENSEX, also known as the BSE 30, is a free-float market-weighted index of 30 major companies listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange. It also notes that Tata Motors is listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange (as part of the SENSEX index), the National Stock Exchange of India, and the New York Stock Exchange.

Vietnam, officially the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, is the easternmost nation on the Indochina Peninsula in Southeast Asia. With around 92.7 million residents, it ranks 14th in population globally and ninth in Asia. It is bordered by China, Laos, Cambodia, and Thailand (across the Gulf of Thailand), as well as the Philippines, Malaysia, and Indonesia across the South China Sea. Since 2000, Vietnam’s economy has been among the fastest-growing worldwide, holding the top Global Growth Generators Index score among 11 major economies in 2011. It remains one of four one-party socialist states that officially espouse communism.
“Dreamer” is a 2005 American sports drama film that was both written and directed by John Gatins, marking his directorial debut.

Bhagat Singh was a young Indian socialist revolutionary known for two dramatic acts of violence against the British. He was executed at age 23 on 23 March 1931, and his death made him a widely revered folk hero of the Indian independence movement.
Aparshakti Khurana made his first appearance in Bollywood with the 2016 film “Dangal.” Directed by Nitesh Tiwari, “Dangal” is a Hindi-language biographical sports drama featuring Aamir Khan.

James VI and I (James Stuart) reigned as King of Scotland from 1567 and, following the union of the Scottish and English crowns in 1603, also served as King of England and Ireland until his death in 1625. Although Scotland and England remained separate sovereign states with their own institutions, James personally ruled both and sought to create a single parliament for them. During his reign in England, he faced significant difficulties with Parliament.

Danielle Cormack (born 26 December 1970) is a New Zealand stage and screen actress. She was part of the original core cast of Shortland Street and is also known for her roles as the Amazon Ephiny in Xena: Warrior Princess, Cynthia Ross in The Cult, and Shota in Legend of the Seeker. Other notable work includes the film Separation City, the Australian series Rake, and portraying Kate Leigh in Underbelly: Razor. Her most acclaimed recent role was playing Bea Smith in Wentworth for four years, ending in 2016.
Rob Sheridan, born on October 11, 1979, is an American graphic designer, director, and photographer, recognized primarily for his extensive work with the band Nine Inch Nails.

David Spade starred in several films, including Tommy Boy, Black Sheep, Joe Dirt, Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser, Grown Ups, and Grown Ups 2. Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser is a 2015 American comedy directed by Fred Wolf and written by David Spade and Fred Wolf.
Angela Evelyn Bassett is an American actress, born on August 16, 1958.

Artpop received mixed reviews from critics but was commercially successful, debuting at number one on the Billboard 200 with first-week sales of 258,000 copies, becoming Lady Gaga’s second consecutive number-one album in the United States. It sold 757,000 copies there and was the ninth best-selling album globally in 2013, with 2.3 million copies sold worldwide.
John Frusciante’s fifth and final album with the Chili Peppers, titled "Stadium Arcadium," was released in 2006 and marked his last appearance with the group before confirming his departure in 2009.

Margaret Thatcher served as Prime Minister and introduced policies known as Thatcherism. She remains a controversial figure, widely regarded as a highly influential British politician, though debates over her policies continue.

Michael Andrew “Duff” McKagan, born February 5, 1964, is an American musician, singer, songwriter, and author. Beyond his music career, he has established himself as a writer, contributing weekly columns on various topics to SeattleWeekly.com, Playboy.com, and ESPN.com.
Tom Baker is an English actor known not only for his acting roles but also for narrating commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.

Valencia is the capital of the Valencian Community (also known as the Valencian Country), an autonomous community in Spain. It is the third-largest city in the country—after Madrid and Barcelona—with approximately 800,000 people in its administrative center. The broader metropolitan area hosts between 1.7 and 2.5 million inhabitants, making it Spain’s third-largest metropolitan region.
Buffy Summers is a character who was portrayed by Kristy Swanson in the film adaptation and later by Sarah Michelle Gellar in the television series.
"Make It or Break It" ended after its third and final season, an announcement made on April 26, 2012, with the series finale airing on May 14, 2012.

Speech recognition is an interdisciplinary area of computational linguistics that transforms spoken language into text using methods and technologies from linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering. Its applications include voice user interfaces (e.g., voice dialing), call routing, appliance control, searching spoken content, data entry, generating structured documents, speech-to-text processing, and aircraft control. Recent advances in speech recognition stem largely from deep learning techniques, which have been widely adopted by leading companies such as Google, Microsoft, IBM, Baidu, Apple, Amazon, Nuance, SoundHound, IflyTek, and CDAC.

Richard Alf (1952–2012) was an American businessman and comic book store owner who co-founded what is now known as San Diego Comic-Con International in 1970. He served as its chairman starting that same year. The event was originally called the Golden State Comic Book Convention and later became the San Diego Comic Book Convention. Its founders included Shel Dorf, Richard Alf, Ken Krueger, and Mike Towry.
"Fist of Legend" is a remake of the 1972 film "Fist of Fury," originally starring Bruce Lee as the lead character.

Victor Dubuisson and overnight leader Jaco Van Zyl both sit at 16 under par, while Rory McIlroy climbed to 15 under par with Kiradech Aphibarnrat after shooting his third consecutive 67. McIlroy, seeking his first victory since May, mixed birdies and an eagle with two dropped shots, even throwing his putter at his bag after a three-putt. The Northern Irishman returned in late summer following an ankle ligament injury in July and is now aiming for his third Race to Dubai title in four years. Three events remain after the Turkish Open, and McIlroy leads England’s Danny Willett by 271,214 points. Chris Wood and Richard Bland, both from England, are also in contention at 13 under and 12 under, respectively.

Sheikh Ali Salman, leader of Bahrain’s largest opposition party al-Wefaq, argues that a genuine national dialogue requires the government to offer concrete solutions and to involve someone with authority to represent the royal family. He sees Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa, viewed as a reformist, as a potential partner, but notes that hardliners—led by Prime Minister Sheikh Khalifa bin Salman al-Khalifa—resist concessions that might spur further opposition demands.

Despite skepticism among younger protesters, Sheikh Salman remains committed to peaceful negotiations and demonstrations, emphasizing collaboration with reform-minded royals. He recounts that just before Gulf Co-operation Council forces intervened in March 2011, the opposition and Crown Prince had agreed on a seven-point plan for constitutional reform.

Sheikh Salman hopes the new US Secretary of State John Kerry will more forcefully promote human rights and democracy, and he criticizes the UK for limiting its pressure to private conversations. He also calls for the release of 13 opposition leaders and activists, insisting that meaningful dialogue cannot occur while they remain imprisoned.

Christopher Hogwood, a leading figure in the early-music movement, died at his Cambridge home after several months of illness. Founder of the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973, he directed it for three decades, recorded more than 200 CDs, and produced the first complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. A pivotal recording was the 1980 Handel’s Messiah with Emma Kirkby and Carolyn Watkinson, recognized by BBC Music Magazine as one of the top 20 of all time. Hogwood studied keyboard at Cambridge and held roles as a musicologist and performer with major ensembles, including the Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields. He was also a founder member of the Early Music Consort of London, served as artistic director of the King’s Lynn Festival and the Handel and Haydn Society, and taught at prestigious institutions such as Harvard and Cambridge. Tributes from colleagues and artists praised his intellectual depth, generosity of spirit, and significant influence on historically informed performance. His funeral will be private, with a memorial service to follow later.

Homicides in Scotland fell to 57 cases in the year ending March 2016—the lowest figure since 1976, and half the total from nine years prior. Nearly all sharp-instrument killings involved knives, which remained the most common method overall. Of the individuals accused, nearly a third were identified as under the influence of alcohol or alcohol plus drugs. Justice Secretary Michael Matheson noted this sustained decline reflects educational and enforcement efforts but emphasized continued vigilance. Labour’s Claire Baker welcomed the trend but advised caution, mentioning past data revisions and expressing concern over rising sexual and other violent crimes. The 2014–15 homicide figure was revised upward from 59 to 62 after reclassification of three cases.

Bournemouth lost 2-1 to Sunderland—Sunderland’s first Premier League win of the season—despite Dan Gosling opening the scoring, marking Bournemouth’s first goal in three matches. Manager Eddie Howe expressed frustration at squandering multiple chances, especially after having recently scored six goals against Hull. Victor Anichebe and a Jermain Defoe penalty secured Sunderland’s victory, even while down to ten men following Steven Pienaar’s red card. Howe stressed the importance of moving on from the disappointing result.

Tony Abbott defends Australia’s policy of detaining and processing boat arrivals offshore, insisting that “stopping the boats” is the only way to prevent migrant deaths at sea. The New York Times criticizes this approach as “brutal” and “inhumane,” while Abbott disagrees and suggests Europe consider similar measures. Confronted by the tragic drowning of Syrian child Alan Kurdi, Abbott reiterates that halting boat arrivals stops deaths. He further provokes controversy by asserting that the so-called Islamic State is worse than the Nazis because it publicly boasts of its atrocities, unlike the Nazis who hid theirs. Australian Jewish groups condemn this comparison, saying it trivializes the systematic genocide perpetrated by the Nazis, but Abbott stands by his remarks, clarifying he does not seek to “rank evil.”

The passage describes how the United States has suspended bilateral talks with Russia over the ongoing conflict in Syria, accusing Moscow and the Syrian government of escalating attacks — including bombings in Aleppo and strikes on hospitals and aid convoys. Russia denies direct involvement in the attacks and blames the US for failing to uphold its commitments, such as separating jihadist groups from moderate opposition. With the ceasefire broken, hundreds have been killed and some 250,000 people are trapped in eastern Aleppo. While suspending talks, the US will continue limited coordination with Russia to avoid military clashes, but personnel involved in potential joint operations have been withdrawn.

Downing Street is backing a Policy Exchange report recommending councils sell off high-value social housing that becomes vacant and use the proceeds to fund new social homes, potentially building 80,000 to 170,000 each year. The think tank’s director argues that selling expensive properties—which it says comprise about 21.8% of social housing stock—would raise around £4.5bn annually after debt, lowering the waiting list by as many as 500,000 people. Critics, including Labour, counter that the proposal would push low-income families out of wealthier areas, breaking up mixed communities. The government maintains councils already have the power to sell high-value homes and should use their stock efficiently, while Labour proposes alternative building programs, such as using a bank bonus tax to fund the construction of new affordable homes.

Gareth Colfer-Williams, age 25, died in Swansea, the center of a measles outbreak that has reached 942 cases since November, requiring hospital treatment for 83 people. Although he tested positive for measles, the exact cause of his death remains unclear and further tests are pending. Shortly before his death, he had been treated for asthma at Morriston Hospital and later developed a widespread rash. He died the morning after visiting an out-of-hours GP. His family, who are unsure how he contracted measles, note that his three-year-old daughter is vaccinated. An inquest into his death has been opened and adjourned for additional investigation.

Vincent Hudson, 54, of Loweswater Avenue in Whitehaven, has been charged with a historic offence against a boy under 16, reported to have occurred in 2001. He is scheduled to appear before North Cumbria Magistrates’ Court.

Gateshead and Guiseley, both on unbeaten runs, drew 1–1 in their National League match. Guiseley took the lead on 15 minutes when James Hurst’s pass set up Jake Lawlor for a simple finish. Gateshead went close just before the break, but Guiseley’s Jonny Maxted saved well. In the second half, a slip by substitute Derek Asamoah allowed Wes York to curl home the equalizer in the 62nd minute, securing a point for the hosts.

Bristol Sport Ltd, owner of the football club, plans to replace two stands to increase capacity, rather than build a new stadium at Ashton Vale (which has been delayed by a town green application). Bristol City Council approved the work in November. Majority shareholder Steve Lansdown announced at a shareholder meeting that the Section 106 agreement will be signed soon, followed by a six-week judicial review period. If there is no legal challenge by March, redevelopment will begin in May.

Cuadrilla suspended its shale gas “fracking” operations in Lancashire following a second small earthquake in two months. Both quakes (the latest at 1.5 magnitude, and a prior 2.3 magnitude event in April) occurred near Poulton-le-Fylde at a depth of about 2 km. The British Geological Survey (BGS) is examining data to determine any link between the activity and the tremors. Fracking involves injecting pressurized water—sometimes with small explosions—into rock to release gas, and has raised environmental concerns in the United States. However, a Commons energy select committee in the UK supports fracking under strict regulations and best industry practices. Cuadrilla’s chief executive emphasized the company’s commitment to working with authorities, and the BGS continues to monitor seismic activity around the Preese Hall site.

Angus Carpenter, a 62-year-old Liverpool piper, was found guilty of one fraud charge after playing with a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner draped on his bagpipes in April 2015, though he was cleared of two other fraud counts. He claimed he had permission to display the banner and was only busking, not collecting money for the charity. The Hillsborough Justice Campaign chairman confirmed Carpenter had been allowed to use the banner but told him not to fundraise with it. Sentencing will take place in January.

Ipswich Town beat Queens Park Rangers 3-0, with Grant Ward’s initial scuffed shot and a second goal resulting from Alex Smithies’ miscued clearance that allowed Luke Varney to tap into an empty net. Tom Lawrence sealed the victory with a composed finish. QPR created few chances, although Sandro headed against the post late on. Ipswich, who had struggled for goals recently, could have scored more, but Smithies made several saves. The win lifted Ipswich to 14th in the table, above QPR in 15th. Manager Mick McCarthy praised Varney’s contribution and expressed relief at improving Ipswich’s fortunes, while QPR boss Ian Holloway lamented his team’s response after the calamitous second goal and called for greater mental toughness.

Wells, 23, delivered a strong T20 Blast performance with 373 runs at an average of 28.69 and a 138.66 strike rate. He expressed enthusiasm for the club’s progress and praised the coaches for fostering a high-performance environment that motivates players to be involved.

The Reds, currently fifth in National Two South, claimed their second consecutive win by defeating third-placed Chinnor 29–12. Head coach Churcher highlighted the dominant defensive effort of the front row—particularly Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey, and Craig Williams—who contributed over 70 tackles. With seven of their next eight opponents sitting below them in the table (and one match against leaders Old Elthamians), Churcher insists there is still room to improve and stresses the importance of building on their recent performance.

Police have arrested 28-year-old Nazrul (also known as Nazu) at a Kolkata railway station for allegedly raping a 74-year-old nun. A Bangladeshi national, he fled to Bangladesh after being identified from CCTV footage. This marks the sixth arrest in a case with eight identified suspects, two still at large. All five previously arrested suspects named Nazrul as the rapist. The incident, which occurred on 14 March in Ranaghat town, involved a robbery and the ransacking of a convent school before the nun’s assault. Another suspect, described as the gang’s leader, was arrested in May, though his exact role was unclear. The crime sparked outrage and widespread protests across India.

The passage describes an interactive video featuring Robert Opie, founder of the Museum of Brands in London, discussing factors that influence what consumers buy—such as the arrival of domestic freezers, washing powders, and cheaper imports. The video also looks at changing ownership and rankings of major UK brands. Viewers are advised the interactive format may not work on older browsers and a non-interactive version is available. Additional resources include information on what China owns, tips on freezing food, a survey of top UK consumer brands, and the Museum of Brands.

Two separate phone scams occurred in Sandyhills and Stranraer, both involving callers claiming to be from BT and offering to fix internet issues. In each case, the scammers gained remote access to the victims’ computers and stole money. The first incident happened on 15 September and involved a 71-year-old woman, while the second occurred a week later. Police warn the public never to give out banking details over the phone and remind people that legitimate businesses do not request such information.

Duffy, aged 37, has left Swinton Lions to become head coach of third-placed Championship side Featherstone on a one-year deal. The Scotland assistant coach will lead Featherstone into their final league game against Toulouse before the Super 8 Qualifiers. Chairman Mark Campbell praised Duffy’s work under difficult circumstances at Swinton, where he was replaced by his former assistant Stuart Littler. Duffy’s 16-year playing career included stints at Leigh, Widnes, and Salford.

A Porthcawl RNLI crew, accompanied by a medic and supported by the coastguard search and rescue helicopter, went to Sker Beach near Kenfig Nature Reserve at 12:50 GMT on Sunday. They found a rider who had sustained head injuries and was lying unconscious on wet sand, suffering from exposure to cold. After receiving treatment on the beach, she was flown to the University Hospital of Wales in Cardiff.

Representatives from over 160 countries agreed at a UN conference in Geneva to allocate a dedicated radio frequency so satellites can receive ADS-B signals from aircraft, enabling real-time global flight tracking. This move follows the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 in 2014, which exposed gaps in current radar-based systems covering only 30% of worldwide airspace. The International Telecommunication Union (ITU) and the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) are working on implementing updated guidelines requiring aircraft to transmit location data at least every 15 minutes, or more frequently in emergencies, by November 2016.

Julian Hernandez went missing at age five and was recently discovered at 18, living with his father Bobby Hernandez in Cleveland. Bobby, now 53, was arrested after a tip to the FBI linked Julian to a missing persons case when the teenager encountered issues applying to college. Investigators confirmed Julian’s identity with help from Alabama police and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children. His mother has been notified, and Bobby faces additional charges for tampering with records in Ohio to obtain a driver’s license. He is being held in the Cuyahoga County Jail on $250,000 bail, and authorities had suspected from the outset that he was responsible for Julian’s disappearance.

A fire occurred on 2 March at Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited’s Duncan Street site, causing train service disruptions and travel delays. The Environment Agency (EA) responded by suspending the firm from accepting waste and ultimately revoked its environmental permit, effective 7 August pending appeal. Despite the fire service visiting the site nine times in the past year and finding it “broadly compliant” with fire safety rules, concerns about potential risks to residents, transport, and the environment led to enforcement action. The company is still required to remove all waste, and the fire’s cause remains undetermined.

Pro-Kremlin party A Just Russia has introduced two bills in response to the crisis in Ukraine’s Crimea region. The first would allow Russia to absorb a territory if its leaders request it or if a referendum supports joining Russia, bypassing the need for a formal treaty. This stems from concern that Ukraine is “disintegrating,” echoing moves Russia took after its 2008 conflict with Georgia. The second bill simplifies passport procedures for Ukrainians: they could apply through Russian diplomatic missions, avoid residency and financial requirements, retain their Ukrainian citizenship, and be fast-tracked to Russian citizenship within two months. These changes are justified in the bill as defense against a so-called “brown threat”—a reference to fascist forces from World War Two. Members of the Russian parliament, including high-profile figures such as an ex-cosmonaut and a former Olympic champion, have traveled to Crimea in support of these measures.

McLaren, once a dominant force in Formula 1—with 182 grand prix wins, multiple drivers’ and constructors’ championships, and legendary partnerships with Honda and Mercedes—has entered a steep decline that began around 2013. The team’s recent struggles revolve around a chassis-engine mismatch: they regained strength in car design, but Honda’s underperforming power unit has held them back. Their downturn follows earlier controversies, including exclusion from the 2007 constructors’ championship (despite scoring the most points) and the “lie-gate” scandal of 2009. 

Historically, McLaren has gone through cycles of success and failure, rising to prominence in the 1970s, dominating the 1980s and early 1990s with drivers like Ayrton Senna and Alain Prost, and later achieving more triumphs with Mika Häkkinen in 1998–99. Ron Dennis, who led the team’s previous comebacks, has returned to restore its fortunes, supported by Fernando Alonso, who rejoined in hopes of winning another title. Dennis remains confident that McLaren will soon break Mercedes’ grip on F1 and return to championship form, though for now, belief is all they have to offer.

Thomas Baker (Tommy), 44, from Everton, was shot in the head and chest at Stanley Meat Market in Old Swan, Liverpool, on 27 January after leaving Phoenix Gym. He later died in hospital. Three local men (two aged 29 and one aged 32) have been arrested and remain in custody. Detectives believe the shooters waited outside the gym for about an hour, and they are seeking a silver VW Polo spotted speeding away along Balmoral Road, Molyneux Road, and Queens Road. Police also want to trace potential witnesses seen on CCTV near the meat market who have not yet come forward.

The passage focuses on various modern, online approaches to celebrating and sharing the Christmas message. Everyday Church Online hosts virtual services worldwide, using chat functions and a Star Wars-inspired sermon to draw analogies to hope. Guardians of Ancora is a free fantasy game for children that reclaims “light” by exploring Bible stories, including two new Christmas-themed quests. Viral videos such as The Digital Story of Nativity and “Christmas Starts with a Baby’s Giggle” adapt the nativity for social media and contemporary storytelling, though advertising restrictions have at times limited cinema showings. Manga Messiah and other apps from Next Manga retell Bible passages in a popular Japanese comic style, even distributing copies to refugees. Finally, many churches and Christian groups use social platforms (Facebook, Twitter, Instagram) to prompt spiritual reflection, illustrating a trend to keep faith accessible and engaging in a digital era.

An eight-day inquiry in Ebbw Vale is examining the proposal to use 250 hectares of common land for a racing circuit, with 320 hectares of replacement land offered by developers and Blaenau Gwent council. Experts disagree on the habitat impact: Natural Resources Wales questions whether the replacement land is of equal value but does not oppose the development, while an ecology report says a “net gain” in biodiversity would result from nearby habitat enhancements, which the Gwent Wildlife Trust disputes. The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will issue a recommendation, after which Welsh government ministers will decide whether to approve the plans.

Chechen Muslim clerics denounced Novaya Gazeta’s report of over 100 men detained and at least three killed in Chechnya for being or appearing to be gay, calling the newspaper’s revelations an insult and threatening retribution. The Russian LGBT Network, corroborating the story with victims who suffered torture near Argun, is helping people flee and warns it may take the case to the International Criminal Court if Russian authorities fail to act. Despite Chechen leaders’ denial of the accusations—stating there are no gay people in Chechnya—Novaya Gazeta insists on pursuing its investigations, recalling previous reporter murders linked to Chechnya. The paper urges dialogue while rejecting claims it intended to offend Chechens.

Investing Solutions and Fresh Start Housing operate alongside each other to house single homeless men aged 35 and over, with referrals coming from London homeless charities. Samir Patel set up both the letting agency (in 2002) and the charity (in 2010). Fresh Start finds tenants and sometimes refers them to Investing Solutions, which rents properties from private landlords. 

Because housing benefit rules allow higher claims for tenants aged over 35 in private accommodation, Investing Solutions can charge more in total than it pays out to landlords, making significant profits. For example, the company charged £2,114 per month for two tenants in one property but paid the owner only £1,150 per month, retaining £11,568 in annual gross profit on that house.

Some occupants, such as Nigel McCann, report poor housing conditions—lack of heating, hot water, and a rat infestation—while local councils, including Wandsworth Council, which alone has paid over £2.1m to Investing Solutions, maintain they have teams to ensure safe and affordable housing. Homeless charity Crisis calls the link between a charity and alleged poor practice “a new low.” Samir Patel and Fresh Start maintain that most rent goes to landlords and emphasize the charity’s independence.

Great Britain led most of the way in their final warm-up match against the Netherlands before being overtaken in the fourth quarter, ultimately losing despite Andrew Lawrence’s 14 points and Ben Gordon’s 13. Coach Joe Prunty emphasized the need for full effort on both ends of the court as GB prepares to begin their Eurobasket qualifying campaign in Hungary. Gordon, who missed London 2012 but has now joined the squad, impressed during a strong third-quarter stretch, while the Dutch, led by Worthy De Jong's 18 points, clinched victory with a decisive start to the final period.

Floyd Mayweather and Conor McGregor both want to use 8oz gloves for their 154lb fight, but Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) rules typically require 10oz for that weight category. Both fighters have submitted waivers, and the NAC will decide on 16 August whether lighter gloves will be permitted, prioritizing health and safety. Mayweather, who has not knocked out anyone since 2007, officially came out of retirement for this bout. McGregor, a UFC champion more accustomed to 4oz gloves, is making his boxing debut amid skepticism from major boxing figures. NAC executive director Bob Bennett says the decision to sanction this fight was influenced by McGregor’s notable knockdowns of UFC rival Nate Diaz and his physical advantages over Mayweather—being younger, taller, and with a reputed “granite-like chin.” McGregor’s camp has also enlisted referee Joe Cortez to help him adapt to boxing rules.

Fleet Street, once the beating heart of British journalism, is losing its final two journalists—Darryl Smith and Gavin Sherriff from the Sunday Post—marking the end of an era. Once home to nearly every national paper, plus provincial titles, Fleet Street’s heyday involved typewriters, smoke-filled newsrooms, and pubs where stories were swapped over drinks. Changing technology and the rise of television and social media gradually eroded its influence: Rupert Murdoch relocated his titles to Wapping in 1986, sparking a prolonged industrial dispute, and by 1988 most national papers had followed suit. Today, famous newspaper buildings house supermarkets and restaurants. Smith and Sherriff’s departure conveys both nostalgia for Fleet Street’s storied past and acceptance that its chapter in journalism history has closed.

J.K. Rowling faced abusive messages after revealing she had donated £1 million to the “No” campaign in the Scottish independence referendum, as well as a similar sum to the Labour party in 2008. She was called a “traitor” by some Twitter users, many of whom she believed to be SNP supporters, although she also noted positive exchanges with others from the SNP. Rowling defended standing up to online bullying and joked about “bringing marshmallows” when someone suggested burning her books. The SNP ultimately won 56 of Scotland’s 59 seats in that election.

The University of Edinburgh’s long-term study found that poverty significantly increases both young people’s likelihood of encountering the juvenile justice system and of becoming involved in violence.
