Children from deprived backgrounds were twice as likely to face police action and up to five times more likely to be placed on statutory supervision than their better-off peers. Prior police involvement was the strongest predictor of a young person becoming not in education, employment, or training by age 18. Poverty also heightened risks for girls’ involvement in violent crime, though boys overall were three times more likely to commit violent acts.

A separate report revealed that once deprived communities continue to bear the brunt of crime, despite overall crime in Scotland being at a decades-long low. Areas with the highest rates of crime frequently overlapped with chronic health issues and unemployment. Researchers argue these findings reflect persistent inequality not fully addressed by current government measures. In response, the Scottish government highlights its investment to reduce poverty and points to dropping crime and homicide rates, as well as increased police numbers.

Mr Haugh, aged 25, was fatally stabbed in the early hours of Sunday in the Marian estate. Robbie Walsh, from Island View, Kilrush, has been charged with assault causing serious harm and remanded in custody until 14 August. Two other men initially arrested were released without charge, with files being prepared for the Director of Public Prosecutions. According to Detective Sergeant Frawley, Mr Walsh and two others entered the estate after 01:00 on Sunday looking for Mr Haugh. A fight ensued involving multiple people using weapons, during which Mr Haugh was stabbed in the back. He was pronounced dead at Limerick University Hospital later that morning. Police recovered knives, including a blade with blood on it, and golf clubs at the scene. The judge noted tension in the Kilkee area following the incident.

Phil Flanagan, a Sinn Féin MLA, tweeted an accusation in May 2014 implying that Tom Elliott, a former UDR member and the current MP for Fermanagh and South Tyrone, had harassed and shot people. Elliott, who served in the UDR from 1982 to 1992 and has a clear MoD record, was alerted to the tweet by Ann Travers and Arlene Foster. The tweet was deleted within an hour, and Flanagan must now publicly apologize on Twitter, admitting his claim was entirely untrue. The High Court has yet to determine compensation, and Flanagan’s insurer at Stormont has declined to cover him, prompting a separate legal challenge. Elliott expressed disappointment at how long the matter took, but felt “totally vindicated” by the outcome.

Hawick Knitwear, employing over 230 staff, has markedly increased its weekly sweater production from 7,500 to 9,500 to meet rising demand. This surge in orders follows better-than-expected sales of a new Hawick Knitwear-branded range launched in January, alongside continued growth in its private label business. Established in 1874 and acquired by managing director Benny Hartop last November, the firm sells across a broad European market as well as in the USA, Canada, Mexico, and Japan. Hartop credits dedicated staff for the company’s success and remains optimistic about future growth.

In December, 72-year-old lollipop lady and mother-of-three, Sylvia Blackburn, suffered serious head injuries outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston when she was struck by a car driven by 55-year-old Brian Wright. Wright told Luton Crown Court he was blinded by the setting sun and could not recall if the traffic lights were red or green. Prosecutors say he failed to stop despite the red light. Mrs. Blackburn, who had been escorting a woman and her child across the road, is now in residential care. Wright expressed remorse, saying he had turned Blackburn’s “world upside down,” but denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving. The trial is ongoing.

Nato’s “Dynamic Mongoose” exercise seeks to counter the growing threat posed by increasingly active and technologically advanced Russian submarines. In the drill, a German U-boat (U33) plays the role of an unseen adversary, testing the detection capabilities of ten Nato warships and anti-submarine warfare aircraft. Russia’s modern fleet of around 60 submarines, described as some of the “quietest and most challenging” in the world, has heightened concern as many European nations―including the UK―have reduced their defense budgets. A key vulnerability for Britain is its lack of maritime patrol aircraft, which forces it to rely on allies for surveillance. The use of underwater drones in the exercise demonstrates future possibilities, but for now, long-range patrol planes remain critical in securing Nato waters. The activity underscores the importance of bolstering anti-submarine warfare measures, especially given Russia’s growing naval capabilities.

Violence in South Sudan has escalated since July, prompting UN officials to warn of potential genocide or ethnic cleansing. Over 340,000 people have fled to Uganda this year—more than from any other country—joining the nearly one million South Sudanese already sheltered there. Refugees recount killings, sexual violence, and ethnic targeting, particularly toward Equatorians, as well as longstanding conflict between the Dinka (President Salva Kiir’s tribe) and Nuer (linked to ex–Vice President Riek Machar). Uganda, with assistance from aid agencies, provides land for farming and quick resettlement, but the continuous influx strains resources—particularly water—on a massive scale. Children compose roughly half of the refugee population, many carrying deep trauma. The UNHCR calls for international pressure on South Sudanese leaders to halt the violence, describing it as “a massacre of civilians from both sides.”

McKenzie, 38, is set to face Jahmaine Smyle at York Hall on 12 November for the English super-middleweight title. Formerly at Norwich and Peterborough, he turned professional in 2013 after quitting football in 2011 and has a record of eight wins and one draw. He is the son of former British and European champion Clinton McKenzie and is trained by his uncle, three-time world champion Duke McKenzie.

The passage describes plans for a new Bridgwater Community Hospital, funded partly by the coalition government’s £330m for new NHS facilities across England. The project total is £33m, with NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust covering the remaining costs. The new hospital—targeted for completion by autumn 2014 on Bowers Lane—will feature 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, X-ray facilities, and space for mobile scanners. Matron Sue Taylor explains that the current hospital, built in 1813, is outdated, often uncomfortable, and no longer meets modern healthcare needs. Dr Donal Hynes adds that the development will improve patient care. This new build follows a wider trend in Somerset, where three of the county’s 13 community hospitals have been replaced in the past five years, and construction is also underway on the Jubilee Building at Musgrove Park Hospital in Taunton.

A man was fatally shot outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace, Upperthorpe, near the city center. Witnesses say he was in or near a black Mercedes when the attack happened around 13:35 GMT. Armed police sealed off the scene, and the victim later died in Northern General Hospital. Neighbors report he was part of a local family gathering. The incident follows recent shootings elsewhere in Sheffield, including one in Shiregreen that left a 25-year-old man seriously injured, gunfire in Southey Green possibly involving mistaken identity, and two separate house shootings in High Green.

Ukrainian Cyber Troops, Cyber Berkut, and Anonymous International are prominent hacktivist groups operating amid the Ukraine conflict. Led by Yevhen Dokukin, the Ukrainian Cyber Troops use distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks, hack into CCTV systems for intelligence, disrupt separatist funding, and allegedly share data with Ukraine’s security services. In turn, Cyber Berkut is staunchly anti-Western, aligning with Russian media narratives; it hacks Ukrainian government websites, claims to release sensitive documents (such as from Joe Biden’s entourage), and posts anti-Kiev messages on electronic billboards. Anonymous International, known as b0ltai or Shaltay Boltay, targets the Russian government by leaking internal documents, sometimes related to Ukraine. The extent of government backing for these groups is unclear, but their actions include data theft, website defacements, and weaponized publicity stunts.

Presiding Officer Tricia Marwick became emotional as two long-serving MSPs—Duncan McNeil and Alex Salmond—delivered their final speeches before stepping down, along with Ms Marwick and Annabel Goldie, ahead of the 5 May election. Salmond reiterated his view that Scotland is “not divided, but diverse,” welcomed new powers from the Scotland Bill (while criticizing unfulfilled promises made by unionist politicians), and humorously noted he was competing with the Chancellor’s budget and a Cheltenham horse race for attention. McNeil urged Holyrood to learn from Westminster about accountability and scrutiny, while Goldie quipped about her exchanges with Finance Secretary John Swinney. Ms Marwick thanked Salmond for his service and was visibly moved by McNeil’s speech, in which he emphasized the parliament’s duty to hold the government to account.

Sarah Rochira, the Older People's Commissioner for Wales, is gathering personal accounts from older people in residential care, as well as their friends and families, to inform recommendations for care providers and public bodies. Her review focuses on the quality of life for residents in terms of their physical health, psychological well-being, social relationships, and the care home environment. 

She aims to highlight examples of good care but also address the impact of poor care and inconsistencies across Wales. The review will use input from older people, carers, and families, along with care providers, staff, and public bodies, to clarify day-to-day realities and guide needed improvements. While Mario Kreft of Care Forum Wales supports the goals of the review, he expresses disappointment that no one with direct experience of living in or running a care home is included on the main advisory panel.

Harbro Group, based in Aberdeenshire, increased its pre-tax profit by £800,000 to £3.5 million in the year ending June 2016, despite turnover dropping by £1 million to just over £100 million. The company reported international sales growth in Europe and new markets. Harbro manufactures and supplies animal feed for the beef, sheep, dairy, pig, and poultry sectors, and runs 19 Country Store shops across Scotland catering to farming and rural communities with various products. While the agricultural outlook remains uncertain, including the impact of Brexit, the board is confident in the group's resilience moving forward.

A man in his 70s was found dead at a house on Nettleden Road in Little Gaddesden near Berkhamsted, and another man in his 80s was hospitalized. Detectives are treating the death as murder and are seeking 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin (also known as Ian John Baker), cautioning the public not to approach him. He is described as white, about 6ft tall, with greying collar-length hair, likely wearing sunglasses, blue jeans or three-quarter length trousers, and a dark blue, light blue, and white checked short-sleeved shirt. Police have urged anyone with information to contact them or Crimestoppers, and have increased patrols in the area for community reassurance.

David Lipton, the IMF’s second-in-command, warns that the global economy’s “weakening baseline” puts it at a delicate juncture. This caution follows stark Chinese trade data showing a significant drop in exports—down by a quarter year-on-year. As a result, the IMF is expected to cut its 3.4% global growth forecast in April, with these developments having ongoing effects on businesses that relied on China’s growth story.

The council held a scrutiny meeting to address issues with a new chain ferry, which has broken down, run aground, been suspended for training concerns, and damaged cars since launching in May. In response, the crossing at Cowes will be free until 2 July, and a project review by auditors has been ordered. Local businesses, suffering from lost trade, seek compensation. Transport councillor Ian Ward indicated that compensation is under discussion and described the ferry as a prototype experiencing “teething problems,” including electrical faults that have since been fixed. The council also authorized new ramp extensions to prevent vehicle scraping, and groundings were attributed to seamanship issues, which have been resolved.

A multi-vehicle crash occurred around 07:30 GMT on Thursday near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott, resulting in the death of a 32-year-old man at the scene. A 33-year-old man from Waterlooville was arrested on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention. The road remained closed between Thursley and Liphook until early evening while police investigated.

Matching Models, a London-based agency self-described as “an international temp agency for beautiful and talented people,” sparked controversy by advertising for staff with specific physical attributes, such as a particular cup size or “sexy” personal appearance. The UK Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) condemned these advertisements as unlawful and demeaning, while women’s equality organizations noted that they hearken back to outdated 1970s sexism. Employment lawyers warned that such ads clearly violate UK equality laws, which forbid specifying personal characteristics like age, race, or body type in job listings unless strictly essential to the role. Despite these criticisms, agency founder Nathalie Jansen defended the practice by citing clients’ wishes for specific “looks,” including one older gentleman seeking a “Jackie O” style outfit, and an Indian businessman asking for a blonde, blue-eyed Greek woman for his plane. The EHRC has demanded clarification of Matching Models’ hiring practices, emphasizing that first impressions in the 21st century should focus on non-discriminatory factors, not narrow physical requirements.

A shooting took place in a school hostel in Bangalore, where Mahesh, an office assistant, allegedly entered 18-year-old Gautami’s room and fatally shot her. He then shot and seriously injured another student, Sirisha, though she is expected to recover. Gun violence in Indian educational institutions is rare, and police have not established a motive. Mahesh, who was arrested after a manhunt, has been remanded until 12 April. Despite strict gun control laws in India, firearms are often used to settle disputes. A similar school shooting occurred in 2007 near Delhi, when a 14-year-old student was killed by classmates.

GLAAD’s study found 278 regular and recurring LGBT characters on scripted TV from June 2016 to May 2017, including a rise in transgender characters from seven to 16. However, they noted more than 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters were killed off, such as Poussey Washington (Orange is the New Black) and Bea Smith (Wentworth). The study also reported a record high percentage of Black characters, largely attributed to shows like Empire, Luke Cage, and How to Get Away with Murder. Although GLAAD president Sarah Kate Ellis welcomed this progress, she stressed that pure numbers “are only part of the story.”

David Mackintosh, the Conservative MP for Northampton South, announced he would not stand for re-election amid pressure from his local party. A significant portion of a public loan—around £10.25 million—to Northampton Town Football Club went missing under his leadership of the borough council. The unfinished stadium redevelopment remains under police investigation for alleged financial irregularities. Despite denying any wrongdoing, Mackintosh’s local party executive council indicated they would vote to deselect him, prompting his decision to step down.

Roy Oliver, a 37-year-old former police officer, shot and killed 15-year-old Jordan Edwards in April while responding to reports of underage drinking at a party in Balch Springs. Initially, police claimed the vehicle carrying Edwards and other teenagers reversed toward Oliver, but video showed it was moving away. Oliver was fired shortly after for policy violations and subsequently charged with murder as well as four counts of aggravated assault in relation to the other teenagers in the car. He currently awaits trial on bail; if convicted, this would mark the first police officer murder conviction in Dallas County since 1973. The county’s district attorney emphasized that the case is proceeding “effectively and thoroughly.”

Melania Trump’s choice to delay moving into the White House so Barron can finish his school year has stirred both support and criticism. Historically, only Martha Washington (before the White House was built) and Anna Harrison (whose husband died soon after becoming president) have not lived there as first ladies. Grover Cleveland’s wife frequently stayed elsewhere, and other presidents’ children have sometimes remained in school away from the White House initially. Critics say the first lady’s presence symbolizes U.S. leadership, while supporters praise her focus on Barron’s education. Traditionally, first ladies host events, attend functions, and advocate causes; Melania’s priorities appear centered primarily on her son, with a possible focus on combating cyber-bullying. Ivanka Trump might assist with some official duties, echoing past instances (like Chelsea Clinton stepping in for Hillary). Ultimately, families shape the role to suit their circumstances, as demonstrated by the Clintons and Obamas, who balanced parental responsibilities with public demands.

A 72-year-old man was found dead at a sheltered housing complex in Inverness on 27 October. The Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (PIRC), under instruction from the Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service, is examining the initial police response to the man’s call, while Police Scotland is cooperating and awaiting the findings. A report on the PIRC’s conclusions will be submitted to the Crown Office in due course.

A yellow wind warning has been issued, with gusts potentially reaching 75mph (120km/h), especially to the west of the mountains. An easterly wind direction could increase the impact, and disruption to travel by road and sea is likely. The warning applies to Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion, and Powys. Overnight gusts brought down a tree in Menai Bridge on Anglesey, closing Telford Road, which is expected to remain closed most of Monday for cleanup.

Belfast opened the scoring short-handed through Derrick Walser before Nottingham leveled. In the second period, Mike Forney’s powerplay goal made it 2–1, Andy Bohmback tied it again, then Mike Radja and James Desmarais pushed Belfast ahead 4–2. David Ling pulled one back for Nottingham, making it 4–3. They meet again in the second match of a double-header. Nottingham leads the league on 28 points, followed by Sheffield on 27 and Belfast on 25.

Nico Rosberg dominated the Chinese Grand Prix after a hectic first lap that saw collisions damage Lewis Hamilton’s and Kimi Raikkonen’s cars. Hamilton, forced to start at the back, broke his front wing and ultimately made five pit stops, leaving him with a substantial points deficit. Raikkonen’s front wing was also damaged when he moved into Sebastian Vettel’s path, as Vettel evaded an aggressive Daniil Kvyat. 

Kvyat finished on the podium, defending his move despite Vettel’s criticism. Daniel Ricciardo had snatched the early lead from Rosberg but suffered a puncture, clearing the way for Rosberg’s comfortable victory. Ferrari’s strategy on softer tyres aided Raikkonen’s recovery through the field, including passing Hamilton late on. Meanwhile, Hamilton’s Mercedes suffered significant aerodynamic damage, hampering his progress. With Rosberg taking his third consecutive win, history suggests he is well-positioned for the championship, leaving Hamilton facing an uphill battle.

Thomas Hitzlsperger publicly announced his homosexuality to highlight the overlooked issue of homophobia in German football. He received widespread support and praise from former teammates, prominent figures in the sport such as Reinhard Rauball and Theo Zwanziger, as well as public figures including German Chancellor Angela Merkel’s spokesman, Steffen Seibert. His announcement is regarded as groundbreaking in German football—an environment where many players feel pressured to remain silent. Previous discouraging remarks (for example, from Philipp Lahm) and the memory of Justin Fashanu’s tragic story underscore the risks players perceive in coming out while active. Hitzlsperger’s step is seen as a potential turning point, with hopes it will embolden other players to be open about their sexuality and foster greater acceptance in the sport.

Steve Sidwell, aged 34, has played a key role in Brighton’s successful push for promotion to the Premier League by making 32 Championship appearances this season. With his contract set to expire, he hopes to secure a new deal and extend his stay for the club’s first top-flight campaign in 34 years. Sidwell joined Brighton on loan from Stoke in 2015–16 before signing a one-year contract in June 2016. Having previously featured in the Premier League with several clubs (Reading, Chelsea, Aston Villa, Fulham, and Stoke), he believes his strong performances this season merit another chance at the highest level. Brighton, meanwhile, hold a four-point lead over Newcastle and aim to clinch the Championship title in their final two matches.

Blackpool opened the scoring early through Jamille Matt, who converted Nathan Delfouneso's precise cross. Colchester equalized soon after when Kurtis Guthrie bundled the ball in following a corner. Blackpool’s goalkeeper Sam Slocombe made several important saves, including stops against Matthew Briggs and George Elokobi, while Colchester twice went close to taking the lead before halftime. Blackpool missed a clear header to win it, and Colchester finished with 10 men after Sean Murray was sent off. The match ended 1–1.

Reid, aged 29, made 37 appearances for the Sky Blues last season, during which they were relegated from League One. He previously played for Charlton, Bradford, and Preston, and could make his debut for Colchester (the U’s) in Wednesday’s EFL Cup first-round match against Aston Villa. Colchester began their season with a 3-1 defeat at Accrington.

PC Keith Palmer’s murder highlighted the need for a permanent memorial honoring police officers who die on duty. The UK Police Memorial Trust is raising funds to build a tribute at the National Memorial Arboretum, inscribed with more than 1,400 names, and has appealed for £1.5 million, in addition to the government’s £1 million commitment toward the £4 million goal. Set to be completed by 2019, the memorial will feature a brass screen with leaf-shaped cutouts for bereaved families. According to Sir Hugh Orde and Home Secretary Amber Rudd, this memorial will serve as a lasting tribute to the courage and sacrifice of officers spanning the past 250 years.

Manchester United sit 15 points clear at the top of the Premier League following a 1–0 victory at Sunderland. Sir Alex Ferguson highlights the club’s record of 25 wins from 30 matches and emphasizes focusing on upcoming fixtures, specifically the derby against Manchester City. United have taken 50 out of a possible 54 points in their last 18 games and still have eight matches remaining to surpass Chelsea’s 95-point record. Ahead of their FA Cup quarter-final replay at Chelsea, Ferguson notes injuries to Rafael, Anderson, and goalkeeper David De Gea, and plans to rotate the squad, potentially bringing in Wayne Rooney, Ryan Giggs, and others. He praises the team’s determined defending and courage, crediting Sunderland for a challenging match.

Google chairman Eric Schmidt asserts that the company pays only what is legally required under existing UK tax laws and would comply with any changes set by the government. Between 2006 and 2011, Google paid £10 million in UK corporate taxes, routing most UK sales through Ireland. Margaret Hodge, head of the Parliamentary Public Accounts Committee, suggests creating a new committee that could hear evidence in secret to better oversee large firms’ tax arrangements. European Union leaders recently agreed to strengthen measures against tax avoidance by improving the exchange of information among tax authorities. Schmidt has also called for a simpler, internationally coordinated tax system, arguing that companies should be taxed in the countries where they carry out economic activity and take on business risks, and emphasizing that politicians, rather than companies, must set clear tax rules.

NHS Improvement set a goal to cut £1bn from last year’s £3.6bn spending on agency staff by the end of the financial year, but progress has fallen behind schedule. A cap introduced in October, limiting agency pay to 55% above standard rates (excluding senior managers), has saved £600m so far. Despite these savings, there are concerns that spending in other pay areas may be rising, and trusts remain 10% behind their target. NHS Improvement plans to publish performance “league tables” and track the highest-earning agency staff, after discovering examples of significantly inflated hourly rates. Chief executive Jim Mackey emphasizes that the NHS cannot sustain the high costs of agency staff.

Longford’s economy, once hit hard by the Celtic Tiger collapse, shows tentative signs of recovery. A local retailer notes recent business growth, partly through diversification. However, critics accuse the government of neglecting the midlands, pointing to investment in water meters instead of broadband and a lack of IDA attention to the area. In contrast, government representatives highlight a Center Parcs tourism plan promising around 1,000 jobs—though it still needs approval. While optimism is rising, local traders also urge further support, such as easing parking fees, to help boost the town’s revitalization.

The tournament involves eight teams playing each other twice, with the top four qualifying for play-offs. It concludes on 29 May. Current leading run-scorers include Warner (294), Kohli (267), and De Villiers (249), with Warner and De Villiers hitting the most sixes (12 each). De Kock holds the highest individual score (108). McClenaghan (9), Kumar (8), and Rahman (7) top the wicket tally. Four current or former England players—Eoin Morgan, Jos Buttler, Sam Billings, and Kevin Pietersen—are participating. A full schedule of matches runs daily (mostly 15:30 BST) through to the final on 29 May.

The passage reports a 200-million increase in plastic carrier bag usage since 2013, highlighting environmental concerns such as landfill and river pollution due to non-recyclable bags being discarded. From October, England will introduce a 5p charge per bag, following similar measures in Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland, where usage has fallen. Campaigners hope this charge in England will reduce the number of bags thrown away and help protect the environment.

High winds across Wales caused extensive disruption, including part of a school roof being torn off at Rhosgadfan near Caernarfon and power cuts affecting hundreds of homes. Arriva Trains Wales services and major bridges operated under speed or lane restrictions, while Irish Ferries canceled fast sailings between Holyhead and Dublin. The National Trust closed Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle due to the severe weather, and Rhyl’s Boxing Day Dip was postponed by a day. Winds eased by Friday evening, lifting earlier bridge restrictions, but travel delays and cancellations remained a concern during one of the busiest festive travel days.

Michael B. Jordan expressed excitement about joining the Black Panther film but did not reveal his role. He will reunite with his Creed director Ryan Coogler and looks forward to working with Chadwick Boseman, who currently appears as Black Panther in Captain America: Civil War, and Lupita Nyong’o, who won an Oscar for 12 Years a Slave. Jordan previously played the Human Torch in the Fantastic Four reboot, while Nyong’o appeared as Maz Kanata in Star Wars: The Force Awakens. Black Panther is scheduled for release in February 2018.

The 1875 theatre at Alexandra Palace is set to be restored and reopened, potentially in 2018, to host performances, cinema, comedy, and live music. The neighboring BBC studios will also be repaired. Both projects are part of a larger east wing restoration to create a new cultural destination, with the glazed east court becoming public and exhibition space. Of the £26.6m refurbishment cost, the Heritage Lottery Fund is contributing £18.8m, Haringey Council £6.8m, and the Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust aims to raise the remaining £1m by summer 2017. The theatre, unused for decades, retains much of its original décor and was originally designed for a wide range of entertainment, including opera and early film screenings.

James Milner, 30, a former Manchester City player, earned 61 England caps after his 2009 senior debut. He featured at two World Cups and two Euros, though he played just three minutes at Euro 2016. He holds the record for most England Under-21 caps (46) and scored his only senior international goal in a 5-0 win over Moldova during the 2014 World Cup qualifiers. Milner stated his decision to step away was “about common sense,” wishing the team success under new manager Sam Allardyce.

Marcy Smith’s home in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador, was destroyed by a fire that started from rubbish burned in a wood stove. Her son David, who was on FaceTime with his father, noticed the flames and woke everyone. Although the family escaped with only their pajamas, they lost their dog and cats, and the fire alarm never went off. The local community quickly rallied with donations of clothes and other necessities. Marcy credits David’s alertness for saving her and his sister, and she remains profoundly proud of his actions.

The passage reports that West Ham’s owners, David Sullivan and David Gold—who bought a majority stake in 2010 for £105 million and now own over 85%—have been linked to potential takeovers, including a rumored £200 million bid from an energy drinks giant, as well as interest from Qatari and Chinese groups since the club’s move to London Stadium. Although Sullivan indicated a minority shareholding could be sold to clear debts, both owners intend to keep the club in their families.

The awards show featured fan-voted categories like Best Kiss and Best Shirtless Performance, with Zac Efron winning the latter again. The Fault in Our Stars was the big winner, taking Best Movie, and its star Shailene Woodley received multiple honors including Best Female Performance, the Trailblazer Award, and Best Kiss (with Ansel Elgort). Bradley Cooper won Best Male Performance for American Sniper, dedicating the award to the late Chris Kyle. Channing Tatum earned Best Comedic Performance for 22 Jump Street, and Meryl Streep was recognized as Best Villain for Into the Woods. Other winners included Jennifer Lopez, Jennifer Lawrence, Seth Rogen, and Rose Byrne. Kevin Hart brought his children onstage to accept the Comedic Genius Award, and Robert Downey Jr received the Generation Award presented by his Avengers co-stars. The show also served as an unofficial platform to preview upcoming summer films such as Pitch Perfect 2, Trainwreck, and Marvel’s Ultron.

Cammy Smith, a 21-year-old Scotland Under-21 forward, was loaned from Aberdeen (the Dons) to Dundee United in July and has scored five goals this season. Having made his Aberdeen debut in 2012, he tallied four goals in 89 appearances for the Pittodrie side. St Mirren manager Jack Ross described Smith’s move to his club as a “brilliant acquisition,” praising him as mature and versatile in attack. Bottom of the Championship, St Mirren will face Falkirk on Saturday.

Northumberland County Council plans to use Jetpatcher machines to fill up to 145 potholes per day over the next four months now that the weather is warm enough. Additional staff will also be deployed to repair rain-damaged drainage systems and clear debris from gutters.

A group of Wood Group contractors on EnQuest’s Thistle platform, off Shetland, discovered they had been exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM) during pipework removal in December. Rigging supervisor Steve Innes says they were unaware of the hazard initially and lacked proper PPE. Although EnQuest and Wood Group state the radiation levels were below reportable limits, blood tests and other precautions are ongoing. Both companies emphasize their commitment to safety and have taken extra measures to prevent future exposure. The Health and Safety Executive (HSE) was informed, but determined the incident was not reportable under current regulations. Union representatives criticize the handling of the situation, calling for greater transparency and worker protections.

The Asian Civilisations Museum (ACM) purchased a bronze Hindu goddess sculpture for $650,000 from New York dealer Art of the Past in 2007. The dealer’s manager later admitted to trafficking stolen Indian antiquities, including this piece, which is believed to have been taken from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu. After discussions with India’s Archaeological Survey (ASI)—which formally requested its return in May—the museum decided to hand the sculpture back. Although no conclusive proof exists of the piece’s exact origins, the ACM noted the dealer’s confession and will seek compensation for the apparent fraud; the sculpture was one of 30 items bought from the same seller, and no other piece is currently suspected of being stolen.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck about 35km north of Lucca at a depth of 15.5km, felt as far away as Milan, Florence, Bologna, and Modena. Though there were no immediate reports of injuries or damage, phone lines and power supplies were disrupted in Garfagnana, and local schools were evacuated for safety checks. Italy’s National Institute of Geophysics and Volcanology described the quake as “medium-strong” and “fairly shallow,” and several smaller aftershocks followed. The incident underscores Italy’s vulnerability to seismic activity—nearly 300 people died in a 2009 quake in L’Aquila, and more than 20 were killed by two earthquakes last May. In 2012, six scientists and an ex-official were found guilty of manslaughter for providing misleading information about the L’Aquila quake risk, which contributed to loss of life.

Austin Grant, a 62-year-old grandfather from Sheffield, initially doubted South Yorkshire’s climate for growing fruit. As of 8 September 2016, he confirmed that the fruit remains attached to the plant and is not yet ripe. Nonetheless, he was delighted by its progress, saying he was “literally jumping for joy.”

Rockstar has postponed the PC release of Grand Theft Auto V from 27 January to 24 March to allow for additional testing and polish. Online heists for console players will arrive before this new PC launch date. Rockstar has released screenshots showcasing the PC version’s enhanced visuals, supporting resolutions up to 4K and high-performance features such as 1080p at 60fps and triple monitor setups. Minimum PC specifications are available for those wanting to prepare their systems, and the announcement follows the game’s record-breaking success, earning $1 billion in revenue within three days of its original release in 2013.

Simpson, aged 76, won the £25,000 John Moores Painting Prize at Liverpool’s Walker Art Gallery for his painting “Squint (19).” Having been shortlisted in 1991 and longlisted three other times, he described finally winning as “very nice indeed.” Judge Ansel Krut praised “Squint (19)” for its subtlety and difficult subject matter: it depicts a “leper squint,” an opening in medieval churches allowing outcasts to view services. Measuring around seven feet tall, the painting was chosen partly for its relatively manageable size, with Simpson adding he would spend the prize money on high-quality materials. The John Moores Painting Prize, established in 1957, is one of Britain’s oldest art awards; previous winners include David Hockney, Peter Doig, and Sir Peter Blake.

Two pro-government newspapers in Istanbul, Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit, were attacked by masked assailants overnight. Although no one was hurt, both buildings were hit by gunfire, shattering windows, and a small fire at Yeni Safak’s office was quickly put out. Police have cordoned off the sites and found bullet casings at both scenes. The two newspapers, which support President Erdogan’s AK Party, are located about 20km apart, and the attacks happened almost simultaneously. No group has claimed responsibility. A similar incident occurred previously when pro-government protesters targeted the newspaper Hurriyet.

A 24-year-old player, formerly under contract with the Stags, has been brought in on a free transfer by Marcus Bignot. He spent the first half of the season at Crawley, netting three goals in 23 appearances, and is an ex-Burton player. He will officially join the Mariners on 1 January, becoming Bignot’s first signing for the club.

Arsène Wenger, whose contract runs until the summer, has been linked to the England manager’s position but says he is focusing on his club role. He praises caretaker boss Gareth Southgate, who replaced Sam Allardyce, noting Southgate has gained experience and can answer questions about his suitability by making sound decisions in upcoming matches, including a World Cup qualifier against Scotland and a friendly with Spain. Wenger also addresses speculation around defender Héctor Bellerín, confirming that Arsenal intends to extend his contract and that he sees Bellerín’s future at the club despite reported interest from Barcelona and Manchester City. Additionally, Wenger reveals that midfielder Aaron Ramsey will remain sidelined for “one or two” more games due to a hamstring injury.

A local man fell from a cherry picker at Fruehauf on Houghton Road at about 13:45 GMT on Thursday. Lincolnshire Police and the Health and Safety Executive are jointly investigating the incident, and the company is cooperating fully with their inquiry.

Transport Minister Humza Yousaf announced that a new charter deal would resolve the dispute over sub-minimum wage pay for crews on two freight vessels, Hellier and Hildasay. Previously operated by Seatruck under contract to Serco Northlink, the boats will return to Serco Northlink’s direct operation. While Seatruck had argued non-UK crew were not covered by the national minimum wage, Serco Northlink had offered to bridge and backdate any pay gap. The new arrangement, set to begin next month once details are finalized, ensures all crew will receive at least the minimum wage. Serco Northlink, which holds a £243m six-year contract awarded in 2012, operates subsidized ferry and cargo services to the Northern Isles.

Ken Dickie, 64, died on 14 May, six days after an altercation at Rockley Park in Poole. Jamie Mitchell, 35, intervened in an argument between Mr Dickie and Mitchell’s mother, Samantha, on 7 May after they had been drinking at the holiday park bar. The two men were separated by bystanders. Mr Mitchell admitted to common assault, and both he and his mother pleaded guilty to attempting to pervert the course of justice by initially giving false statements. Mr Mitchell later described the incident as a “tragic accident.” Sentencing for both is set for 6 February.

Rod Temperton, a British songwriter from Cleethorpes, died at 66 after a short battle with cancer. Known as “The Invisible Man” for his low profile, he first achieved success in the 1970s with the disco band Heatwave, writing hits like “Boogie Nights,” “Always & Forever,” and “Groove Line.” His work caught the attention of producer Quincy Jones, who enlisted Temperton to write for Michael Jackson’s breakthrough solo albums, Off the Wall (“Rock With You,” “Off the Wall,” “Burn This Disco Out”) and Thriller (“Thriller,” “Baby Be Mine,” “The Lady in My Life”). Temperton’s songs also appeared on records by Anita Baker, Donna Summer, Aretha Franklin, and others. He won a Grammy in 1990 for “Birdland” with Quincy Jones and received two Oscar nominations in 1986 for work on The Color Purple soundtrack. Following his passing, fellow musicians like Nile Rodgers, LaToya Jackson, Mark Ronson, and Chaka Khan paid tribute to Temperton’s prolific songwriting legacy.

Researchers from Swansea University, alongside Brazilian and UK colleagues, have uncovered over 450 ancient earthworks in Acre state, western Brazilian Amazon—likely around 2,000 years old and known as geoglyphs. These structures, hidden by bamboo-dominated rainforest until recent deforestation, do not appear to be villages or fortifications. Instead, evidence suggests they were sporadically used ritual spaces built amid taller forest. Analyses of plant fossils, charcoal, and isotopes reveal significant human influence on the surrounding environment over at least 6,000 years, indicating that people selectively cultivated useful tree species rather than clearing large areas—creating a form of “prehistoric supermarket.” This ancient agroforestry legacy may still shape today’s forest biodiversity.

Nick Kyrgios, ranked a career-high 12th, defeated Sam Querrey 6-4 6-4 in 53 minutes to reach the second round at the Shanghai Masters. He recently won the Japan Open and is closing in on the top 10. Kyrgios said he felt “bored” and “tired” during the match, attributing his fatigue to late arrivals, poor sleep, and the lengthy travel to the Qi Zhong Stadium. Last year in Shanghai, he was fined for using foul language, referring to the tournament as a “circus.”

Scientists, charities, and medical organizations in Wales are pushing for an HPV vaccination program to include boys, highlighting rising head and neck cancer cases linked to the virus. The Welsh government is waiting for guidance from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation. Currently, girls aged 12 and 13 already receive the HPV jab to protect against cervical cancer, and 85% of girls in Wales are vaccinated. However, experts note that three-quarters of HPV-related head and neck cancer patients are men, with most being non-smokers around age 55. Advocates argue that vaccinating boys now could reduce the global cancer burden attributable to HPV and demonstrate a strong commitment to public health.

Jak Trueman was a 15-year-old with a rare blood cancer, gamma delta T-cell lymphoma, who documented his treatment and experiences on social media. Diagnosed in August, he shared his journey on a Facebook page called “Jak’s Journey,” with his mother, sister, and girlfriend helping. Despite his illness, he briefly attended a school prom held for him, meeting former Rangers captain Barry Ferguson, though he had to leave due to feeling unwell. His positive outlook inspired many, and his Facebook page garnered over 28,000 Likes. He received the Bronze Duke of Edinburgh Award and the Kerry MacGregor Memorial Trophy. Doctors later found the cancer had spread and ceased further treatment; however, Jak continued to enjoy special outings and encouraged donations to Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research. He passed away shortly afterward, with his mother announcing his death on Facebook. A charity football match was organized to raise additional funds in his honor.

Egypt secured a 1-0 victory over Uganda with an 89th-minute goal by Abdallah El Said, set up by Mohamed Salah. Earlier, Uganda had a goal correctly ruled out for offside. The result knocks Uganda out of the tournament, while Ghana had already progressed after beating Mali 1-0. Egypt next face Ghana for top spot in Group D, and Uganda will play Mali, who must win and hope Egypt lose by at least two goals to advance.

Lancashire County Council plans to build a new railway station in Skelmersdale on land at the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College, both currently unused. The move follows a Network Rail study that compared these sites with another near the Concourse shopping centre. Skelmersdale’s original station closed in 1956; under the new plan, there could be two direct trains per hour to Liverpool. Local officials describe this as an exciting step forward, noting the chosen site allows for future expansion and has good road and area connectivity. The council will now begin acquiring the necessary land. Skelmersdale, designated a new town in 1961, remains among the largest in north-west England without its own station.
During a Saturday morning search of a warehouse near Ashbourne, police discovered plants in what they described as “an elaborate grow house.” A man in his late 40s was arrested at the scene.

A 28-year-old woman in Hamelin was found seriously injured after reportedly being dragged by the neck through several streets. She underwent emergency surgery and was transferred to a specialist clinic. Her 38-year-old ex-partner, from nearby Bad Muender, later turned himself in to police. Both the victim and suspect are German citizens of Kurdish origin. Authorities say the motive is unclear, and they are seeking eyewitness accounts.

The study, which analyzed 4,600 workers using Australian survey data, found that although women ask for pay rises just as often as men, they are less likely to receive them. It disproved the “reticent female” theory, noting no evidence that women hesitate to negotiate out of fear or stereotype concerns. When like-for-like male and female workers were compared, men were 25% more likely to be granted a raise. The researchers suggest possible discrimination could be at play. The study also revealed that among men and women under 40, both ask for and receive raises at the same rate, hinting that negotiation patterns may be shifting for younger generations.

Oxford City Council has spent money investigating possible new burial sites but has been unable to find suitable land. Two cemeteries, Wolvercote and Botley, still have space until about 2018 and 2021, respectively. After that, only reopening existing family plots, using reserved plots, and interring ashes will be possible. The council cites issues such as ground conditions, water table problems, and usage covenants for ruling out potential sites. The last increase in Oxford’s burial space was in 1932.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival, running from 19–22 July in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis, will let visitors use an app to scan signs and posters for online content such as band interviews and videos. Notable acts include The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean. According to festival director Caroline Maclennan, this app-based augmented reality feature will enhance the festival experience, allowing people onsite or worldwide to access information, interviews, buy tickets, and capture the event’s atmosphere.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred racehorse, collapsed and died following victory in the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham. A veterinary examination revealed the cause to be a severe pulmonary hemorrhage. Although the horse had a history of post-race ataxia (including overheating and wobbling), he had shown no related symptoms on the day of his final race and had never before collapsed. Experts note that this type of hemorrhage is rare, even in otherwise healthy sport horses. Many Clouds had enjoyed significant success, including wins in the Grand National, the Gold Cup trial, and the Hennessy Gold Cup, and was described by trainer Oliver Sherwood as a “horse of a lifetime.”

The passage describes a rape case involving a now-34-year-old defendant, Davina (formerly David), who met the then-15-year-old victim in 2004. Davina denies the charge but will be sentenced on 4 March. Because the judge considers her a risk to herself and of absconding, she is to be remanded in custody, likely at a male prison. The court heard that Davina has learning difficulties and previously attempted suicide. She changed her name in 2012 and has made no physical or medical transition. The alleged rape happened in a garage while two others were asleep; the victim recalls shouting for Davina to stop. In 2014, Davina disclosed the attack to a care home worker.

Novak Djokovic and his Serbian doubles partner lost 6-4 6-4 to Brazil’s Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in Rio, following Djokovic’s earlier singles exit at the hands of Juan Martin del Potro. Before the Olympics, Djokovic, the world number one at age 29 and already a 12-time Grand Slam champion, had bounced back from a surprise Wimbledon third-round loss to Sam Querrey by claiming his 30th Masters title in Toronto.

More than 20 competitors from Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada, and the US are set to compete in a chainsaw-only carving event on Saturday in Carrbridge, in the Cairngorms. They will transform logs into animal and human sculptures using only chainsaws, with other tools strictly banned. Last year’s champion, Scotland-based carver Pete Bowsher, will return to defend his title and retain the Claymore Trophy.

Rhys Webb, who has been sidelined since a serious foot injury in a World Cup warm-up in September, is nearing a return to fitness. The 27-year-old expects to be ready before Wales’s Six Nations campaign, aiming for an early February comeback. Wales begins the tournament on 7 February against Ireland in Dublin. Webb, capped 16 times, has renewed his national dual contract with the Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, choosing to stay at his home region over other offers to maintain his chances of playing for Wales.

Two men were apprehended near Sumas, Washington, after U.S. border agents interrupted an alleged attempt to smuggle ecstasy from Canada to San Francisco. When agents approached them, one man fired a weapon and ran; the other, identified as Jeffrey Laviolette, was taken into custody. The fugitive, Nathan Hall, was later arrested in British Columbia. Their backpacks reportedly contained 58 pounds of ecstasy, along with a driver’s license bearing Hall’s photo but another name. Authorities also arrested two alleged accomplices, Kali Henifin and Ryan Lambert; Lambert claimed he was to be paid $11,000 to transport the drugs. All three defendants held in U.S. custody face conspiracy, drug possession, and distribution charges. The wooded area where the incident occurred is known as a common smuggling route for drugs and firearms.

Childline counseled more than 4,500 children in the past year, nearly doubling from 2011–12 figures. Many young victims—including some as young as seven—reported severe torment and fear. Dame Esther Rantzen called these findings a crucial wake-up call, highlighting how cyberbullying invades children’s lives beyond school. She stressed the importance of adult intervention, as bullying often worsens without help. The report coincides with Anti-Bullying Week, organized by the Anti Bullying Alliance, which collaborates with parents, schools, and others. Children who contacted Childline noted the emotional toll of being told to harm themselves and the lack of understanding from some parents.

Israel postponed a planned vote on approving nearly 500 new settlement homes in East Jerusalem following a request from Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s office, in an apparent attempt to avoid further conflict with the United States before US Secretary of State John Kerry’s speech on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. This occurred shortly after the US abstained from a UN Security Council resolution calling for an end to settlement construction, which infuriated Netanyahu. Israel rejects the resolution—specifically its condemnation of activities in East Jerusalem—and has taken diplomatic steps in response, including summoning ambassadors and cutting aid. The US denies Israeli claims that it helped draft and push the resolution. Meanwhile, Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas views the resolution as advancing prospects for a planned Middle East peace conference in France.

The passage describes preparations and tributes for the Queen’s 90th birthday, including the release of a new four-generational royal portrait for commemorative stamps and events at Windsor, such as unveiling a new bandstand, viewing a Royal Mail exhibition, and marking the 500th anniversary of the postal service. Prime Minister David Cameron and Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn plan to send their birthday wishes, while Prince William praises the Queen as a “guiding example” of a monarch. He addresses criticisms of being “work-shy,” explaining he is gradually assuming more royal duties. Celebrations include the Queen lighting a beacon to start a chain of beacons worldwide, a lunch with President Obama, and recognition that the Queen traditionally has both an actual and an official birthday. The republican group Republic criticizes the BBC’s coverage as excessive.

West Ham United won 2-0 at Cheltenham Town with first-half goals from Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew, taking control early and seeing out the result. Cheltenham, unchanged from a recent league defeat, created some promising chances through Harry Pell and substitute Dan Holman but rarely threatened goalkeeper Adrian. West Ham, having made seven changes after recent Premier League losses, nearly extended the lead through James Collins and Sam Byram. The win repeats West Ham’s narrow victory over Cheltenham at the same EFL Cup stage four years prior and ends League Two’s representation in this year’s competition before the third-round draw.

Hospital radiographer Aidan McNicholl, 36, died in a crash on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion after Andreas Werner, 46, of Leipzig, failed to notice the motorcyclist while turning his VW Transporter. Werner, a father of four, pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving, received a £1,000 fine, and was banned from driving in the UK for two years. The victim’s family accepted it was a momentary lapse and saw no value in a prison sentence, while Werner expressed remorse and offered no explanation for the incident.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old from west London, traveled to Syria in January and joined the Islamic State–affiliated group Rayat al Tawheed. Under the alias Abu Daigham al-Britani, he regularly posted propaganda, showed gruesome images, and appealed for donations. After faking his own death online, he tried to secretly return to the UK with help from his cousin, but was arrested at Dover. He was deemed highly dangerous by MI5 and, upon remand, held in a special high-risk unit. Khawaja has admitted to four terrorism-related offences, and a more serious charge of soliciting to murder remains on file.

Kayden Jackson, 22, scored four goals in 36 appearances last season as Wrexham finished eighth. Now Barnsley’s third signing for next season, he joins ahead of their League One play-off final at Wembley. Caretaker boss Paul Heckingbottom praised his pace and attacking style. Jackson turned down a contract offer from Wrexham for next season.

A large number of Vanish detergent bottles have washed up on several Cornish beaches—including Poldhu Cove, Gunwalloe, Polurrian, Church Cove, and Marazion—after possibly falling overboard from a container ship near Land’s End. The National Trust and other agencies are removing the bottles, warning the public to keep children and pets away. Conservationists, including Cornwall Wildlife Trust, are concerned about the environmental impact, though most bottles remain sealed. The Maritime and Coastguard Agency notes the link to the MV Blue Ocean—known to have lost a container—is not yet confirmed, but evidence points to stormy weather causing the container to go overboard. The situation is being monitored by local authorities, and Vanish’s parent company has not yet commented.

An incident took place at around 14:00 on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness, resulting in several minor injuries. The road was closed, with traffic diverted via the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich route. Police Scotland confirmed investigations are continuing.

Dorian Dervite, a 28-year-old French centre-back, made 14 appearances last season to help Bolton Wanderers secure second place in League One and promotion. Joining from Charlton in 2014, he has totaled 83 appearances for the club. Manager Phil Parkinson praised his contribution toward the end of the campaign. Dervite is the latest player, after David Wheater, Gary Madine, and Jem Karacan, to sign a new contract following Bolton’s promotion to the Championship.

The passage describes a fallout between the Liberal Democrats (Lib Dems) and Labour after they initially joined forces in the Lords to challenge the government on EU citizens’ rights and on requiring parliamentary approval for a Brexit deal. When MPs rejected their amendments, Labour chose to accept the Commons’ decision, while Lib Dems insisted on persisting, leading Labour to accuse them of “grandstanding” and offering “false hope.” In return, the Lib Dems criticized Labour for “waving through” the government’s Brexit plans. Both parties have previously formed alliances on various issues, but their current dispute signals tensions that could linger, even though each side suggests they can still work together on matters where they agree.

The passage highlights that defense spending and policy have slipped low on the political agenda in the UK, with public and political priorities centered on issues like the economy, the NHS, and immigration. Despite growing global threats—ranging from Russian belligerence to Islamic extremism— Britain’s armed forces have been subject to significant cuts, and defense now accounts for less of the nation’s GDP, threatening to drop below NATO’s 2% threshold. Only UKIP and the DUP pledge to meet that goal. Major parties—Conservative, Labour, and Liberal Democrats—offer limited and vague defense proposals; none fully protect the defense budget from further cuts, which may include reductions to the Army, Navy, and Air Force or scaling back on major procurements. A key point of contention is Trident, the UK’s nuclear deterrent, with each party proposing different policies ranging from renewal with four new submarines to scrapping it entirely. The passage also notes concern over two new aircraft carriers, which risk being under-resourced in both crew and fighter jets. Overall, the text underscores uncertainty over how these parties will address future defense challenges and maintain Britain’s perceived military credibility.

Barcelona insists it committed no offence in relation to Neymar’s transfer but has paid an additional €13.55m to cover differing tax interpretations. Originally stating they paid €57m (£48.6m), it emerged the total cost—including fees and wages—could reach £106.8m, with £34m going to Neymar’s parents. Former president Sandro Rosell resigned amid misappropriation accusations, which he denies. A Spanish judge is continuing investigations into the transfer, and there is no confirmation yet on whether Barcelona’s extra payment will end the case. Meanwhile, Neymar has scored seven league goals and three Champions League goals this season.

Michael Luciw, a 27-year-old father from Nottingham, was killed when the van in which he was a passenger was struck head-on by a car traveling the wrong way, driven by Albert Kenneth Newman, who also died. Luciw’s family advocates for mandatory, practical driving tests for older drivers, arguing that slower reactions raise risks and that those unfit to drive can still maintain independence via free bus passes. Currently, UK drivers over 70 must fill out a self-assessment form every three years, but medical or on-road tests are not required. The DVLA says evidence does not indicate a higher crash rate among older drivers and that licensure is revoked if individuals fail to meet health standards. Age UK emphasizes preserving older adults’ driving independence, as it is crucial to their daily lives.

Scottish transvaginal mesh implants, used to treat incontinence, have been under intense scrutiny due to serious side effects reported by some women. Two patient representatives quit the original independent review, claiming its final report was watered down. Subsequently, Prof Alison Britton is now tasked with examining how the review reached its conclusions. The report itself advises against routinely offering mesh procedures for pelvic organ prolapse, recommends informing patients of all treatment options, and calls for mandatory reporting of adverse events. Despite calls for a total ban, the Scottish government does not have authority to prohibit the procedures; that power lies with a UK regulatory body. Criticism also focused on the review’s chair, who took over late in the process, and apologized for failing to produce a consensus. Over 20,000 women in Scotland have received implants in the past two decades, with more than 400 currently pursuing legal action over complications.

Laura Muir, 23, broke Liz McColgan’s 25-year-old indoor 5K record by 14 seconds with a time of 14 minutes, 49.12 seconds. McColgan, though initially concerned about whether Muir’s solo run met UK Athletics’ requirements—particularly regarding race format and drug testing—expressed delight and noted that British Athletics expects Muir’s time to be officially ratified. McColgan praised Muir’s talent, predicting even faster times in the future and highlighting her potential for world-level success. She also compared Muir’s record performance to her own achievement 25 years ago, when she lapped a young Paula Radcliffe. Muir has previously broken the British 1500m record and reached the 1500m final at the Rio 2016 Olympics.

Michael Jung claimed victory riding Sam, a late stand-in after Fischertakinou’s July infection. France’s Astier Nicolas took silver, and Phillip Dutton of the United States secured bronze. Great Britain’s William Fox-Pitt, who recovered from an induced coma 10 months earlier, finished 12th after errors in the cross-country phase derailed his early lead. He had led following the dressage but dropped to 21st before rallying with a flawless show-jumping round. Ireland’s Jonty Evans placed ninth. The passage also mentions opportunities to engage with equestrian sports during the Rio Olympics, including meeting “Henry the mechanical horse” and accessing a BBC Sport newsletter.

Andy Murray beat Fabio Fognini, 6-2 4-6 6-1 7-5, in a two-hour, 39-minute match that nearly went to a fifth set. Fognini had five set points in the fourth, but Murray won five straight games to avoid the decider, securing a place in the last 16 for the 11th time. He will next face Benoit Paire on Monday. Elsewhere, Johanna Konta advanced to the second week for the first time with a 6-4 6-1 victory over Maria Sakkari. Murray acknowledged the match’s ups and downs but expressed relief at finishing in four sets before dark. Fognini showed flashes of both brilliance and frustration, including a penalty for a visible obscenity. Despite double-faulting and appearing vulnerable at times, Murray produced a late comeback in the fourth set, demonstrating his trademark resilience to clinch the win.

Paramedics were called to Joe's Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST on 6 October 2014 following a sudden death. Police arriving afterwards discovered patrons still on the premises, with till receipts indicating alcohol had been served until 04:49 BST. The judge closed the bar for three months and noted that Colleen O’Neill, the license holder, had “an appalling record”; she was fined £3,000 for allowing alcohol consumption outside licensed hours. James Thomas was fined £1,000 on a similar charge. The judge lamented not having the power to impose a custodial sentence.

Mike Nesbitt launched the Ulster Unionists’ “Real Partnership” manifesto, emphasizing that the election should serve as a referendum on the Renewable Heat Incentive scandal. Amid controversy over his call for voters to transfer to the SDLP, Nesbitt stood by his remarks and denied making any mistake, noting that partnership in a future government would likely involve a nationalist party. While a senior colleague, Danny Kennedy, distanced himself publicly from the comments, Nesbitt joked this showed Kennedy was listening. The manifesto itself focuses on reducing hospital waiting lists, increasing police numbers, improving infrastructure, supporting LGBT rights, and ensuring no group is disadvantaged by Brexit. Nesbitt framed the election as a judgment on “incompetence, arrogance, cronyism and a strong whiff of corruption,” criticizing the current DUP–Sinn Féin governance.

Justice Minister Claire Sugden will bring forward a motion to the Northern Ireland Assembly to pardon men convicted under now-abolished sexual offences, in line with measures already announced in England and Wales (known as “Turing’s Law”). This includes both posthumous pardons and the opportunity for living men to apply for pardons. Sugden has secured executive agreement for the legislative consent motion, aiming to achieve equal treatment for gay and bisexual men in Northern Ireland and to address past injustices. The proposal will now go before the assembly for approval.

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old from Kinross, broke Yvonne Murray’s 1994 Scottish mile record by running 4:19.12, placing her second behind Faith Kipyegon and also second on the British all-time list behind Zola Budd. Muir, who now holds both the Scottish 1500m and mile records, expressed her delight at the achievement. Having finished fifth in the previous year’s World Championships, she is aiming to secure a spot for Great Britain at the Rio Olympics. After an 800m win in France, she will next compete in a 1500m race in Stockholm. Muir balances her training alongside her veterinary studies, having recently completed her fourth year.
The passage presents a collection of pictures showcasing 26 beaches in Scotland that have been ranked as “most excellent” for their water quality.

Met Police barrister Richard Horwell QC argued that suspects Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi lacked a personal motive to kill Alexander Litvinenko and that the Russian state likely sponsored his murder. Litvinenko was poisoned with polonium-210 during a meeting with the two men, leading to his death three weeks later. Horwell noted that the use of polonium pointed to Russian state involvement, but stressed there was no direct evidence implicating President Putin personally. Litvinenko’s defection to the UK in 2000 and his criticisms of Russian authorities could have been viewed as treachery, providing possible motives. Horwell also highlighted that Litvinenko was poisoned twice, public health risks to London remain uncertain, and the suspects remain in Russia with extradition attempts having failed. The inquiry was adjourned until Friday.

Steve Smith, aged 26, has been named as Australia's new captain in Test cricket, succeeding Michael Clarke after Clarke announced his retirement. Smith already leads the one-day side and will captain the Twenty20 team in Aaron Finch’s absence. David Warner, 28, has been appointed vice-captain despite past disciplinary issues, with selector Rod Marsh praising both players: he cites Smith's exemplary talent and Warner's maturation. Smith previously captained the Test side in three matches when Clarke was injured and has an impressive record of 2,952 runs at an average of 54.66. Both Smith and Warner will also lead Australia in the upcoming limited-overs matches following the final Ashes Test at the Oval.

Tim Farron repeatedly declined to say whether he considers homosexual sex sinful, instead stating that “we are all sinners.” While emphasizing his commitment to LGBT+ rights and his intent to defend and extend equal marriage—particularly addressing barriers facing transgender people—he faced questions about his past vote against the 2007 Equality Bill. Farron explained that the Liberal Democrats had proposed an amendment due to concerns over “protection of individual liberties”; when it failed, he voted against the bill. Despite these controversies, he insists he fully supports equality under the law for all.

Sanofi’s 2015 closure of its Fawdon drug manufacturing site resulted in the loss of 450 jobs. Now, Accord Healthcare will take over the facility, aiming to re-employ former Sanofi staff. Local leaders, including Councillor Nick Forbes, see this as a positive boost for Newcastle’s science and healthcare sector. Accord Healthcare itself is a global pharmaceutical firm, developing and distributing over 130 products to around 60 countries.

Three senior council staff members—Richard Ellis (former interim corporate governance director and acting deputy chief executive), Ciaran Monaghan (head of the chief executive’s office), and Ewan Sutherland (head of human resources and customer services)—are leaving the council. Ellis’s departure coincides with the end of his contract, while Monaghan and Sutherland are taking voluntary redundancy and early retirement. Opposition SNP leader Stephen Flynn criticized the departures as evidence of the council’s difficulty retaining senior staff and expects further resignations. Angela Scott, the council’s chief executive, thanked the three for their commitment and professionalism.

Guy Martin crashed at this year’s TT on a mechanically troubled Honda Fireblade. He initially told MCN he was quitting road racing but later clarified on Facebook that he’s not done racing, only halting his Honda road racing plans for this year. Following John McGuinness’s crash, Martin skipped the North West 200 and will also miss next month’s Ulster Grand Prix. Calling the TT a “bloody disaster,” he said he ended up acting as a test rider. After further testing showed the bike wouldn’t be competitive at the Ulster GP, his team withdrew him. Martin says he has “no unfinished business” and wants to race classics and unusual events instead.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) secured 19 out of 28 governorships in elections that further weakened the once-dominant Peoples Democratic Party (PDP), which now holds only eight seats (with Taraba’s result still pending and one inconclusive race in Imo). APC’s gains include many northern states and Lagos in the southwest, but the party failed to win any of the five oil-producing states in the south—a potential challenge for President-elect Muhammadu Buhari. While some areas saw violence, overall the polls were more peaceful than past elections. The PDP, in power since 1999, was hurt by defections, corruption accusations, and its inability to end the Boko Haram insurgency, leading voters to call for change.

Mighty, an environmental lobby group, accuses Singapore-based commodities trader Olam—and by extension its majority stakeholder Temasek—of tolerating questionable palm oil sourcing and contributing to harmful slash-and-burn practices linked to annual haze in Southeast Asia. Both Olam and Temasek reject the allegations. 

Olam, which buys 99% of its palm oil from third parties, only recently disclosed its supplier list and maintains that it strictly enforces a “no burn-no peat-no deforestation” policy. However, Mighty argues Olam has created a “secretive market” for palm oil from unknown or “rogue” producers and that Temasek’s investment ties Singapore to potential environmental damage. The report also raises concerns about Olam’s operations in Gabon, alleging that the firm bulldozes rainforests to expand plantations. Olam refutes this, saying its joint ventures in Gabon follow responsible agricultural practices and are transparent. The passage highlights the larger problem of unsustainable practices throughout the global palm oil industry, with NGOs calling for stricter enforcement to curb environmental harm.

A restaurant began serving puppy platters following the introduction of a new law permitting dogs to dine at restaurants, as long as they remain outdoors. The passage highlights how the initiative looks like a “dog’s dinner,” inviting viewers to watch the accompanying clip.

Fernando Forestieri is doubtful with a knee injury, having only featured as a substitute in the past two matches. David Nugent could return after missing the Huddersfield match due to a groin problem, and Jacob Butterfield hopes for a starting place following his late equalizer in that game.

Pakistan lifted its YouTube ban after Google launched a Pakistani version of the platform. While many Pakistanis welcomed the move, activists demanded more transparency over the agreement between Google and the government. Authorities stated they can request YouTube to block specific content deemed offensive within Pakistan, but YouTube emphasized it only removes or restricts videos after reviewing potential violations of its guidelines or local laws. The original ban, imposed in 2012 following the controversial film "Innocence of Muslims," sparked protests in Pakistan that resulted in more than a dozen deaths. Google also introduced local YouTube versions for Nepal and Sri Lanka alongside Pakistan.

Domenico Scala, head of Fifa’s Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee and a Swiss-Italian national, previously withdrew from handling the 2015 elections due to sharing Swiss nationality with then-incumbent Sepp Blatter. Now, Liberian FA President Musa Bility is demanding Scala again step aside, citing a conflict of interest because one of the current candidates—Gianni Infantino—is also Swiss-Italian. Bility threatens to appeal to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not step down. However, Scala’s representative insists there is no conflict this time because none of the current five candidates is an incumbent. Bility, who was barred from running in this election, has pledged his support to Prince Ali, while the other candidates are Jerome Champagne, Sheikh Salman, and Tokyo Sexwale. The election is scheduled for 26 February in Zurich.

Two men, 29-year-old Daniel Timbers and 56-year-old Barry Joy, were killed on Monday morning at Harford Attachments in Spar Road while working in a paint-spraying area. A forensic search indicated a flashover explosion caused by a build-up of toxic fumes and an ignition source. Their bodies were removed on Tuesday afternoon. The Health and Safety Executive, along with forensic investigators, is gathering evidence and conducting inquiries into the incident.

Tunisia risked being barred from the 2017 Nations Cup after a dispute with Caf over refereeing decisions in their 2015 quarter-final defeat to hosts Equatorial Guinea, but they ultimately stayed in by apologizing for their complaints. Morocco initially faced a ban after withdrawing from hosting the 2015 tournament because of Ebola fears, but Cas overturned Caf’s ruling and reduced their fine, allowing them to enter the 2017 qualifiers. Both countries have now reconciled with Caf—Tunisia’s letter never formally accused anyone of corruption, and Morocco’s football officials spoke of minimal fallout from their absence. Following the 2017 qualifying draw, Tunisia will meet Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti, while Morocco faces Cape Verde, Libya, and Sao Tome, with Tunisia poised for a record-thirteenth consecutive Nations Cup appearance if they qualify.

Manchester City's Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho were both sent off in a mass fracas during their 3-1 loss to Chelsea at Etihad Stadium. Aguero received a four-match ban for his high, late challenge on David Luiz—his second dismissal for violent conduct this season—while Fernandinho was banned for three matches after clashing with Cesc Fabregas. Fabregas faces no further action. City manager Pep Guardiola apologized for his team's conduct, and both clubs have until 18:00 GMT on 8 December to respond to the charge.

Wales has some of the poorest cancer survival rates in the developed world. A new six-month pilot scheme in Cwm Cynon and Neath aims to diagnose patients more quickly if GPs suspect cancer but symptoms are not clearly urgent. This approach follows a visit by Welsh doctors to Denmark, where diagnostic centres have helped improve survival rates. 

Under the pilot, GPs who suspect something is wrong can refer patients to a diagnostic centre within seven days, with several tests arranged for the same day. Currently, only around 35% of patients in Cwm Taf with concerning symptoms receive a prompt diagnosis. The new pathway hopes to identify and treat patients earlier, before their cancer has advanced. If successful, the service will be rolled out across local health boards in coming months.

England leveled the series with a dominant victory over Pakistan at Old Trafford, setting up their second-largest run-margin win against them. Joe Root, promoted to number three, anchored England’s performance with 254 in the first innings and a rapid 71 not out in the second, earning man-of-the-match honors. England’s captain Alastair Cook praised Root’s controlled batting, while coach Trevor Bayliss commended his response to earlier dismissals. Pakistan struggled with the bat, showing limited resistance in both innings. Former England players Michael Vaughan and Geoffrey Boycott noted England’s discipline and Pakistan’s broken spirit; however, Vaughan expects a tight series. Pakistan captain Misbah-ul-Haq admitted confidence was low but remains hopeful ahead of the third Test at Edgbaston.

Warren Gatland, currently leading the British and Irish Lions in New Zealand, has named Rob Howley to his backroom staff. While Gatland is away, forwards coach Robin McBryde will become Wales head coach for the third time, having led tours in 2009 and 2013. The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) plans to appoint further assistant coaches for this summer’s tour. WRU chief executive Martyn Phillips hopes to finalize the full coaching team soon. Union chairman Gareth Davies, who is also on the Lions’ selection panel, expects these different roles to strengthen Welsh rugby. He views the 2017 summer tours as an opportunity to develop Welsh coaches and credits past Lions campaigns with invigorating both coaches and players.

Hull took an early blow when they lost both starting strikers to injury after Charlie Austin’s sixth-minute penalty put Southampton ahead. However, substitute Robert Snodgrass transformed the match in the second half, first scoring an equalizer and then providing the free-kick assist for Michael Dawson’s decisive header. David Marshall’s goalkeeping heroics and Sam Clucas’s last-minute goalline clearance helped Hull secure a 2–1 victory— their first league win since 20 August—ending a six-game losing streak. Southampton, fresh from a Europa League triumph, were undone by a lack of urgency and concentration, leaving manager Claude Puel frustrated. Hull boss Mike Phelan praised his side’s resilience, especially given the injuries and recent poor form, as they head into the international break still in the bottom three.

A motorcyclist was killed following a collision with a tractor at about 14:15 BST on the B1191 in Thornton, near Woodhall Spa. The motorcyclist was local, though no further personal details were released. The tractor driver was uninjured. Lincolnshire Police are appealing for witnesses, and the B1191 was closed in both directions between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction in Woodhall Spa and the A158 Jubilee Way junction in Horncastle.
