Macedonia’s President Ivanov cancelled an investigation into alleged abuses of power revealed by covert recordings, aiming to end the political crisis before early elections. This decision was condemned by both the opposition, led by Zoran Zaev, and EU officials, who warned it jeopardized Macedonia’s EU membership ambitions. The covert recordings, released since 2015, allegedly show government involvement in vote-rigging, cover-ups of killings, and mass wiretapping. While Zaev accuses the government of widespread corruption and abuse, officials deny these claims and insist Zaev is trying to destabilize the country. Protests broke out in the capital following the president’s announcement.

Swansea’s caretaker boss Alan Curtis, supported by Paul Williams, has stepped in after Bob Bradley’s sacking ahead of the match against Bournemouth. Former Derby manager Paul Clement is the preferred candidate to take charge on a permanent basis. Curtis expresses concern about relegation, warning it would be difficult to bounce back if Swansea drop into the Championship. He reflects on the club’s impressive rise to the Premier League in 2011—after coming close to bankruptcy almost a decade earlier—and believes a key reason for their troubles is the repeated managerial changes following Michael Laudrup’s departure in 2014. Curtis also cites a loss of the “Swansea Way” and questions whether departing players have been adequately replaced. Despite these issues, he feels the current squad can survive, emphasizing that new signings understand the club’s journey, in part through the documentary “Jack to a King,” and appreciate the importance of remaining in the Premier League.

Dagenham & Redbridge’s 3-2 defeat to Leyton Orient confirmed their relegation to the National League, ending a nine-year stay in the Football League. They struggled at both ends of the pitch this season, with the worst goal difference in League Two and fewer goals from key striker Jamie Cureton. Manager John Still, who led the club into League One in 2010, remains committed to guiding them back up next year. Orient’s victory, under interim manager Andy Hessenthaler following the removal of Kevin Nolan from his managerial role, keeps their play-off hopes alive, leaving them two points outside the top seven.

Steven Gerrard, the former Liverpool and England captain, will begin his post-playing career in February as a youth coach at his old club—his first role since retiring. Manager Jürgen Klopp welcomed the appointment, noting Gerrard’s ambition to become a manager in the future and praising his readiness to learn. Gerrard joined Liverpool in 1998, won multiple major trophies (including the Champions League), and finished his playing career at LA Galaxy before retiring in November. Though he was linked with the manager’s job at MK Dons, he felt it was too soon. He is currently working toward his UEFA A coaching license to continue pursuing a managerial career.

Morton took an early lead through McManus and a deflected Forbes strike, Alloa pulled one back via McAusland before half-time, but a second McManus goal and a late Johnstone finish secured a comfortable victory for Morton.

Ofsted has shut down three Birmingham institutions found teaching children in squalid conditions and believes this is only the “tip of the iceberg.” Those running unregistered schools can face up to 51 weeks in jail. Current law requires any place teaching children more than 20 hours a week to register as a school, but there are concerns some operators are exploiting home-education rules by labeling themselves as part-time or “flexi” schools. Ministers are consulting on tighter regulations for those teaching more than six to eight hours weekly. Ofsted’s Chief Inspector, Sir Michael Wilshaw, revealed inspectors were alarmed by unsafe environments and risk of radicalization or abuse; he also criticized officials for providing confusing advice to the shuttered schools. The government is funding a new six-inspector team at Ofsted to investigate such illegal schools, regardless of religious affiliation, and has asked Ofsted to prepare prosecutions against them. A formal consultation on stronger oversight is underway until mid-January.

Lilliard Gin, located at the Born in the Borders visitor center in Jedburgh, has launched alongside proposals to establish the region’s first whisky distillery since 1837. Lead distiller Kate Macinnes highlights the gin’s small-scale production, which takes place in a converted cowshed, and its focus on using local botanicals from the Teviot valley to capture the Scottish Borders’ distinct flavor. John Henderson of Born in the Borders praises the synergy between the new gin distillery and the existing brewery on-site. The name “Lilliard” is inspired by a legendary local heroine of the 1545 Battle of Ancrum Moor, underscoring both the area’s history and the distillery’s strong female production team.

Harry Whitlam died in August 2013 at Swithens Farm near Leeds after being reversed into by Gary Green, who was over twice the legal alcohol limit at the time. The incident occurred on private land, so Green was prosecuted under health and safety legislation rather than road traffic law. He admitted failing to ensure others’ safety and was jailed for 16 months and two weeks. An investigation found Harry was walking toward a worker in a closed-off area of the farm when Green backed the tractor into him. Harry’s mother, Pam, described how the loss had profoundly changed their close-knit family and hoped people would remember her son’s life beyond the day of the accident. The Health and Safety Executive called Green’s behavior “reckless.”

Luis Suarez’s ban from all football‐related activity for biting Giorgio Chiellini has been partially reduced by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS). He still cannot play in competitive matches for club or country until late October but is now allowed to train, appear in friendlies, attend matches, and take part in promotional activities. The CAS felt a complete ban was “excessive,” although it largely upheld FIFA’s original sanctions, including Suarez’s remaining eight‐match international ban and the prohibition from competitive Barcelona matches until late October. Suarez’s legal team argued that FIFA had misapplied its own rules and that the punishment was disproportionate. While CAS’s decision means he remains unavailable for official fixtures, Suarez will be able to prepare with Barcelona and represent Uruguay in upcoming friendlies. Critics, such as world players’ union Fifpro, remain disappointed by the severity of the ban. Suarez has faced previous bans for biting and racism.

Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won a 380-meter obstacle race—featuring haystacks, a steep slope, and water pistols—against strong competition from Lithuanian rivals. Although often referred to as a “wife-carrying” contest, participants need not be married, and the race attracted various carrying combinations. After just a week of dedicated training, Richard and Anna’s victory secured them a spot at the World Championships in Finland in July.

Stephen Hammond confirmed that from October, paper car tax discs will be replaced by an electronic system, including the option to pay by monthly direct debit. He acknowledged this would naturally reduce the number of refunds processed and mean changes to some job roles at the DVLA, but insisted any staffing adjustments would be handled through redeployment rather than redundancies. Swansea East AM Mike Hedges, who had asked the minister for reassurance, welcomed the commitment that DVLA workers would be trained for new processes instead of facing job losses, and expressed support for the convenience of the planned electronic payments.

Hungary’s foreign minister insists the EU should not interfere with what he views as domestic matters, including recent legislation on asylum seekers, NGOs, and higher education. He maintains Hungary will not backtrack on those laws, citing Polish support in vetoing any EU move to strip Hungary of its voting rights. Critics fear the higher education law could force the closure of the Central European University, and new NGO legislation may stigmatize groups as “foreign-backed.” Hungary’s practice of housing asylum seekers in secured containers also raises compatibility concerns with EU law. Despite ongoing protests in Hungary and pressure from European institutions, the government remains firm, while EU officials warn of possible sanctions if there is no change.

In this live-action remake of “Beauty and the Beast,” an Oscar-winning star will portray Mrs. Potts—originally voiced by Angela Lansbury in the 1991 animated film—while fellow Oscar-winner Kevin Kline plays Belle’s father Maurice. Emma Watson stars as Belle, with Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, and Josh Gad as Gaston’s sidekick LeFou. Bill Condon directs, with filming beginning at Shepperton Studios in May, and a U.S. release date set for 17 March 2017.

Adrian Gill was a long-serving Sunday Times columnist, celebrated for his witty and fearless writing style and known for dictating his copy due to dyslexia. Diagnosed with multiple cancers—what he termed the “full English”—he approached his illness with stoicism and gratitude. Gill died suddenly, prompting tributes from colleagues and fellow writers who regarded him as a giant of journalism. Though widely admired, his articles often sparked controversy: he once described shooting a baboon, made offensive comments about the Welsh, and was censured for calling Clare Balding a “dyke on a bike.” Born in Edinburgh in 1954, Gill studied art before transitioning to journalism in the 1980s; he wrote for Tatler and, from 1993, for the Sunday Times. He was married twice—including to Amber Rudd—and became engaged to his long-term partner, Nicola Formby, shortly before his death.

Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, a Mongolian rapper, was allegedly beaten by a Russian diplomat during a performance in Ulan Bator while wearing a traditional Mongolian robe bearing an ancient swastika symbol. Though the swastika is sometimes linked with Nazis, in Mongolia it is traditionally seen as a sign of eternity. Sukhbaatar was reportedly struck with a metal object, kicked in the face, and spent around 10 days in a coma. Both his father and lawyer deny that Sukhbaatar used Nazi slogans on stage. Mongolian authorities say the Russian suspect was not detained because the injuries were not deemed serious, and the Russian embassy claims media reports about the incident are distorted. The case remains under investigation.

Campaigners from the group Plane Stupid held a protest early Monday on the airport’s northern runway to oppose expansion plans. They have been charged with aggravated trespass and entering a security-restricted aerodrome area, and will appear in court on 19 August. Following the incident, which took place at 03:30 BST, the Metropolitan Police announced that airport security procedures would be reviewed.

Nick Selman anchored Glamorgan’s innings with a measured 101 off 144 balls—his second first-class century—after a lucky reprieve when dropped on eight. Despite his efforts, Gloucestershire’s seamers, notably Matt Taylor (who hit the stumps three times) and Craig Miles, made frequent inroads in overcast conditions, restricting Glamorgan to 220. Aneurin Donald contributed a brisk 36, while Graham Wagg and Timm van der Gugten eked out a bonus point for Glamorgan.

Gloucestershire then faced a testing period of batting in the evening gloom, leaving the contest balanced at the close. Glamorgan were captained by Michael Hogan in place of the injured Jacques Rudolph. Selman expressed relief at his return to form following a series of low scores after his century at Swansea, emphasizing the challenges of opening on seamer-friendly pitches. From Gloucestershire’s perspective, Taylor was pleased with his performance, highlighting the assistance on offer for bowlers and appreciative of extended opportunities in both white-ball and red-ball formats. The day ended with both teams still vying for control.

Craig Hughes, aged 33 from Flint, was arrested in August after making threats in online chats with a crisis center in Tennessee, indicating he intended to falsely report a crime so that responding police officers could be ambushed and shot on the Dee Estuary. He admitted two charges at Mold Crown Court and is awaiting sentencing. The threats were made late at night while he was drunk. Hughes had a prior firearm conviction from 2009. Police were particularly concerned as he was on bail for firearms offenses at the time, though he was later cleared of those. His legal team stated he neither planned to kill himself nor actually intended to carry out any threats against the police. The Hope Line Crisis Centre offers confidential support to people in distress.

Surrey recovered from 8-2 to post 255-7, largely through a 130-run partnership between Steven Davies and Ben Foakes (90). Yorkshire’s pursuit faltered when Stuart Meaker took three wickets in nine balls—dismissing Bairstow, Ballance, and Leaning—and although Bresnan (68) and Waite (38) rallied, Yorkshire were bowled out for 236. Surrey captain Gareth Batty praised the decisive Davies-Foakes partnership and Meaker’s timely strikes, while Yorkshire skipper Alex Lees lamented the lack of a big top-order contribution in a reachable chase.

A 56ft converted trawler became distressed six miles west of South Stack at 07:00 BST due to incoming water that overwhelmed its onboard pump. The RNLI lifeboat crew provided an additional pump and then towed the vessel to Holyhead.

Scottish middle-distance runner Laura Muir will miss the 2018 Commonwealth Games in Australia because they clash with her veterinary medicine exams. Despite finishing fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships, Muir has prioritized completing her final year of studies in May. She remains hopeful of competing at the World Indoor Championships in March and is looking ahead to future Olympic opportunities. Muir expressed disappointment at missing the chance to represent Scotland but remains confident the Scottish team will perform well. She set a new outdoor personal best (14:52.07) in the 5,000m at the World Championships, a race won by Hellen Obiri ahead of Almaz Ayana.

Robbie Savage argues that Liverpool have fallen well short of last season’s title-contending form, in part because they lost the prolific Suarez-Sturridge strike partnership and failed to recruit suitable replacements. Their defense, muddled by inconsistent personnel changes, remains no better than before. Savage believes that Champions League qualification alone would mark genuine success for manager Brendan Rodgers—though some fans remain dissatisfied. He proposes a line-up favoring more energy and pressing, including Fabio Borini up front for his work-rate, and criticizes Dejan Lovren’s performances. Savage also discusses Steven Gerrard’s ongoing importance to the team, acknowledging the mental and physical challenges he faces at age 34, but maintaining that he still has much to offer despite the lingering pain from last season’s costly slip against Chelsea.

A £45m campus will be built in Kilmarnock’s Sutherland Drive, bringing together primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare centre. East Ayrshire Council plans to seek permission from the McIlvanney family to name the complex in honor of William McIlvanney, a renowned Kilmarnock-born writer who was passionate about education. McIlvanney, known as the “Godfather of Tartan Noir,” gained recognition with his first novel, “Remedy Is None,” and wrote the celebrated “Laidlaw” trilogy among other works. He was also a poet, journalist, and broadcaster, contributing to political and sporting life in Scotland. McIlvanney died on December 5 at his Glasgow home.

Authorities evacuated three streets near a swimming pool in Gourock after a suspected British sea mine from the 1940s or 1950s was discovered on Monday. Residents within 500m of the device were advised to open windows, stay indoors, and avoid going outside, while a half-mile exclusion zone at sea halted small boat operations and caused some ferry disruptions. Although there was no immediate danger, experts decided to move the deteriorated mine to a safer location to assess its explosives. Local officials praised residents and businesses for their cooperation throughout the precautionary measures.

UK Sport will invest £345m in 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports for Tokyo 2020—£2m less than the Rio 2016 cycle. Despite Team GB’s successful 2016 performance, funding for badminton has been fully withdrawn, leading to criticism from Badminton England. Other affected sports include archery, fencing, weightlifting, and wheelchair rugby, while cycling sees its budget reduced by over £4m. Meanwhile, judo—also winning a single Rio bronze—receives a slight increase. UK Sport defends the cuts by emphasizing a need to prioritize medal potential, setting targets of 51-85 Olympic medals and 115-162 Paralympic medals.

Team sports like basketball, handball, and volleyball remain unfunded and criticize UK Sport’s reluctance to support their performance pathways. Additionally, £9m of the total budget is reserved for newly added Olympic and Paralympic sports—baseball/softball, karate, skateboard, sports climbing, surfing, Para-taekwondo, and Para-badminton—pending further evaluation of their medal prospects.

Councillors voted 7–3 in favor of demolishing three Victorian hotels on East Cliff in Bournemouth—Bay View Court, The Cottonwood, and The Ocean View—to build a six-storey, four-star, 90-room hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks (one nine storeys and one seven storeys, totaling 122 apartments). English Heritage objected that the development’s scale would severely harm the designated conservation area. Despite acknowledging the hotels’ historic appeal, planning board chair David Kelsey argued they were no longer functional and emphasized the need to move forward for tourism and senior living. The council received 246 letters in support and 49 objections alongside opposition from the Ancient Monuments Society.

Private Matthew Boyd, a 20-year-old soldier from the Royal Gibraltar Regiment, was fatally attacked by 24-year-old Jake Vallely in Brecon after a night out. Boyd, originally from Carrickfergus, County Antrim, had been in the area for training when Vallely, under the influence of alcohol and boasting he was “the hardest man in Brecon,” punched and beat him outside The Cellar bar. Boyd’s body was dragged from the scene before Vallely fled. Co-accused Aaeron Evans was cleared of manslaughter, as he was not present for the violence. Vallely is due to be sentenced on December 8. Boyd’s family tribute described him as a loving and loyal all-rounder with a promising career, and they lamented the void created by his death. The attack was called “despicable” by local authorities, who urged people to walk away from potential violence.

Andrew Travers, Barnet Council's chief executive, left by mutual agreement following a major error in which voters were turned away from all 155 polling stations due to missing names on the register. An independent investigation is underway, with Deputy Chief Executive John Hooton stepping in temporarily. Barnet Council apologized for the incident, offered emergency proxy votes, and acknowledged concerns about the fairness of the outcome. Travers attributed the disturbance to electoral registration lists, and the review’s findings—expected by the end of May—will be presented publicly, also assessing preparations for the upcoming EU Referendum in June.

Gateshead took an early lead when Josh Gillies scored from a free-kick, only for Sean Newton to equalize with another set-piece before halftime. The winner came in the second half when Ryan Bowman headed in Craig Baxter’s cross. Gateshead manager Malcolm Crosby praised his team’s improved passing after the break and described Bowman’s goal as “wonderful.” Wrexham manager Gary Mills expressed disappointment over missed chances and a weaker second-half display. The match ended 2–1 in Gateshead’s favor.

The passage describes the Global AgeWatch Index 2014, which measures the social and economic welfare of people over 60 in 96 countries. Norway ranks at the top of the index, while Afghanistan is the worst-performing country, followed by Mozambique.

Airbus and OneWeb are collaborating to launch a global broadband satellite constellation—initially 600 spacecraft, potentially growing to over 2,000—aimed at providing affordable internet worldwide, including schools. Building so many satellites demands a new manufacturing approach, using automobile-style assembly lines to produce units quickly at under a million dollars each. Airbus opened its first line in Toulouse and will establish more in Florida. 

The plan involves more than 20 Soyuz rocket launches, each placing 32–36 satellites into orbit; about 300 satellites should be operational by late 2020 or early 2021, 600 a year later, and 800 by mid-decade. OneWeb—which has raised US$1.7 billion—faces competition from other mega-constellation proposals (SpaceX, Boeing, ViaSat), but Airbus believes it has a first-mover advantage.

OneWeb is registered in the UK’s Channel Islands and must work with the UK Space Agency on licensing. The firm has committed to strict debris mitigation: satellites will be de-orbited within two years using additional hardware, and each satellite will carry an adapter so a “chase vehicle” can drag failed units out of orbit. Airbus hopes these high-volume, lower-cost production techniques may eventually serve other satellite customers as well.

Scotland’s Finance Secretary, John Swinney, contends that the UK government’s recent spending review places “unprecedented pressure” on Scotland’s budget, pointing to a 12.5% real-terms reduction in the Scottish government’s discretionary budget from 2010–11 to 2019–20, with 4.2% of that yet to come. Although the UK government asserts that Scotland will have £390m more spending available next year (increasing to £750m with underspend), Mr Swinney argues the cuts could have been avoided. He pledges to protect core services—schools, hospitals, and policing—from the “chancellor’s austerity obsession.” The UK government counters that Scotland benefits from a £30bn block grant, citing low oil prices as evidence of the advantages of remaining within the UK. Labour’s Jackie Baillie challenges Mr Swinney to back up his “anti-austerity posturing” with a long-term budget strategy and different tax decisions from both the Conservatives and the SNP.

Many people with severe disabilities require toilets equipped with additional space, hoists, and benches—known as “Changing Places” facilities—to meet their needs. However, these amenities are currently only recommended, not compulsory, leaving families stressed and often forced to change loved ones on dirty floors or in cars when no suitable facility is available. Campaigners, including parents like Lorna and Alison, have shared firsthand accounts of the physical and emotional strain this causes. Although there are nearly 900 Changing Places toilets across the UK, advocates urge legislation to mandate them in newly built large venues such as shopping centers, cinemas, and sports stadiums. Examples of successful installations, like those at Cardiff’s Principality Stadium and Arsenal Football Club, demonstrate the benefits not only for visitors with disabilities but also for businesses looking to welcome a broader range of customers.

Italian consumer groups have filed a formal antitrust complaint with the European Commission against McDonald’s, alleging that the company charges franchisees excessive rents and fees, and binds them to longer-than-average contracts, limiting their ability to switch to other brands. The high costs, they claim, lead to reduced consumer choice and higher prices in franchised outlets. Supported by the Service Employees International Union and other workers’ unions, the complaint calls on the Commission to investigate McDonald’s. McDonald’s denies any wrongdoing, stating that it shares both risks and rewards with its franchisees and that its approach has provided good business opportunities and customer experiences. The European Commission will examine the allegations and may launch an investigation. Franchisees own 73% of McDonald’s restaurants in Europe, and McDonald’s received US$9.27 billion worldwide from franchised restaurants in 2014.

Joshua Martin, a 13-year-old from Donaghadee, County Down, was unexpectedly diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve. Originally set to have an appendix operation, doctors instead removed a large primary growth and five smaller tumors. In response, Bangor Elim Church, where Josh’s father works, launched #prayforjosh on social media to rally support. This hashtag quickly went viral, garnering tens of thousands of views worldwide and prompting classmates and strangers alike to share messages of encouragement. A mystery donor even sponsored a billboard featuring #prayforjosh in Holywood, symbolizing the extensive global backing for Josh and his family as he continues his recovery.

The UK government plans to close Brecon Barracks, part of a broader reorganization of military sites in Wales. Conservative MP Chris Davies strongly opposes the closure, emphasizing the barracks’ historical significance—dating back to 1805 and linked to soldiers who fought at Rorke’s Drift—and raising concerns about economic impact and respect for local heritage. He vows to fight the decision and has started a petition, although it is believed current civilian and military jobs will not be at risk. Nearby Sennybridge training facilities remain unaffected. Defence Secretary Sir Michael Fallon announced a new light infantry centre at St Athan and confirmed eventual closures of Cawdor Barracks in 2024 and a Sennybridge storage depot in 2025. Labour’s Shadow Defence Secretary Nia Griffith acknowledged the need to restructure but cautioned about the uncertainty facing communities around these bases.

Britain’s fishing industry, despite representing only a small fraction of the country’s economy, faces significant opportunities and risks as part of Brexit negotiations. The House of Lords EU Committee warns that UK fishing interests risk being sidelined, and that any deal securing tariff-free access to the European market may require allowing EU boats continued access to UK waters. While fishing communities see Brexit as a chance to regain control over their 200-mile exclusive economic zone, the report highlights the need for cooperation on shared fish stocks, retention of scientific quotas, and awareness that different UK regions could adopt varying management regimes. Nonetheless, industry representatives remain optimistic, viewing Brexit as a potential catalyst for fairer quotas and better fisheries management.

Edward Snowden, a former CIA technical worker, publicly identified himself as the source of leaked documents showing that the US National Security Agency (NSA) conducts large-scale surveillance of digital communications and phone records. The revelations indicate that the NSA can gather data such as individual chat logs, stored files, call details, and social networking information, largely through an initiative known as Prism, which allegedly grants access to servers of major tech companies—though how Prism actually operates remains unclear. 

US authorities, including the NSA’s director and President Barack Obama, have defended the surveillance as essential for national security and counterterrorism. However, companies named in the leaks deny knowingly participating, and privacy advocates argue that such measures violate personal privacy. The leaks also highlight how data protection laws differ between countries, yet US legislation (such as the Patriot Act and the FISA Amendments Act) may allow American authorities to access data stored on US-based servers, even if the users live elsewhere. European officials have expressed concern, requesting more information on potential impacts to EU citizens. Snowden, citing privacy concerns, said he acted to alert the public to the extent of government monitoring.

OpenAI is a new venture backed by prominent figures such as Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, Infosys, and Amazon Web Services. Its mission is to advance artificial intelligence in a way that benefits humanity, without the pressure to generate profit. Concerns about AI posing a threat to human existence have been raised by Elon Musk and Stephen Hawking, though other experts believe such risks remain distant. OpenAI’s stated goal is to ensure AI serves as an extension of human will and is broadly accessible. While $1 billion has been pledged, only a small fraction is expected to be used in the near term.

Ben Parkinson, a soldier seriously injured in a 2006 Afghanistan bomb attack, carried the Olympic torch on 26 June. Despite enduring a severe brain injury (which initially took his speech) and extensive physical challenges, he has persevered, now speaking unaided and walking with crutches. After carrying the torch, he received an overwhelming surge of Facebook friend requests—far exceeding the 5,000 limit—leaving many people unable to connect directly. Ben devotes 12 hours a day to gym work and rehabilitation, raises funds for military charities, and serves as a patron for Pilgrim Bandits. His mother reports that his popularity and messages of support have been “phenomenal,” with thousands of people joining Pilgrim Bandits and his own Facebook page receiving over 19,000 hits. Facebook suggests he create a public page or use its “subscribe” feature. Ben’s story underscores his remarkable recovery, dedication to charitable causes, and the huge public response following his torch-bearing role.

In 2011, the US poverty rate held at 15% (46.2 million people), following three prior years of increases. Real median household income declined by 1.5%, while the average poverty threshold for a family of four stood at $23,021. Income inequality rose by 1.6% (its first annual increase since 1993), and the uninsured rate dropped from 16.3% to 15.7%. Poverty had reached a record high of 15.1% in 2010.

Jos Buttler, a 25-year-old short-format specialist, joined Lancashire (the “Red Rose”) in 2013 and has extended his contract with the club until 2019. He is known for scoring England’s three fastest ODI centuries, including a 46-ball ton against Pakistan. Cricket director Ashley Giles praised Buttler’s talent and influence on Lancashire’s T20 Blast victory, noting his international experience and positive impact in the dressing room. Currently playing in the IPL with Mumbai Indians, Buttler is set to return for Lancashire’s T20 Blast match against Durham.

The four former Devonport-based Type 22 frigates (HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham, and HMS Cornwall) are now moored in Portsmouth Harbour and open for bids. While no proposals to preserve them have been submitted, interested parties are finalizing offers, with viewings scheduled for late February and March and a decision expected in the spring.  
The UK’s Disposal Services Authority intends for at least one frigate to be recycled in the UK to assess domestic ship-recycling capacity. Conservative MP Penny Mordaunt supports giving UK recyclers the opportunity to prove themselves and suggests preserving at least one frigate as a diving attraction to generate tourist income. The Ministry of Defence says all options remain under consideration to ensure the best financial outcome. Originally designed for anti-submarine warfare, Type 22 frigates evolved into versatile surface combatants with extensive weapons, command, and control systems. Last year, the aircraft carrier HMS Ark Royal sold for scrap at £3m.

Fiji has experienced repeated coups since 1987, sparking ongoing racial and political instability. In 1987, indigenous Fijians overthrew an Indian-dominated government, triggering the introduction—and later withdrawal—of a constitution favoring indigenous supremacy. A subsequent coup in 2000, led by George Speight, involved the hostage-taking of the first ethnic Indian prime minister and others, damaging Fiji’s economy and global reputation. Continued tensions culminated in a 2006 military takeover, and in 2009 Fiji was suspended from the Commonwealth for its lack of progress toward democracy. After agreeing to hold 2014 elections, Fiji was reinstated. 

The population is largely split between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians (descendants of Indian indentured laborers). Though they were once roughly equal in number, political upheavals prompted many Indo-Fijians to emigrate, leaving indigenous Fijians in the majority. Social mixing remains limited. Beyond sugar and tourism, Fiji’s economy also includes mining, services, and light manufacturing, but persistent trade and budget deficits have made it a significant per capita aid recipient.

Syrian Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad insists his government is committed to meeting its obligations on destroying its chemical weapons, despite missing a recent deadline and only removing about 4% of the stockpile so far. He blames attacks by rebel groups for delays in transporting weapons to Latakia, while emphasizing Syria is at war and requires international understanding. US officials express concern about the slow pace of removal, and Russia calls for completing transfers by 1 March to make the end-of-June destruction timetable feasible. Meanwhile, Syria faces allegations of using barrel bombs against civilians in Aleppo, causing hundreds of casualties, which the government denies. Conflicting reports also emerge on rebel forces supposedly seizing Aleppo’s central prison, with government media rejecting the claim and activist groups insisting the prison has fallen under rebel control.

This passage describes the 2014 Booker Prize shortlist—its first year open to all English-language authors regardless of nationality—announced for the 46th year of the prize. Six novels are selected: Neel Mukherjee’s The Lives of Others (the betting favorite), Howard Jacobson’s J (Jacobson having previously won in 2010), Ali Smith’s How To Be Both, Joshua Ferris’s To Rise Again at a Decent Hour, Karen Joy Fowler’s We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves, and Richard Flanagan’s The Narrow Road to the Deep North. Fowler’s novel is noted as the best-selling among them; Mukherjee’s has seen a post-shortlist sales surge. There is critical debate about whether the list is “weak” and about awarding Jacobson a second win soon after Hilary Mantel’s two-time victory. The judging panel is chaired by AC Grayling, and last year’s winner was Eleanor Catton for The Luminaries. The winner is to be announced at London’s Guildhall, with each shortlisted author receiving £2,500 and a specially bound edition of their book.

A celebrity referred to as “PJS” is seeking to maintain an injunction preventing media in England and Wales from publishing details of alleged extra-marital activities. After an appeal court lifted the ban, PJS took the case to the Supreme Court, which will decide whether to allow and rule on the appeal. Until then, an interim ban remains in place. The Court of Appeal previously noted stories had spread online and in other jurisdictions, making complete confidentiality “probably lost,” and concluded PJS was unlikely to secure a permanent injunction. PJS contends he has a right to privacy, given he has young children and a spouse also in the public eye, while the Sun on Sunday argues that widespread publication elsewhere undermines the injunction.

Fosse Park, located near junction 21 of the M1, first opened in 1989 and was purchased in August for £345.5 million. The new owners are working with Blaby District Council on potential planning questions and plan to address parking, traffic congestion, and the appearance of the park’s units and common areas. Council leader Ernie White notes the park serves as a gateway from Blaby into the city, and Paul Clarke of Crown Estates emphasizes the goal of refreshing what he describes as a “tired” facility, improving the experience for visitors.

Disney’s live-action “Beauty and the Beast” faced controversy in Malaysia over a “gay moment” involving the character LeFou. The Malaysian Censorship Board (LPF) approved the film with a minor edit, but Disney delayed its release “for review.” Homosexual activity is illegal in Malaysia, though the tourism minister deemed a full ban “ridiculous.” The film was assigned a P13 rating, but no new release date has been set. Director Bill Condon cited LeFou’s struggle with feelings for Gaston, sparking criticism online, with many Malaysians labeling the censorship “stupid and laughable.”

Southampton City Council requires landlords renting to more than three unrelated people to obtain an HMO licence, which can cost up to £1,000; failure to comply may result in a fine of up to £20,000. Despite an estimated 1,500 unlicensed HMOs in the city, many landlords are deterred by the fees. Tenants often contact Shelter about eviction fears and poor conditions, issues linked to the broader shortage of affordable housing. Nationally, licensing applies to properties with three or more storeys housing five or more unrelated occupants. In Southampton, licences are required within specific designations—Bargate, Bevois, Portswood, Swaythling (from 2013) and Shirley Freemantle, Millbrook, and Bassett (from 2015). While most landlords comply, a small minority do not, leading so far to prosecutions against one firm and 13 individuals.

Acting Taoiseach Enda Kenny (Fine Gael) and Micheál Martin (Fianna Fáil) aim to avoid a second election. Fianna Fáil will facilitate a minority government but not support its overall programme. Water charges remain a central issue: Fianna Fáil wants them removed immediately, while Fine Gael sees a continued role for charges. A commission to examine the future of Irish Water is being discussed. Post-election, Fine Gael won 50 seats, Fianna Fáil 44, Sinn Féin 23, and Labour 7, leaving no party with a majority and no taoiseach yet elected.

The ferry Sorrento, en route to Valencia, caught fire near Mallorca, forcing passengers and crew to evacuate onto lifeboats. They were rescued by another ferry, the Puglia. At least three people were injured—one seriously—and airlifted to hospitals. The Sorrento, owned by Atlantica di Navigazione, was about 27 km off Mallorca when the fire started on a car deck for unknown reasons. Spanish authorities warned the ship may sink due to extensive damage, and psychologists were called to assist survivors arriving back in Palma de Mallorca. Initially, the captain did not see the need to abandon the vessel, but the spreading blaze prompted a full evacuation.

The passage describes concerns over duplicate voter registrations leading up to the June 2017 UK general election. The Electoral Commission found potentially high numbers of duplicate applications—estimated between 30% and 70% in some areas—partly because there is no direct link between local electoral registers and the online registration system. This caused large administrative and financial burdens for officials.

Although some individuals, particularly students, may register in more than one place and vote in local elections accordingly, voting twice in a general election is a criminal offence. While a record 46.8 million people were registered and turnout was at its highest since 1997, 38 MPs reported allegations of double voting. Hence, the Commission recommends integrating registers, introducing online checks to reduce the likelihood of duplicate entries, and requiring individuals registered at two addresses to confirm in advance which constituency they will vote in. Labour cautions against steps that might deter legitimate registrations by young people.

Lawrence Phillips, 40, was found dead on Wednesday in his prison cell, where officials believe he took his own life. Once a star football player at the University of Nebraska, he went on to play in the NFL for the St. Louis Rams, Miami Dolphins, and San Francisco 49ers but struggled with repeated legal and behavioral issues. Convicted of assault for driving his car into a group of teenagers and for assaulting a former girlfriend, Phillips was serving a sentence of more than 30 years. He had recently been placed in solitary confinement after being accused of killing his cellmate and was due to stand trial for that charge. Tom Osborne, his former coach, described Phillips as intelligent but unable to overcome his anger issues.

Private Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram officially classed as a soldier in the Mercian Regiment, was promoted to lance corporal during an event in Chester marking the regiment’s eighth anniversary. Awarded this honor by Brigadier Andrew Williams for good behavior, he is the 30th in a line of mascot rams dating back to the Indian Mutiny War in the mid-19th Century. Acquired by the old 95th (Derbyshire) Regiment of Foot in 1858, the “Private Derby” tradition continued when the Mercian Regiment formed in 2007. The current Lance Corporal Derby XXX joined in February 2014, has his own army number, receives pay for rations, and takes holidays during mating season on the Chatsworth Estate. His duties have included switching on Christmas lights in Ashbourne and meeting Prince William at a memorial unveiling for the 1914 Christmas Truce.

Liverpool produced a stunning 4-3 comeback win against Borussia Dortmund, echoing the club’s famous “Istanbul 2005” spirit. Under manager Jürgen Klopp—Dortmund’s former coach—the team transformed early doubts into belief, spurred by Anfield’s electric atmosphere and unrelenting fan support. Divock Origi’s emerging form and goals from Philippe Coutinho, Mamadou Sakho, and a last-gasp winner from Dejan Lovren capped the dramatic turnaround. Klopp’s emphasis on turning “doubters into believers” and refusing to concede mirrors his intense touchline presence, inspiring both players and supporters. Despite defensive frailties, Liverpool now look toward Europa League glory and a potential Champions League spot, with Klopp instilling his identity on the club in just six months—symbolized by his ban on touching the “This Is Anfield” sign until they have truly earned it.

The passage describes a meeting of the EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee, where UK Brexit Secretary David Davis proposed regular monthly meetings to share negotiation analysis with the devolved administrations of Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland. While Mr Davis emphasized collaboration and a “two-way information flow,” Scotland’s Minister Michael Russell criticized the lack of clarity on the UK government’s strategic intentions, particularly regarding single market and customs union membership—issues he deems crucial for Scotland’s economic prosperity. The passage also mentions the ongoing legal challenge related to the triggering of Article 50, with the Scottish government intending to oppose the UK government’s appeal in the Supreme Court.

Researchers at the University of Nottingham are closely monitoring 13 cloned sheep, including four (Daisy, Debbie, Denise, and Diane) cloned from the same adult ewe as Dolly, to investigate whether clones age normally. Dolly’s early death at six-and-a-half and her arthritis led to concerns about “age-memory” being carried into clones, meaning they could show signs of aging prematurely. To test this, the team, led by Professor Kevin Sinclair, conducts thorough examinations—checking joints, conducting X-rays, and doing fMRI scans—focusing on three key age-related conditions: cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and osteoarthritis. Although final study results are pending, the now nine- and ten-year-old cloned sheep so far appear healthy, potentially influencing future views on cloning safety.

Shutter Speed won York’s Musidora Stakes under soft conditions, beating Vintage Folly by one and three-quarter lengths. Trainer John Gosden will now aim her at the French Oaks at Chantilly, leaving stablemates Enable and Coronet to represent him in the longer Epsom Oaks. Tasleet claimed the Duke of York Stakes for William Haggas. Gosden, meanwhile, is wary of running his colt Cracksman in the Dante Stakes on soft ground, especially given the short 16-day gap before the Derby.

The passage describes sterling’s fluctuating value amid uncertainty about the upcoming Brexit referendum. Early in the day, the pound fell against the dollar, euro, and yen before briefly recovering, then dropping again. Market volatility reached highs similar to 2008, fueled by polls favoring the Leave campaign and reduced odds of a Remain vote. Analysts predict sterling will become more volatile if polls remain tight. Hedge funds have been short-selling the currency, and global markets—particularly in Asia—reacted negatively. Meanwhile, the FTSE 100 initially showed a muted response but ultimately closed down, with banking stocks notably affected. Leave campaigner Nigel Farage argued that recent currency shifts merely returned sterling to March levels and that a weaker pound could aid exporters; official data showed the UK trade deficit narrowed in April as exports rose.

Braintree Town, known as The Iron, sit sixth in the National League, just one point and position shy of the playoff places. Despite a challenging away trip and conceding an early goal in their loss to Barrow—who extended their unbeaten league run to nine matches—manager Danny Cowley remains positive. While acknowledging a third straight defeat and the difficulties of being a part-time team, he lauds the team’s achievements thus far as “remarkable,” emphasizes the toughness of their journey, and expresses determination to face the challenges ahead.

From April 2015, local councils in Northern Ireland will assume responsibility for most planning decisions—previously handled by the central Planning Service—giving elected politicians significant power over local development. Proponents see this as a chance for councils to shape their communities, with experts like Michael Corr arguing it allows for more democratic planning. However, concerns remain about potential favoritism and past discrimination, particularly referencing alleged bias in the 1960s. Environmental groups, such as Friends of the Earth, warn that rigorous codes of conduct and greater transparency—especially regarding political donations—will be crucial to ensure fairness. While some politicians oppose donor disclosure, citing security worries and relatively small donation amounts, the decision ultimately rests with the Northern Ireland Secretary, who can mandate greater openness in political funding.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie was found with three gunshot wounds, requiring the amputation of her back leg. Though “incredibly lucky” to survive, she is now relearning how to walk. The Scottish SPCA, along with Teenie’s owner, condemned the incident and urged anyone with information to come forward. This case renews debate around the Scottish government’s proposed air weapon licensing, intended to restrict ownership to those with a legitimate reason. While a government consultation sparked this proposal, 87% of respondents opposed it, with some calling it “draconian” and others arguing it did not go far enough.

Christian Benteke has joined Liverpool on a long-term contract, triggering a release clause to become the club’s seventh summer signing and second most expensive purchase. Formerly with Aston Villa, he scored 49 goals in 101 games after arriving from Genk in 2012. Benteke expressed excitement about competing for trophies and being part of Brendan Rodgers’ plans. 

Liverpool struggled for goals following Luis Suarez’s departure and Daniel Sturridge’s injuries, leading to limited returns from Mario Balotelli and Rickie Lambert. By signing Benteke—along with Danny Ings, Roberto Firmino, and the returning Divock Origi—Rodgers aims to revitalize Liverpool’s attack. Benteke overcame an Achilles injury that kept him out of the 2014 World Cup, helping Villa reach the FA Cup Final last season. Both former Villa manager Paul Lambert and ex-Liverpool striker John Aldridge predict Benteke will succeed at Anfield due to his strong physical presence and proven scoring ability.

The study finds tablet use growing rapidly in schools, with 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools using them in some way. In about 9% of schools, each pupil has an individual device, notably more common in academy schools than in independent or other state schools. While an increase in tablets is expected (from 430,000 in 2014 to 900,000 by 2016), the study concludes there is no definitive proof they boost academic results. However, school leaders report benefits: tablets can motivate disengaged students, involve families, and reflect how pupils already use technology at home. Another report indicates tablets support reading especially for boys and lower-income pupils. Despite uncertainties around measurable academic gains, schools such as Honywood Community School view technology’s role as essential for preparing students for today’s world, emphasizing portability, flexibility, and alignment with modern life.

“Growing Up in the City” at the Museum of Liverpool showcases 25 photographs depicting children’s lives across Liverpool from the 1880s to the 1990s. Curated by Kay Jones, the images reveal how childhood experiences have shifted over time, capturing both moments of play and the reality of child labor. The earliest photo, from 1887, shows the well-off Rollo children dressed for a fancy dress ball, while another highlights a young maid at work around 1900. Jones selected the final photographs from hundreds in the museum’s collection to reflect both the joyful and difficult aspects of growing up. The exhibition runs until 25 September.

Centre-back Myles Anderson, 27, has left Barrow by mutual consent to join another National League side. Previously with Aldershot, Exeter, and playing experience in Italy, he could face his former club on 18 February. Striker Ruairi Keating, 21, arrives after being recommended by Micky Adams, having played for Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps (pending international clearance). Torquay boss Kevin Nicholson views Anderson as a leader figure and Keating as a hungry, if raw, talent. The Gulls sit four points above the relegation zone and have won only once in their past six matches.

Bolivia has passed a law allowing children as young as 12 to work with parental permission. The legislation, signed by Vice-President Alvaro Garcia Linera, toughens penalties for violence against minors and imposes a 30-year jail term for child homicide. Despite international norms suggesting a higher minimum working age, the Bolivian government argues this law aligns better with the country’s economic realities, where over 500,000 children already work to help support their families. The International Labour Organisation is reviewing the legislation to determine if it conflicts with global child labor standards.

Rosie O’Donnell, aged 50, experienced a heart attack characterized by sudden nausea, aches, and chest pain. After researching women’s heart attack symptoms online and taking aspirin, she saw a cardiologist who found one of her arteries was 99 percent blocked and inserted a stent. She described this type of heart attack as the “widow maker” in her blog poem titled “my heart attack.” O’Donnell admitted she did not call emergency services but urged women to recognize and act on warning signs by calling 911. She had recently hosted The Rosie Show on the Oprah Winfrey Network, which was canceled in March due to low ratings.

Che Labastide-Wellington, a boy from Harrow, was fatally stabbed at a party in Belvedere Way, Kenton, following a dispute involving a group of youths who had attempted to enter the event. He was attacked around 00:30 GMT and died about an hour later. A second 16-year-old boy was also stabbed but is in stable condition. Police believe Che—who had been officially invited—was not part of the initial altercation but was specifically targeted later in an alleyway. Authorities are appealing for witnesses, particularly those near the alley between Belvedere Way and Tylers Gate. A 21-year-old man was arrested on suspicion of murder, along with two teenage boys (15 and 16) who were subsequently bailed. A 14-year-old boy is in custody on suspicion of possessing an offensive weapon.

Denmark introduced a three-route model to improve cancer diagnosis after alarming survival statistics showed long waits hindered early treatment. First, patients displaying clear “alarm” symptoms are fast-tracked to specialists under strict time targets. Second, newly established diagnosis centers quickly evaluate individuals with uncertain or difficult-to-diagnose symptoms, preventing repeated “ping pong” referrals between GPs and specialists. Third, “yes-no” centers offer rapid tests for those with minor symptoms, identifying the small percentage who do have serious illnesses and ensuring they receive timely treatment.

These changes did not overwhelm the Danish health system but reorganized existing resources. Better coordination between GPs and specialists has led to improved cancer survival rates, and Denmark’s performance is now catching up with neighboring Scandinavian countries. The Welsh delegation, noting Denmark’s similarity in health system funding and structure, highlights how such organizational reforms could benefit Wales by removing diagnostic barriers and accelerating patient pathways.

Powys Council will take over responsibilities previously held by the OFT for regulating estate agents, issuing warnings or banning orders when necessary. They won the government contract, worth £170,000 a year, through a competitive bidding process. Complaints about estate agents should still go to local trading standards departments, which will pursue prosecutions and refer cases to Powys if the Estate Agents Act is breached. James Munro of Powys Council leads the new team, hoping to demonstrate the council’s capacity for further external contracts.

NHS Employers, guided by a Nuffield Trust review, proposes expanding the roles of nurses and other staff to address shortages of junior doctors and GPs. Examples where nurses and pharmacists already support doctors show the potential of a reshaped workforce, especially for managing long-term conditions. However, unions caution that such measures should not be used as a quick or cheap fix, underscoring the need for proper training and funding. The British Medical Association similarly highlights that skilled doctors remain essential and lengthy medical training cannot simply be substituted. NHS Employers plans to use the report’s findings to inform workforce development.

Avon and Somerset Police closed the Lower Bristol Road in Bath at Rackfield Place following a crash at 03:00 GMT, causing significant disruption to commuters and bus services until the A36 reopened at 14:00 GMT. Investigations are ongoing. While parts of First’s bus services resumed normal schedules, full service will take a few more hours. Managing director James Freeman thanked the public and staff and hoped bus services would fully recover in time for the evening commute.

Natural Resources Wales (NRW) estimates that the proposed Swansea tidal lagoon could result in 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout fatalities annually, a claim Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP) considers unsupported by clear scientific evidence. TLP says its own modeling puts the worst-case impact at a 2% fish kill rate. While the £1.3bn project is seen as a test bed for larger future lagoons, TLP disputes NRW’s methodology and says it was not fully shared. The Welsh Government supports the scheme but awaits clarity from the UK government. NRW stands by its figures, citing expert assessments and extensive evidence.

A new, industry-led agri-food marketing body for Northern Ireland was announced by DETI Minister Arlene Foster, who highlights the sector’s significance in supporting nearly 100,000 jobs across farming, fishing, retail, and distribution. Developed by the Agri-Food Strategy Board, the body will provide strategic leadership similar to Scotland Food and Drink. Agriculture Minister Michelle O’Neill welcomes the initiative, noting the need for coordinated marketing, but also points out potential implications for other organizations, including her own department, and plans to discuss these with the AFSB.

The Woodland Trust is creating one of four new commemorative woods across the UK at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley. The four-year project aims to plant millions of native UK trees in tribute to those who died in WWI. Locally, 40,000 trees will be planted to reflect the number of people from Ireland who lost their lives. Members of the public are invited to help with the planting on Saturday afternoon; saplings will be provided, and participants should wear sturdy footwear. The charity envisions a space for remembrance and wildlife, with wildflowers—including poppies—where people can walk, relax, and reflect.

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award in Harrogate for “Someone Else’s Skin,” described by judge Alison Graham as “emotionally exhausting and powerful.” The book, the first in a series featuring Det Insp Marnie Rome, tackles domestic violence and so-called “honour crime.” Meanwhile, US author Sara Paretsky—creator of detective VI Warshawski—received an outstanding contribution award. VI Warshawski, who was portrayed by Kathleen Turner in a 1991 film, was seen as a pivotal female protagonist, and Paretsky also established Sisters in Crime to support women crime writers. The awards opened North Yorkshire’s annual crime writing festival, with programming chair Ann Cleeves citing the shortlist’s strength and praising Hilary’s novel for its tight writing and evocative atmosphere.

Mitch Santner, a 24-year-old left-arm batsman and spinner who debuted in Test cricket in 2015, will return to Worcestershire following the ICC Trophy in June. He previously joined the county in 2016 but broke his finger in only his second game, which director of cricket Steve Rhodes called a huge setback to their qualification hopes. Santner expressed frustration at last season’s injury and looks forward to making an impact with both bat and ball. Worcestershire also signed Australian pace bowler John Hastings as their primary overseas player for 2017 in all formats.

Barry Pring was killed in Kiev in 2008 by a speeding car with stolen license plates that failed to brake or stop. A coroner in England ruled his death an unlawful killing and noted he was likely inebriated at the time. Pring’s wife, Ganna (“Anna”) Ziuzina—19 years his junior—had briefly left him on the roadside under the pretext of retrieving a missing glove. Shortly after his death, she attempted to claim his assets, sold his possessions, and was found to have been in a relationship with another man. Though Ukrainian police initially closed the case, they later relaunched it as a murder inquiry; it remains open but is not actively pursued. Pring’s family members believe his death was a staged hit-and-run orchestrated for financial gain.

Charlie, from Merseyside, has been seriously ill since he was three and experienced a third relapse in April. With no further treatment options available in the UK, his parents turned to Seattle Children’s Hospital’s experimental T-Cell therapy. Although a previous transplant failed, they urgently pursued another round of treatment. An anonymous donor has now covered the costs, leaving Charlie’s family both “ecstatic” and “overwhelmed.” Having gained financial clearance from the hospital, his treatment will begin as soon as they receive a confirmed start date, expected next week.

Apple has extended its two-step verification system to iCloud backups following reports that hackers used third-party software to access private celebrity photos. Under this system, users who log in from a new device must enter both their password and a four-digit code sent to a trusted phone number or app. A backup 14-character recovery key is also provided, but experts note the key could be lost or stolen. Previously, two-step verification did not protect iCloud backups, allowing tools such as Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker to download data even if users enabled extra security for account logins. The maker of the software confirmed Apple’s update blocks the method used to infiltrate iCloud. Some security specialists argue Apple should make two-step verification the default, rather than an opt-in choice, and Apple has indicated plans to encourage stronger passwords and greater use of the feature. Tim Cook, Apple’s chief executive, acknowledged more user awareness is needed.

Dan Groves confirmed that details are still being worked out regarding Mark Wright buying a 20% stake in Billericay Town, with The Sun reporting Wright will also become a club director. The club currently sits eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points shy of a play-off spot. Wright, who was the 2011 runner-up on “I’m A Celebrity…Get Me Out Of Here,” previously played non-league football at several clubs. Billericay was recently taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin—reportedly investing £10,000 a week—and the club signed former England international Paul Konchesky in March.

Mr Ashley was asked by a parliamentary committee to address concerns about worker treatment at Sports Direct’s Derbyshire warehouse, following a BBC investigation. Despite inviting the committee to visit the Shirebrook facility, he has yet to accept or agree to attend a formal Westminster hearing. The committee, chaired by MP Iain Wright, reminded Mr Ashley that low-paid workers and minimum wage enforcement are key concerns and warned they could pursue a contempt complaint in the House of Commons if he does not respond by 21 March. Sports Direct has not commented publicly, though it previously pledged to review workers’ rights under Mr Ashley’s oversight.

The passage describes how colleagues of the late opposition politician Boris Nemtsov, led by Ilya Yashin, completed Nemtsov’s unfinished report “Putin. War,” claiming President Putin orchestrated and directed the conflict in eastern Ukraine. Drawing on media sources and witness testimony, the report alleges that regular Russian troops were involved on the ground and that volunteer fighters were paid salaries of up to $3,000 a month. Costs to Russia are put at 53 billion roubles, and the families of dead soldiers did not receive promised compensation. Despite the evidence, the report faces challenges in publication and distribution, and there are doubts over how many Russians are willing to confront these findings. The authors argue Putin leveraged the war to bolster his popularity, but previous exposés by Nemtsov did not spark significant public protest.

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, was discovered at the Woodhead Tunnels off the A628 in Derbyshire at 11:00 BST on Monday. A post-mortem revealed the 34-year-old from Wath-Upon-Dearn, Rotherham, died of head injuries. Two individuals—a 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman—were subsequently arrested in Sheffield by South Yorkshire Police and remain in custody.

Carwyn Jones, Wales’s First Minister, expressed frustration that he had not seen or contributed to Prime Minister Theresa May’s Article 50 letter before its release. Jones criticized the lack of respect shown to the devolved administrations, highlighting his concern over the uncertain fate of powers returning from the EU. Welsh Secretary Alun Cairns countered that the UK government had consulted widely and acted in the interests of the entire country, noting Wales was explicitly mentioned in the letter.

May’s letter pledged a full consultation on which powers should remain at Westminster or be devolved, suggesting an eventual increase in devolved decision-making for Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland. However, questions remain about which powers will be devolved—such as those related to farming and economic aid—and whether the associated funding will follow post-2020. Jones voiced skepticism that the necessary financial support would accompany any new powers.

While there is discussion in Whitehall about how EU funds have been spent in Wales, the exact distribution of any returning powers is unclear. Further details may emerge in the government’s Great Repeal Bill White Paper, but for now, the future scope of Welsh decision-making after Brexit remains uncertain.

Two cars were damaged on Friday night in Newry’s Nursery Drive and Parkhead area. Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin expressed shock at the “mindless attacks” targeting both PSNI officers and the local community. A PSNI Newry & Mourne Facebook post mentioned that officers were on duty when attacked and asked parents to be aware of their children’s whereabouts and activities.

Mr Charney, the founder and former chief executive of American Apparel, was removed from his position following employee complaints and allegations of financial misconduct. The company’s board stated in court filings that it does not expect him to return, citing illicit emails to female employees and racist remarks as evidence of his repeated violations of sexual harassment and anti-discrimination policies. In response to Mr Charney’s defamation suit, the board emphasized that such allegations make it unlikely any company would rehire him, considering the high risk to shareholders. Furthermore, a restraining order was issued preventing Mr Charney from publicly disparaging American Apparel or attempting to remove board members. Mr Charney’s lawyer has denied the accusations, calling them part of an invasion of his privacy meant to gain leverage over him.

Great Britain host Greece in a basketball warm-up at London’s Copper Box, their only home fixture before September’s EuroBasket 2017. Greece prevailed 92-64 in Patras earlier in the month, but three of their previous team members are missing this time. GB guard Teddy Okereafor, excited to play in his hometown, anticipates a strong atmosphere and valuable preparation for EuroBasket. After facing Greece, GB will participate in a four-team tournament in Poland. Coverage of the London game (17:30-19:30 BST) will be available on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website and app.

In this passage, the author recounts covering Apple’s then-new iPhone in 2007 and describes how, by briefly getting hold of Phil Schiller’s device before an interview, they managed to feature it on the BBC’s Ten O’Clock News. Though criticized for granting a product launch prominent coverage, the author defended this decision by arguing the iPhone promised a major shift in how people would use technology—comparing it to the introduction of the Model T Ford. Over time, this assessment proved accurate: smartphones have revolutionized photography, social media sharing, and much more. The passage concludes by noting that, while other companies have continued innovating with artificial intelligence, the iPhone’s unveiling marked the clear beginning of the modern mobile-connected era.

Several cats in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, have died after ingesting antifreeze near Victor Avenue. Most recently, seven-month-old Meereen died on Monday, and three others died within the past week, in addition to one two weeks ago. It is unclear whether the poisonings are accidental or intentional. RSPCA officials advise local residents to safely store any pesticides or chemicals and to check for leaks and spills, especially from car antifreeze.

The passage describes how Greece, under Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras and the Syriza government, is agreeing to new austerity and liberalization measures—despite previously opposing such demands from creditors—to secure another bailout. Tourist arrivals in Athens remain high, yet ordinary Greeks have not launched significant protests against imminent VAT increases, pension cuts, and other reforms, suggesting a shift in public sentiment following Greece’s “near-death experience” in July. Banks remain partially closed, perpetuating economic strain, and retailers face funding challenges that could jeopardize the holiday season. Tsipras’s personal popularity persists, even though austerity has intensified. The piece concludes that genuine economic recovery hinges on debt relief from European creditors, notably Germany, echoing calls for reducing Greece’s debt burden to foster hope of better times ahead.

Ross Kemp will briefly return to EastEnders as Grant Mitchell to reunite with his terminally ill on-screen mother, Peggy, played by Dame Barbara Windsor. Peggy recently reappeared to reveal her cancer had returned, and producers confirmed she will be killed off in emotional scenes. Kemp’s return, having last played Grant in 2006, will bring the Mitchell family together for Peggy’s final moments, reuniting Grant with his brother Phil (Steve McFadden) and other past connections. EastEnders executive producer Dominic Treadwell-Collins highlighted that seeing the Mitchell brothers face losing their mother will showcase Ross Kemp and Steve McFadden “at their very best.”

Lance Corporal Trimaan “Harry” Dhillon became obsessed with and stalked Alice Ruggles before fatally attacking her. Alice’s parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, immediately suspected Dhillon upon learning of her death. They expressed guilt at not recognizing the seriousness of the stalking sooner, particularly when Dr. Hills tried to reassure Alice that the police would manage the situation. In response, they established the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness about the dangers of stalking and to honor Alice’s vibrant personality. Dhillon, who denied the charge of murder, was found guilty and sentenced to a minimum of 22 years in prison.

EDF’s board approved funding for the £18bn Hinkley Point C nuclear power station in Somerset, with a third of the investment from China. However, shortly after this decision, the UK government announced it would review the project, surprising EDF executives. Critics have raised concerns over environmental damage, escalating costs, and the risk of relying on foreign governments. EDF itself has faced financial pressure, with major figures resigning over concerns about the project’s viability. Hinkley Point C is projected to supply 7% of the UK’s electricity, but delays could jeopardize energy security and increase reliance on more expensive, less environmentally friendly power sources. The government’s latest hesitation follows a series of milestones since 2006, including the UK agreeing to pay £92.50 per megawatt-hour—about double the market rate at the time. Proponents argue Hinkley will boost industry and jobs, while opponents call for greater investment in renewables.

The updated divorce application form in England and Wales explicitly asks for the name of the person with whom a spouse has committed adultery. Family lawyers argue that naming a third party often heightens conflict and can delay or complicate proceedings, despite ministry guidance stating there is no obligation to provide these details. The new design aims to be user-friendly, but lawyers worry petitioners may fill out the name field without realizing the repercussions, including increased legal costs and the third party’s formal involvement in the case. Statistics show adultery was cited in 12,148 of more than 100,000 divorces granted in 2015, while unreasonable behavior was the most common reason. Lawyers caution against naming the third party because it can reflect poorly on the petitioner and judges disapprove of dragging new partners into the process. The Ministry of Justice clarifies that naming the third party has always been possible but is not mandatory.

Britain’s heavy reliance on wood imports is at odds with Welsh forestry, where conifer forests—key to the timber industry—have declined by about 16,000 hectares since 2001. Confor argues replanting is critical to meet future needs. However, successive governments have prioritized native species, conservation, and recreational access, creating tension with commercial foresters. The Welsh government aims for a balance of environmental, economic, and social interests and points to its Glastir scheme as a step toward more woodland creation. Confor’s Martin Bishop contends bureaucracy hinders planting; only 90 hectares were planted last year, yet 20,000 hectares annually are needed to meet ministerial targets and satisfy strong market demand for Welsh timber.

A boy was struck and seriously injured in Coatbridge. Emergency services arrived at Bank Street, near Langloan Primary School, at around 16:40. He was taken to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow, where his condition is believed to be serious.

The passage describes the belated recognition of British veterans who served on World War II Arctic convoys, with Russia awarding them the Ushakov medal in gratitude for their role in supporting the Eastern Front. Initially blocked by the UK’s Foreign Office due to rules against accepting foreign medals for long-past events, an exception was eventually granted. These convoys, deemed by Winston Churchill as “the worst journey in the world,” transported supplies from Britain to northern Russia in perilous conditions and under constant German threat. Many thousands of Allied seamen lost their lives, and the veterans, though honored by Russia’s award, generally view themselves as simply having done their duty rather than considering themselves heroes. The British Government introduced the Arctic Star in 2012 for these veterans, and Russia’s presentation of the Ushakov medal followed soon after, culminating in Vladimir Putin personally awarding the first medals during his London visit in June 2013.

HM Inspectorate of Probation’s report highlights significant delays and a lack of enforcement of unpaid work sentences (or “community payback”), with some offenders completing minimal hours long after sentencing. Problems include disorganization—often due to chaotic lifestyles of offenders—and insufficient sanctions for non-attendance. Despite some examples of high-quality work and positive offender attitudes, the overall system still struggles to ensure timely completion or provide meaningful skills training. The report outlines 15 recommendations, such as reducing how often punctual offenders are turned away and creating objectives that suit individual circumstances. The Ministry of Justice has accepted these recommendations and pledged to enforce consequences for absences more strictly, aiming for more effective rehabilitation.

Russell Brand has been labeled a “hypocrite” by a newspaper for living in a luxurious London home while advocating for an economic and political revolution to support the poor. He has faced similar accusations before, including one involving a tense exchange with a TV reporter questioning his own rent while he supported East London residents facing eviction. Brand has not publicly confirmed legal action against the paper, though he has criticized it on social media using #TheSunLogic. In response to charges of hypocrisy, Brand has openly acknowledged his wealth, fame, and past behavior, emphasizing that true revolution involves both personal transformation and systemic change. Despite his affluence, he insists that inequality and environmental crises remain critical issues that must be addressed, and that his personal success does not invalidate the urgency of these problems.

Craig Venter revolutionized genomic science by spearheading rapid gene-sequencing methods and challenging traditional public research. After a difficult youth and service in Vietnam, he pursued medical research at the National Institutes of Health, where he accelerated gene sequencing by focusing on messenger RNA instead of entire genomes. Criticism from established figures and lack of public funding led him to found private ventures: first The Institute for Genomic Research, where he decoded the full genome of Haemophilus influenzae in 1995, and then Celera Genomics, which raced against the public project to sequence the human genome by 2001. Though he was vilified by some for blending commerce with research and restricting data access, he gained both wealth and independence to pursue new ideas. He later created the J Craig Venter Institute, culminating in the production of the first synthetic organism, dubbed Synthia, while also conducting large-scale projects studying genetic diversity in ocean microbes—all with the aim of harnessing genetic innovation for future industrial and environmental benefits.

Researchers surveyed around 1,000 parents in England and found that four out of five children who ate school lunches had tried foods they had not eaten at home. Half of these parents said their children later asked for these new foods to be cooked at home. Carrots, sweetcorn, and peas were the most popular vegetables, while aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach were the least preferred. A Mumsnet survey indicated some parents opt for packed lunches due to concerns over picky eating, but the School Food Trust and Mumsnet highlight that school environments and updated menus encourage children to try a wider variety of healthier foods. In England, about four in ten primary students eat school lunches (with even higher uptake in Scotland at 46%), and schools must adhere to strict nutritional guidelines. The survey took place online between late February and early March among parents of children aged four to seventeen.

Alvaro Morata, aged 23, moved from Real Madrid to Juventus in 2014 with a buy-back clause reportedly worth up to 30 million euros. He scored 27 goals in two seasons at Juventus, helping secure two Serie A and two Coppa Italia titles. Having played in consecutive Champions League finals—winning with Real in 2014 and scoring in Juventus’s defeat by Barcelona in 2015—he also made his senior debut at Real at 18, netting 10 goals there. At Euro 2016, he has scored three times for Spain and has been linked with Arsenal and Chelsea.

Wilson, aged 30, rejoined Nottingham Forest from Celtic in August 2013 for £2.5m and made 51 appearances during his second stint at the City Ground. He was released in May and is currently without a club. Prior to Celtic, he spent four seasons at Forest and has also played for Preston North End and Notts County.

Tesco, the world’s third largest retailer, is exiting the US market by selling its struggling Fresh & Easy chain to Los Angeles-based private equity firm Yucaipa, headed by Ron Burkle. The deal transfers around 4,000 of Fresh & Easy’s 5,000 employees to the new business, while roughly 50 of the 200 stores will close. Tesco will lend Yucaipa about £80 million and incur a £150 million cost for disposing of Fresh & Easy, potentially offset by repayment of the loan. If Yucaipa succeeds in turning the business profitable, Tesco can buy a stake in the future. The move comes after Fresh & Easy consistently lost money since its 2007 launch and follows Tesco’s first drop in annual profits in 20 years.

The passage describes an athlete who initially faced racial abuse, overcame it, and briefly contemplated representing France.
