He now aims for a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics, as discussed in a BBC Sport interview with Nick Hope. The text also points readers toward a special guide on getting into martial arts.

Glacial coverage in the French Alps decreased from about 375 sq km in the late 1960s/early 1970s to around 275 sq km in the late 2000s—a roughly 26% loss over four decades. A new inventory by Marie Gardent and colleagues at the University of Savoie assessed about 600 glaciers across multiple massifs, integrating historical maps, satellite imagery, and aerial photos, with manual verification to correct errors from automatic delineation. The retreat varies by region: southern sectors like Belledonne and Ecrins experienced the greatest losses, while northern areas (including the Mont Blanc Massif) fared better due to higher elevations and more precipitation. Nonetheless, even the largest French glacier, La Mer de Glace on Mont Blanc, shrank slightly over the same period. These findings align with similar accelerating glacier retreats observed in other parts of the Alps.

Scotland’s women’s football team, undefeated in five European Championship qualifiers, face a pivotal match against Iceland that could virtually secure their first-ever major finals. Forward Lisa Evans, reflecting on past near-misses, stresses the importance of avoiding another heartbreak. Iceland, just above Scotland in world rankings, are also unbeaten, making these two upcoming fixtures decisive. With the best six of eight runners-up qualifying, Scotland remain well-placed even without a play-off. Evans, who plays for Bayern Munich, recently experienced the euphoria of winning the women’s Bundesliga alongside the club’s men’s team, and highlights how playing abroad—along with many other Scotland internationals—enhances the national side through exposure to different playing styles and professional environments.

Stuart Campbell, a blogger known for his pro-Scottish independence site "Wings Over Scotland," was arrested in the west of England following a complaint by a woman in south London alleging two years of harassment. He was released on bail and said the matter involved non-threatening tweets, criticizing media reports for fueling speculation. The Metropolitan Police confirmed an investigation into online harassment, with Campbell due to return in mid-September. In a statement on his blog, Campbell insisted only tweets were involved, none of which were deleted or threatening.

PETA proposes replacing Skegness’s historic mascot, the Jolly Fisherman—commissioned in 1908 to promote train travel—with a fish-based image they feel is more humane. They argue the fisherman represents animal cruelty through fishing practices and suggest “Skegness – A Happy Plaice” as a modern alternative. The mayor welcomes suggestions but doubts public support for removing the well-loved mascot, viewing Jolly as a cheerful figure rather than a symbol of cruelty. The matter will be considered by the council, but the mayor sees no need to change something that “isn’t broken.”

Scotland overcame an initial Georgian try by Vasil Lobzhanidze to dominate possession and score six tries in total. First-half tries came from Tommy Seymour (set up by Stuart Hogg’s kick), a penalty try awarded after Georgia collapsed a maul, Sean Maitland following multiple phases, and a solo effort by Hogg off a fortunate bounce. After the interval, Hamish Watson powered over from a scrum to extend Scotland’s lead. Georgia had success at scrum time, driving Scotland back for Lobzhanidze’s second try and forcing Moray Low’s yellow card. However, a late break sparked by Ali Price on his debut saw Rory Hughes link once again with Hogg for Scotland’s sixth try. Head coach Vern Cotter praised Scotland’s control, especially in the first half, and highlighted Greig Laidlaw’s role in guiding the team to an emphatic victory.

Widnes led 14-6 at half-time, helped by tries from Leuluai, Ah Van, and Bridge, with Castleford’s loanee Flynn replying against his parent club. Flynn added another try early in the second half, but further scores from Ah Van, White (twice), and Mellor stretched Widnes’ lead to 38-12. Although Castleford mounted a late comeback with tries from Patrick, Gale, and Flynn (completing his hat-trick), Widnes held on for the win. The victory moved Widnes above Wakefield into seventh, leaving Castleford sixth and enduring a fourth consecutive home league defeat.

Fawzi al-Odah, a Kuwaiti detainee at Guantanamo Bay since 2002, was released after a US review panel determined he was not a continuing threat. Arrested in Pakistan on suspicion of ties to al-Qaeda and the Taliban—which he denies—he challenged his detention before the US Supreme Court. Following the panel’s decision, he returned to Kuwait to spend at least a year in a militant rehabilitation program. His release brings the Guantanamo inmate count to 148 and is the first since the May exchange of five Taliban detainees for US Sgt Bowe Bergdahl. President Obama has repeatedly pledged to close the facility.

Thousands gathered in London to commemorate Anzac Day, marking the first major World War I battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces at Gallipoli. Events included an early morning service at Hyde Park Corner, a parade of up to 400 people, and wreath-laying at the Cenotaph. A Westminster Abbey service was also held, repeating a tradition begun in 1916 by King George V. Alexander Downer, Australia’s high commissioner to the UK, spoke at the dawn service, reflecting on the courage of the original Anzac troops. Expatriates and visitors from both nations joined veterans in honoring these sacrifices, underscoring the enduring importance of Anzac Day for Australians and New Zealanders worldwide. The Gallipoli campaign lasted eight months and was one of the war’s bloodiest, aiming to push the Ottoman Empire out of the conflict.

David Clarkson, aged 30, returned to Motherwell for a second spell in July and is set to make his St Mirren debut against Alloa in the Championship. He scored nine goals at Dundee last season but has mainly appeared as a substitute this term. Clarkson, who has been training consistently and featuring for the U20s, emphasizes his readiness and match fitness. Capped twice for Scotland in 2008, with one international goal, he has nearly 400 senior appearances for clubs including Bristol City, Brentford, and Bristol Rovers. St Mirren currently sit eighth in the Championship, seven points above Alloa. Clarkson aims to help the team gain confidence, move up the table, and restore the club to a stronger position.

Bernard Matthews, a turkey producer, was sold to food tycoon Ranjit Boparan. Concerns arose about the workers’ pension scheme, but Unite representative Steve Harley confirmed they received guarantees the current pension agreements would be honored. The scheme in question—a final salary pension—was closed in 2004, and the existing alternative pension plan remains unaffected. Boparan’s office pledged to invest in Bernard Matthews, achieve cost savings, and use spare capacity to process chicken as well as turkey, aiming to return the business to profitability.

Council leader Dave Stewart acknowledged multiple issues with a newly launched chain ferry in Cowes, offering free crossings until 2 July as a gesture to affected users. Since starting service in mid-May, the ferry has faced breakdowns, groundings, and temporary suspension due to training shortcomings. Some vehicles have been damaged, and local shopkeepers, such as Angie Booth, reported significant business losses and requested compensation. Transport councillor Ian Ward stated that compensation was under discussion, attributing the problems to the ferry’s prototype nature, electrical faults, and the need for ramp extensions. He explained that grounding issues were also addressed through improved seamanship. The council has asked auditors to review the project.

The passage highlights that while many in the UK fishing industry hope Brexit will bring greater control over British waters and improved quotas, there are important trade-offs to consider. Fishing regions heavily supported leaving the EU, partly due to dissatisfaction with the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP). However, the House of Lords report warns that granting EU boats continued access to UK waters might be necessary if Britain wants tariff-free exports to the EU—crucial given that most UK-caught fish is sold to European markets. The report also stresses that scientific advice, shared stock management, and elements of the CFP will remain relevant. There is concern over potential fragmentation of fisheries management within the UK itself and the risks of the industry being overshadowed in broader Brexit negotiations. Nonetheless, recent quota increases and the prospect of controlling a 200-mile exclusive economic zone fuel optimism among fishers, while the government promises to seek both free trade and sustainable fisheries outside the EU.

Timothy Geaney, a teacher, admitted to taking or permitting the taking of inappropriate images of children between 2004 and 2014. In February, he was placed on the sex offenders register and given a community payback order, along with a requirement to attend a specialist programme for sex offenders. A General Teaching Council Scotland (GTC Scotland) hearing then removed him from the teaching register, citing the nature and duration of his offences—downloading mostly images of partially dressed young boys—and his failure to uphold professional standards. The panel noted his conduct was incompatible with teaching, and found a substantial risk of reoffending due to the volume and length of time over which the images were collected. Geaney, 69 at the time of sentencing, was not present at the hearing and is prohibited from applying for re-registration for two years.

A fire broke out on 2 March in Duncan Street, causing train service disruptions and travel delays. Following the blaze, the Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste and decided to revoke the firm’s environmental permit, effective 7 August unless appealed. The site, operated by Asset and Land Group, was visited nine times over the past year by Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service, which found it “broadly compliant” with fire safety legislation. However, concerns raised by the fire service in February prompted the EA to take enforcement action. The firm must now remove all waste from the site, and the cause of the fire remains undetermined.

Syria insists it is adhering to the timetable for destroying its chemical weapons, despite missing a key deadline and having shipped out only a small fraction of its declared 1,300-tonne stockpile. Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad attributes delays to attacks on convoys and ongoing conflict. The United States has expressed concern over the slow progress, while Russia maintains the transfer should be completed by 1 March. Meanwhile, human rights groups report deadly barrel-bomb attacks in Aleppo—claims the Syrian government denies, insisting it targets only “terrorists.” Conflicting reports also surround control of Aleppo’s central prison, with rebels alleging they have seized it and freed inmates, while state media denies this. Despite setbacks and security issues cited by the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons, Syrian officials assert they remain committed to meeting all obligations by the end-of-June deadline.

England dominated the second Test at Old Trafford, leveling the series with a commanding performance. Joe Root led the way, named man of the match after scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second, also contributing four catches and a wicket. Alastair Cook praised Root’s step up to number three, calling his innings “extraordinary.” Pakistan, struggling with low confidence and poor shot selection, batted only 63 and 70 overs in their two innings. Former England players Michael Vaughan and Geoffrey Boycott highlighted England’s discipline and quality batting, while acknowledging Pakistan’s lack of resistance. Despite England’s momentum, Vaughan predicted a tight series, with Misbah-ul-Haq hoping his side regains form ahead of the third Test starting 3 August.

Sarah Rochira, the Older People’s Commissioner for Wales, is gathering evidence about the experiences of older people in residential care, as well as insights from their friends, families, care providers, and public bodies. Her goal is to produce recommendations aimed at improving the quality of life and care standards across Wales, examining factors like physical and psychological health, social relationships, and care environments. While the initiative also highlights examples of good care practice, Rochira has voiced concern over "unacceptable variations" in care quality. Mario Kreft, chair of Care Forum Wales, supports the review’s aims but criticizes the advisory panel’s exclusion of provider experts, who could contribute firsthand experience of running or living in care homes.

Paul Sheerin, a 39-year-old former Aberdeen midfielder, served as player-manager at Arbroath (nicknamed the Red Lichties) from 2010 until he was chosen to replace Neil Cooper at Pittodrie. Under his management, Arbroath were relegated to League Two in 2014 but achieved their first national trophy by winning the Scottish Third Division in 2011. Aberdeen’s chief executive Duncan Fraser credited manager Derek McInnes for selecting Sheerin after “a comprehensive process,” noting Arbroath chairman John Christison’s understanding of Sheerin’s desire to return. Sheerin, who played for several Scottish clubs and in Sweden, also earned a Scotland Under-21 cap in the mid-1990s.

Swansea, having just sacked Bob Bradley, will be led on Saturday by Alan Curtis and Paul Williams. The club aims to appoint a new manager quickly, with Paul Clement as the leading candidate. Curtis acknowledges the threat of relegation and warns it would be difficult to bounce back from the Championship. He reflects on Swansea’s rise from near bankruptcy to their Premier League promotion in 2011 and notes the team has lost its distinct “Swansea Way” since Michael Laudrup’s departure in 2014, partly due to frequent managerial changes. Still, Curtis believes the current squad is capable of avoiding relegation and stresses to new players the importance of preserving the club’s hard-earned status.

Craig Venter is a biologist and entrepreneur known for accelerating human genome research and challenging scientific conventions. Initially working at the National Institutes of Health, he pioneered faster gene-decoding methods by focusing on messenger RNA, a breakthrough that led him to establish a private research institute when public funding was not forthcoming. Venter attracted criticism—particularly from James Watson—and stirred controversy by forming Celera Genomics, which raced against the public effort to map the human genome. Despite pushback, both efforts published their results in 2001.

Venter’s entrepreneurial success gave him independence and the resources to pursue large-scale projects. He founded the J Craig Venter Institute, which spearheaded the creation of the first synthetic life form, nicknamed “Synthia.” Alongside this work, Venter conducted a vast genetic survey of microbes from the world’s oceans to shed light on evolutionary processes and potentially develop new biotechnologies. His vision for synthetic organisms includes using them to address environmental issues—such as reducing reliance on oil and capturing carbon dioxide—potentially driving a new industrial revolution. Although sometimes seen as brash, Venter’s urgency stems from his Vietnam War experience, and his accomplishments have indisputably advanced the fields of genomics and synthetic biology.

The Sutton Trust, drawing on Boston Consulting Group research, warns that many apprenticeships in England are too short, low-quality, and below the equivalent of A-level (level three). In contrast, Germany offers far more high-level apprenticeships with clear, respected routes. The report highlights that fewer than 200,000 of England’s annual 520,000 apprenticeship starts are at level three, and only 61,000 go to young people. A lack of employer engagement, overly complex qualifications (18,000 in England vs. 330 in Germany), and the majority of apprenticeships going to older workers compound the issue. The Sutton Trust calls for a major expansion—up to 300,000 new starts each year, mainly at level three or higher—and insists apprenticeships should last at least three years. While acknowledging some existing lower-level apprenticeships are valued in industries like construction, the report argues that radically improving quality and clarity is essential for social mobility and economic competitiveness. The Department for Education says it is already reforming apprenticeships to improve standards, and the Association of Colleges agrees that higher-level options should be the focus, with certain well-respected level two programs retained.

Sarah Storey finished more than two minutes ahead of Poland’s Anna Harkowska in Nottwil, Switzerland, and aims for her 17th title in Saturday’s road race. At 37, she is Britain’s most decorated female Paralympian, with 22 medals (11 gold, 8 silver, and 3 bronze) across six Paralympics in swimming and cycling. She won four golds at London 2012 and has earned 21 world titles in both sports. Storey began her career as a swimmer in 1992 before switching to cycling in 2005, and she now targets further success at the Rio 2016 Paralympics.

Hereford United failed to pay their football creditors by repeated deadlines set by the Conference, despite extensions granted beyond the original 5 June cutoff. This debt, amounting to £148,000 owed to various players and staff (and totaling roughly £225,000 overall), led to the club’s eventual expulsion from the league on 10 June. Ironically, Chester, the team relegated on the final day due to Hereford’s late winning goal, was reinstated in their place. Multiple takeover talks were held, including an offer from the Hereford United Supporters’ Trust to purchase the club for £1 and assume its debts, but a London businessman, Tommy Agombar, acquired control instead. The club’s financial struggles were exacerbated by declining gate receipts since their 2012 relegation from the Football League.

James Milner, a 30-year-old former Manchester City player, earned 61 caps for England after his senior debut in 2009. He was part of the England squad at two World Cups and two European Championships, though he only played three minutes at Euro 2016. Milner holds the record for the most England Under-21 appearances (46), and scored his sole senior international goal in a 5-0 win over Moldova during the 2014 World Cup qualifiers. He described his decision to step away from international duty as “common sense” and wished manager Sam Allardyce and the team well.

Christopher Hogwood, a pioneering conductor in the early-music movement, died at his home in Cambridge after several months of illness. He founded the Academy of Ancient Music in 1973, directing it worldwide for 30 years and producing over 200 recordings, including the first complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. Among his most notable works was a 1980 recording of Handel’s Messiah with Emma Kirkby and Carolyn Watkinson, named one of the top 20 recordings of all time. 

Hogwood initially studied keyboard at Cambridge and later with Zuzana Ruzickova and Gustav Leonhardt. He worked as a keyboard player and musicologist under Sir Neville Marriner at the Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields and co-founded the Early Music Consort of London. He also served as the artistic director of the King’s Lynn Festival, Boston’s Handel and Haydn Society, and held academic appointments at Harvard University, Cambridge University, and Cornell University. 

Colleagues praised his generosity, academic rigor, and commitment to historically informed performances. His funeral will be private, with a memorial service to follow at a later date.

A young Northern Irish boy with special educational needs had to be taken out of mainstream schooling in June because he was struggling to cope. His mother left her job to care for him, and the family requested a place at a special school. In September, they were told that all local special schools were full, with no clear timeline for when a spot might open. The boy feels isolated, missing social interaction, and his mother worries that overcrowded special schools will affect other families too. Recently, a local special school hired an additional classroom assistant, raising hopes that he might start there soon. The Education Authority declined to comment on his specific case but noted it is reviewing the need for special school places and aims to ensure availability near children’s homes from 2016.

The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) is seeking to take over Newport Gwent Dragons, a proposal set for a shareholder vote on 9 May. Newport County, who share Rodney Parade, have a lease with fixture priority until 2023 if they remain in the Football League. The planned WRU installation of an artificial pitch could conflict with Football League rules, but Newport RFC’s chairman notes that current agreements protect both County and the on-site squash club. Meanwhile, Newport County face a crucial battle to avoid relegation from League Two under caretaker manager Mike Flynn, having improved form recently. Chairman Foxall highlights the significant impact relegation would have on both the club and the city, given they only regained Football League status in 2013.

The passage recounts one individual’s journey from being a teenage recruit forced into Sierra Leone’s civil war to later working to combat the Ebola outbreak. Kidnapped by the Revolutionary United Front at age 15, he was branded, threatened, and compelled under the influence of drugs to commit violence. After eventually escaping, he was helped by preacher Richard Cole, who inspired him to pursue education and contribute positively to the nation. 

During the 2014 Ebola crisis that claimed nearly 4,000 lives in Sierra Leone, his organization focused on three main efforts: educating over 10,000 people in multiple languages about Ebola’s reality, providing food and support to more than 11,000 people, and partnering with others to establish a treatment unit. Despite initial community mistrust, these consistent efforts built acceptance and helped save lives. Now, he views himself as a transformed person dedicated to uplifting young people and rebuilding the future of Sierra Leone. The passage also provides overall Ebola death figures in the region, totaling 11,314 across Liberia, Sierra Leone, Guinea, and elsewhere.

A public fundraising campaign quickly raised enough money to prevent the sale of approximately 80,000 Wedgwood items—including art, ceramics, and manuscripts—originally threatened by pension debt. Led by the Art Fund, the collection will be gifted to the Victoria and Albert Museum and then loaned back to the Wedgwood Museum in Staffordshire, ensuring it remains on public display. The Wedgwood Museum had inherited the now-defunct pottery firm’s pension debt, and courts ruled the collection could be sold to cover costs. Thanks to the successful campaign, the artifacts—important to Britain’s cultural heritage—are preserved together rather than scattered worldwide.

Mark Wright is reported to be in negotiations to buy a 20% stake in Billericay Town and could join the club’s board. Billericay, currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division and three points off the play-off places, was recently taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who has said he is comfortable investing £10,000 a week. Wright, a former non-league footballer and runner-up on I’m A Celebrity in 2011, has previously played for clubs including Lewes, Crawley Town, and Rushden & Diamonds. The club also signed ex-England defender Paul Konchesky in March.

Blackpool took an early lead through Jamille Matt just 12 minutes in, after Nathan Delfouneso’s fine setup. Colchester equalized five minutes later when Kurtis Guthrie scored from a goalmouth scramble following a corner. Despite major chances for both sides—most notably Colchester’s near miss that hit the bar just before halftime and Tom Aldred’s wide header near the end—the match ended 1–1. Colchester finished with 10 men after Sean Murray saw a straight red in stoppage time.

Developers Fawley Waterside plan to transform the disused Fawley Power Station site, retaining its 198m-high chimney as a central attraction—potentially the tallest such feature south of The Shard. The former oil-fired station, commissioned in 1971 on Southampton Water’s western shoreline, supplied power to a million homes before closing in 2013. A £1bn “merchant city” scheme proposes a petal-shaped glass structure, marina, housing, restaurants, and fast ferry services to Southampton and Portsmouth. Outline planning permission is expected later this year, with construction possibly starting in 2018.

Great Britain’s Chris Latham won bronze in the men’s scratch race, following Elinor Barker’s earlier silver in the women’s event. Adrian Teklinski of Poland took gold and Germany’s Lucass Liss claimed silver. Britain’s men’s team pursuit lost out on bronze to Italy, while Joe Truman was unable to progress in the men’s keirin. In the women’s team pursuit, a young British lineup featuring Elinor Barker finished fifth, with Barker and Joanna Rowsell Shand noting the squad’s potential. Elsewhere, sprinter Katy Marchant, who earned bronze at Rio 2016, was disappointed to go out in the first round but planned to focus on upcoming events—Saturday’s 500m time-trial and Sunday’s keirin.

Ross Kemp will briefly return to EastEnders as Grant Mitchell to join forces with his on-screen brother Phil, played by Steve McFadden, for Peggy Mitchell’s final storyline. Dame Barbara Windsor’s character has come back to Albert Square to reveal her cancer has returned, and producers confirm she will die in emotional scenes airing in the spring. Kemp, who previously portrayed Grant until 2006, views the chance to reunite the Mitchell family under such circumstances as unmissable, and the show’s executive producer describes the return as a powerful moment for both Kemp and McFadden.

Liverpool defeated Tottenham Hotspur with two rapid goals from Sadio Mane. Spurs’ manager Mauricio Pochettino criticized his team’s poor start and lack of desire, noting it is difficult to fight for the Premier League with such performances. Chelsea could go 12 points clear if they win their next match, compounding Spurs’ challenge. Tottenham’s away form has been weak, posting only two away wins since September and just one victory in their past 17 away games against top-six opponents. Former Liverpool and Spurs player Danny Murphy also faulted the decision to shift from a back three and cited Spurs’ lack of pace.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of 28 governor posts, confirming a major decline for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP), which had already lost the presidency. APC leader Muhammadu Buhari becomes president on 29 May, while the PDP—previously in power for 16 years—is now largely confined to its strongholds in the south-east and the oil-producing Niger Delta. Key northern states like Katsina, Kaduna, and Adamawa fell to the APC, though the PDP held Rivers State. Elections were not held in seven other states, Taraba’s result is pending, and Imo was declared inconclusive. Despite some violent incidents, the overall vote was calmer than earlier polls, suggesting a maturing democracy. Analysts note that APC’s failure to secure any of the five major oil states could pose challenges for the incoming administration’s control of vital oil revenues.

Visitors to the Hebridean Celtic Festival (19–22 July in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis) can use a new augmented reality app to access online content—such as videos, band interviews, and ticket information—by scanning signs and posters. Acts include The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean. According to festival director Caroline Maclennan, the app will enhance visitors’ enjoyment on-site and allow people worldwide to experience the festival’s atmosphere at any time. The content will be periodically updated leading up to and during the event.

Park View and Nansen Primary schools face the termination of their funding agreements, while Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School risk losing theirs unless they address Ofsted’s concerns. Ofsted’s investigations, triggered by allegations of a “hardline Muslim takeover,” found these Birmingham academies “inadequate” due to poor safeguarding, failure to promote cultural development, and discriminatory practices. The Department for Education has laid out demands, including ending the segregation of boys and girls, ensuring balanced curriculums, and properly vetting external speakers, with a deadline set for early July. A head teacher spoke of parents undermining her authority, saying she nearly resigned before realizing other schools faced similar issues. Some parents, however, dispute Ofsted’s findings, accusing inspectors of bias and calling for an open meeting with Education Secretary Michael Gove. Meanwhile, Birmingham City Council and school leaders have vowed to work toward improvements and higher Ofsted standards.

Vincent (Vinnie) Barker died in July 2012, five months after a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich. Prosecutors allege that the optometrist, Honey Rose, failed to detect Vinnie’s swollen optic discs during the exam and did not refer him for further investigation, leading to a fatal build-up of fluid in his brain. Ms. Rose, who denies gross negligence manslaughter, is accused of conduct so far below competent standards that it was “criminal.” The trial is ongoing.

Clive Weatherhogg arranged for a woman to have sex with a man he found online, filmed their encounters, and then sent an explicit clip to the woman’s sister on Christmas Day. He was found guilty at Dundee Sheriff Court of coercing the woman into sexual activity between September 2013 and September 2014, as well as causing her sister and father to view sexual images on December 25, 2014. The victim said she felt “blackmailed,” and Weatherhogg was assessed as posing a “moderate risk” of reoffending. Having been placed on the sex offenders register, his case was referred to the High Court in Edinburgh for sentencing due to its greater powers.

Ireland posted 165–5, led by Stuart Thompson (56), Gary Wilson (41*), and captain William Porterfield (39). However, Afghanistan comfortably chased the total, finishing on 171–4 inside 18 overs with significant contributions from Samiullah Shenwari (56) and Mohammad Shahzad (47). Paul Stirling fell early, but Ireland’s middle-order built a competitive score before Afghanistan’s openers, led by Shahzad and Najeeb Tarakai, set the platform for victory. Afghan spinner Amir Hamza took 2–23—one of the few standout bowling performances. Ireland captain Porterfield noted they were 15 runs short of their target, and the loss of paceman Boyd Rankin to injury was a further blow. The teams meet again for the second T20 on Friday, with Rankin expected back for the subsequent ODI series.

Barcelona signed Neymar for an initially stated fee of £48.6m, with £34m going to his parents, but the total cost, including wages, signing-on fees, agents’ fees, and a subsequent tax payment, rose to £106.8m. Former president Sandro Rosell resigned amid accusations of misappropriation of funds but denies wrongdoing. Investigations continue, as a Spanish judge noted sufficient evidence to challenge Barcelona’s declared payment. In response, Barcelona insists it has committed no tax offenses and has made an additional payment of over €13.5m to cover any possible discrepancies. It remains unclear whether the case will now be dropped. Neymar, meanwhile, has scored multiple goals in league and Champions League matches for the club.

On 15 September, the bodies of David Miller (24) and Hannah Witheridge (23) were found on a beach in Koh Tao, Thailand. Two Burmese migrant workers, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, allegedly confessed to the killings, though Thai police deny reports that they later withdrew these confessions. The suspects face charges of conspiracy to murder, conspiracy to rape, and robbery, carrying a possible death penalty. UK detectives traveled to Thailand to review the case and will now return to compile their findings and update both families. The UK Foreign Office raised concerns about the DNA evidence and possible mistreatment of the suspects. Post-mortem exams showed Miller died from a blow to the head and drowning, while Witheridge died from head injuries.

Scotland’s women’s football team is on the verge of qualifying for a major tournament after winning all five of their group qualifiers so far. With two key matches against Iceland approaching—the first at Falkirk Stadium—victory would likely secure a spot at the European Championship in the Netherlands. Striker Lisa Evans, who has experienced heartbreak in previous qualification play-offs, acknowledges the team still faces tough challenges, particularly given Iceland’s unbeaten run.

Scotland could potentially qualify without a play-off if they finish among the best six of the eight group runners-up. Twelve of the current 20-player squad now compete abroad, including Evans, who recently celebrated the Bundesliga title with Bayern Munich and believes that playing in stronger European leagues benefits the national side. Evans notes that experiencing different football cultures helps improve the overall standard and provides a new perspective for the team. With high hopes for reaching their first major finals, the Scots are calling on home supporters to boost their chances against Iceland, while remaining focused on the step-by-step process needed to finally overcome their past near-misses.

Apple has updated its two-step verification feature for iCloud so that anyone trying to access an account on a new device must enter both a password and a four-digit code sent to a trusted phone or via Find My iPhone. This change closes the loophole that allowed third-party software—such as Elcomsoft’s tool used in celebrity photo hacks—to download complete iCloud backups. Now, even if attackers have a stolen or guessed password, they cannot access an account’s backups without the code. Apple also notifies users by email if a backup is requested, and offers a 14-character recovery key in case the trusted device is lost. However, some experts criticize Apple’s decision to make this verification optional, arguing it should be enabled by default to better protect users from password-related breaches. Apple has pledged to encourage stronger passwords and increased adoption of two-step authentication.

UKIP, which won the May election, spent £2,956,737, slightly less than the Conservatives’ £2,980,815. Labour, coming second, spent £1,027,339, while the Lib Dems spent £1,580,575 but lost 11 of their 12 MEPs. Per vote, UKIP spent 68p, Labour 26p, the Conservatives 79p, the Lib Dems £1.45, and the Green Party—spending £534,249—43p. Including the SNP’s £267,372, the six highest-spending parties together spent £9,347,087. All but Labour spent more than in the 2009 European election campaign. The figures cover 23 January to 22 May.

Centre-back Myles Anderson, 27, left Barrow by mutual consent to join another National League club and may play against his former team on 18 February. Previously with Aldershot, Exeter, and in Italy, Anderson was praised by manager Kevin Nicholson for his leadership qualities. Striker Ruairi Keating, 21, recommended by Micky Adams, has played for Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps, with his move awaiting international clearance. Nicholson described Keating as “young, raw, but incredibly hungry,” while his Torquay side sits four points above the relegation zone, having won only one of their last six matches.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, collapsed and died from a severe pulmonary hemorrhage shortly after narrowly defeating Thistlecrack in Cheltenham’s Cotswold Chase. Although he previously exhibited post-race ataxia (over-heating and unsteady gait), he had shown no such symptoms that day. Veterinary authorities emphasized that these rare hemorrhages can happen even in horses with no significant underlying health issues. Many Clouds, trained by Oliver Sherwood and once a Grand National winner, had also won the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014.

Presiding Officer Tricia Marwick grew emotional as two long-serving MSPs, Duncan McNeil and former First Minister Alex Salmond, delivered their valedictory speeches before stepping down ahead of the 5 May election. Salmond emphasized his longstanding view that Scotland is diverse rather than divided, welcomed additional powers afforded by the Scotland Bill (while contending they fall short of promised levels), and signed off lightheartedly by referencing the UK budget and a horse race at Cheltenham. McNeil warned that Holyrood must learn from Westminster to improve its committee system and ensure adequate scrutiny and accountability. Annabel Goldie, a former Scottish Conservative leader, also announced her departure, joking that she would particularly miss her exchanges with Finance Secretary John Swinney.

The passage confirms Disney’s 2017 live-action Beauty and the Beast casting: an Oscar-winning actress as Mrs. Potts (originally voiced by Angela Lansbury), Kevin Kline as Belle’s father Maurice, Emma Watson as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, and Josh Gad as LeFou. Bill Condon will direct, and filming commences at Shepperton Studios in May, with a planned US release date of 17 March 2017.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) is set to announce its decisions regarding potential charges linked to the 1989 Hillsborough disaster, in which 96 football fans died. Relatives of the victims, including Margaret Aspinall—whose 18-year-old son was killed—will learn these decisions at an 11:00 BST meeting. Evidence files on 23 suspects were handed to the CPS in January, with 15 stemming from Operation Resolve (focusing on the disaster’s causes) and eight from an independent investigation into police conduct afterward. Families, who have fought for accountability—especially following last year’s inquest verdict that the deaths were unlawful—hope these decisions represent a significant step toward long-awaited justice.

Chelmsford Prison has experienced multiple attempts to smuggle contraband, with packages of items like mobile phones and synthetic cannabis hurled over the wall. Nearby residents have witnessed several incidents, and the prison is inviting them to discuss how to respond if they see packages thrown. The Ministry of Justice acknowledges staff are working hard to stop these activities but says stricter measures are needed. Though a former inmate believes drones are delivering contraband, the Ministry has found no evidence of this at Chelmsford. New legislation allows for prison contraband smugglers to be jailed for up to two years.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old school crossing guard, was seriously injured outside Bedford Road Lower School by Brian Wright, a 55-year-old driver who says he was blinded by the setting sun. Wright acknowledged hitting Mrs Blackburn but denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving. The court heard he failed to stop at a red traffic light, while Mrs Blackburn—wearing appropriate clothing—had stepped into the road to escort a woman and child. Judge Michael Kay QC briefly paused the proceedings after Wright expressed remorse for turning Mrs Blackburn’s “world upside down.” She is now in residential care, and the trial is ongoing.

Laura Muir, a 24-year-old middle-distance runner and final-year veterinary student, will miss next year’s Commonwealth Games in April due to her final exams in May. Despite her disappointment at not being able to represent Scotland, she emphasizes the importance of completing her degree. Muir, who placed fourth (1500m) and sixth (5000m) at the World Athletics Championships, is considering competing at the World Indoor Championships in March. She set a new outdoor personal best of 14:52.07 in the 5000m and remains optimistic about future events, including potentially multiple Olympic appearances.

Trevor Deely, then 22, disappeared in December 2000 while walking home from a Christmas party. A new search of a three-acre woodland area in Chapelizod, Dublin, has begun and is expected to last several weeks. A team of detectives recently reviewed his case, enhancing CCTV footage that shows Deely speaking with a man in black outside the Bank of Ireland on Baggot Street—where he was retrieving an umbrella—before being followed by what appears to be the same man on Haddington Road. Gardaí are still seeking to identify this individual and have called on him to come forward.

Juan Martin del Potro, back from multiple wrist operations and ranked 165th, defeated Stan Wawrinka in four sets to reach his first Grand Slam third round since 2014. Del Potro, in the same half of the Wimbledon draw as Andy Murray, will next meet either Lucas Pouille or Donald Young. Nick Kyrgios similarly progressed in five sets against Dustin Brown and now faces Feliciano Lopez, who overcame Fabio Fognini in five sets. Meanwhile, Tomas Berdych and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga each secured routine straight-sets wins.

Tunisia narrowly avoided expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations after apologizing to Caf for complaints regarding a controversial penalty decision in their 2015 quarter-final against hosts Equatorial Guinea. Initially, Tunisia wrote a critical letter to Caf but clarified they did not accuse either the referee or Caf officials of corruption. A March meeting between Tunisian and Caf officials defused tensions, enabling Tunisia to join the 2017 qualifying draw, where they face Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti.

Meanwhile, Morocco re-entered the 2017 Nations Cup after the Court of Arbitration for Sport overturned a Caf ban. Morocco had been punished for refusing to host the 2015 tournament over Ebola fears and requesting a postponement. After substituting Morocco as host, Equatorial Guinea quickly stepped in for the 2015 event. Following Cas’ ruling, Morocco’s fine was reduced, and the team was allowed into Group F alongside Cape Verde, Libya, and Sao Tome.

McLaren, once one of Formula 1’s most dominant teams, is experiencing a major downturn that began in 2013. Despite winning 182 grands prix, 12 drivers’ titles, and eight constructors’ titles over its history—including legendary partnerships with Honda in the late 1980s and Mercedes in the late 1990s—the team has struggled recently, especially with its Honda engines. High-profile controversies, such as the 2007 “Spygate” affair and the 2009 “lie-gate,” hurt McLaren’s reputation, and it has not won a constructors’ championship since 1998. Ron Dennis, who oversaw previous eras of success, returned after the 2013 slump, and two-time world champion Fernando Alonso rejoined in hopes of reviving the team’s fortunes. McLaren insists success is inevitable, believing they have solved chassis issues and that Honda will improve, but for now, their revival remains a matter of faith in a history built on cyclical triumphs and declines.

Paramedics were called to Joe’s Bar in Dungiven at around 06:00 BST due to a sudden death on 6 October 2014. Police found patrons still on the premises, with records showing alcohol was served past legal hours (until 04:49 BST). The bar was ordered to close for three months. License holder Colleen O’Neill was charged with two counts of allowing consumption of alcohol after hours and fined £3,000, while James Thomas faced one count and was fined £1,000. The judge labeled O’Neill’s record “appalling” and noted concern about the lack of custodial sentencing powers.

Stephen Curry set a new NBA record for three-pointers in a season by making eight and scoring 45 points, helping the Golden State Warriors overcome a 13-point deficit and defeat the Portland Trail Blazers 116–105. Klay Thompson added 26 points, while Portland’s LaMarcus Aldridge and Damian Lillard scored 27 and 20, respectively. In another game, Pau Gasol tallied 16 points and 15 rebounds to lead the Chicago Bulls past the Miami Heat 89–78, overcoming a 19-point halftime deficit as Miami missed its first 12 shots of the second half. Derrick Rose contributed 12 points in his ongoing return from injury, and the Bulls outscored the Heat 57–27 after halftime.

YouTube free-kick specialist Bas van Velzen visited Liverpool’s Melwood training ground under the guise of a competition winner. Initially, Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic believed Van Velzen was there to learn free-kick techniques, but soon discovered his impressive dead-ball talents. Van Velzen, who has gained fame uploading his free-kick videos online, surprised and delighted the Liverpool quartet—especially Balotelli—with his skills. He described the experience of meeting and playing with his football idols as a dream come true, and capped the day by revealing Balotelli’s famous “Why always me?” slogan, referencing the striker’s iconic T-shirt celebration.

A large study of women carrying BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutations found that removing the ovaries (oophorectomy) after a breast cancer diagnosis significantly reduces the risk of death—but only for BRCA1 carriers. Overall, the 20-year survival rate was 77.4% among 676 patients studied; those who underwent oophorectomy (about half) saw a 62% drop in breast-cancer mortality and a 65% drop in all-cause mortality if they carried BRCA1. The protective effect was most pronounced when the surgery was done soon after diagnosis (within two years), showing a 73% reduction in death. These findings support considering oophorectomy as part of initial treatment discussions for women with BRCA1 mutations, though further research is suggested for BRCA2 carriers. Angelina Jolie’s decision to have her ovaries removed exemplifies this approach, which may confer survival benefits without diminishing femininity.

A married couple, Derek Lowe (38) and Tina Lowe (33), were struck and killed by an Amtrak train on Easter morning in Durham, North Carolina. Authorities believe they had lingered on the tracks before being hit shortly before 10 a.m. by the northbound train, which was traveling from Charlotte to New York City. None of the 166 passengers on board were injured, although one passenger fell ill during the subsequent delay of about two hours and 45 minutes. The couple was pronounced dead at the scene, and it is reported they may have been living in a homeless camp nearby. After the delay, the train continued its journey.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former Medellin Cartel member, worked undercover for the DEA for 27 years in exchange for a promise of U.S. citizenship. His information aided in major prosecutions, including those of Colombian cartel leader Carlos Lehder and ex-Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega. Despite being a key DEA asset and performing undercover operations worldwide, Toro was never paid and instead relied on the expected reward of citizenship. After retiring due to health issues, he lost his legal status, and the DEA refused to help once he went public with his situation. Toro fears immediate danger if returned to Colombia and remains in the U.S. illegally, hoping to secure the promised citizenship or any legal documentation. He is prepared to go into hiding if necessary, stating that deportation would be a death sentence.

ICANN is investigating Canadian company Vox Populi Registry, which manages the new “.sucks” domain, after complaints that it charges trademark holders and celebrities—such as Kevin Spacey—exorbitant fees (up to $2,499 a year) to secure or remove their names. Critics, including an advisory panel of major businesses, call it a “shakedown scheme.” Vox Populi began accepting registrations on March 30, before a public launch, and defends the domain as a legitimate forum for customer feedback within ICANN rules. ICANN has asked U.S. and Canadian regulators to determine if Vox Populi’s practices are illegal; if so, it may revoke or revise the company’s contract. Taylor Swift has also previously paid to protect her name on other controversial domain endings.

In 1988, the body of a newborn boy was discovered wrapped in a blanket inside a Sainsbury’s bag, floating in a pond at Weasenham St. Peter, Norfolk. After an extensive but initially unsuccessful investigation, police exhumed the baby’s remains 27 years later and used DNA testing to trace his mother, who admitted concealing her pregnancy. She stated the baby was stillborn and that she placed the body in the pond. Although she was arrested on suspicion of infanticide, no evidence of foul play emerged, and the charge was dropped; she remains on bail while authorities consider whether to charge her with failing to register a birth and preventing a lawful burial. The baby, named Peter after St. Peter’s Church, was reburied in the same churchyard with a new headstone funded by a support group for stillbirths, effectively closing the long-unsolved case.

A taxi driver, Michael Young, wrongly believed passenger Kristopher Hicks intended to avoid paying his fare and decided to drive him back to the taxi rank “to teach him a lesson.” Hicks, feeling unlawfully detained, jumped from the moving vehicle at over 20mph. He sustained severe brain injuries, developed epilepsy, and now requires full-time care. In High Court proceedings, the judge ruled that Young had unlawfully imprisoned Hicks, entitling him to damages (to be set at about half the amount originally sought, amounting to “hundreds of thousands of pounds”) plus £250 for unlawful imprisonment. Both sides may appeal, and a future hearing will determine the exact compensation owed.

Multiple tornadoes were reported in Kansas and Missouri on Wednesday night. A tornado was spotted near Goddard, Kansas, passing just west of Wichita before moving northeast, while additional twisters were reported near Aetna. In Missouri, a possible tornado touched down in Potosi, causing wind damage and flooding. Nighttime tornadoes are especially dangerous, according to a CNN severe weather expert. Large hail damage was also reported in Farmington, and more storms are forecast for the Midwest and surrounding regions on Thursday.

Luke Rockhold and Lyoto Machida both seek a title shot and face each other in a middleweight clash, with Rockhold intending to pressure Machida’s elusive style by “being the bull” to Machida’s “matador.” Rockhold, on a three-fight winning streak, believes his versatile skill set will overpower Machida’s more limited options, especially on the ground. Despite his respect for Machida’s experience and technique, Rockhold plans to chase him down for a decisive victory. Machida, also coming off a win, is confident in his own strategy, expecting to exploit any weaknesses Rockhold shows in the fight. Both athletes agree that the winner deserves the next title opportunity.

A light twin-engine Aerostar aircraft arrived at Aero Acres Residential Airpark in Fort Pierce, Florida, without deploying its landing gear and skidded along the runway on its belly, damaging its propellers. Despite the impact, the pilot, 85-year-old Chris Georgaklis—flying with his dog, Buddy—managed to power back into the air and fly 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale, where he landed safely. The incident, believed to have been caused by human error, is under investigation by the FAA.

Manchester City manager Manuel Pellegrini admits he is disappointed with Yaya Toure’s performances but will continue to back him until the end of the season. City are reportedly open to offers for Toure in the summer, though the player intends to stay. Toure’s underwhelming form has drawn criticism, but Pellegrini dismisses claims that the midfielder needs a rest. 

Club captain Vincent Kompany faces a potential season-ending injury, and Joe Hart acknowledges the team’s responsibility for poor results, insisting the dressing room still supports Pellegrini. Meanwhile, West Ham’s Sam Allardyce, amid reported Manchester City interest in Aaron Cresswell, warns the left back against moves that risk limited playing time, using Jack Rodwell and Scott Sinclair’s City spells as cautionary examples.

Domenico Rancadore, an alleged Sicilian Mafia member living in the UK for over 20 years, was given a seven-year prison sentence in Italy in 1999 for mafia association. He lost his fight against extradition in early 2015 and was due to return to Italy. However, it later emerged that his sentence had effectively expired in October 2014 under Italian law, which extinguishes punishments after more than double the penalty’s time has passed. 

As a result, the European Arrest Warrant against Rancadore will be withdrawn, and his solicitor stated he can remain in Britain. Although the conviction itself still stands, the Italian Court of Appeal ruled that the sentence is no longer enforceable. The Crown Prosecution Service noted that the case must still be heard by the Italian Supreme Court, but in practice, Rancadore’s extradition will not proceed. 

The proceedings generated criticism from legal experts for the time and expense spent on an extradition request that could not be enforced after October 2014. Rancadore, also known as “the Professor,” had changed his name to Mark Skinner and lived quietly with his family in Uxbridge before his arrest in 2013.

Mr Mole, trained by Paul Nicholls, is one of three 7-2 co-favourites alongside Special Tiara and Sprinter Sacre in the seven-runner Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday. Sprinter Sacre will be ridden by Nico de Boinville, as Barry Geraghty is injured. This race marks AP McCoy’s final Grade One ride before his retirement, with his full book of rides for his last day not confirmed until Friday. Notably, McCoy announced his decision to quit riding after partnering Mr Mole to victory in February. Other entrants include Mick Channon’s Somersby.

Virginia Trimble Ritter’s daughter, Marcia, was raped and strangled in 1975 by Jerome Sydney Barrett. Marcia’s body was found 33 days after she disappeared, and at the time, Ritter’s husband cautioned her against viewing the body or crime scene photos. Decades later, Ritter asked to see the pictures and, despite warnings, viewed them. She was horrified by her daughter’s injuries and expressed a desire for revenge. Barrett, who was linked by DNA evidence, was ultimately found guilty of second-degree murder and sentenced to 44 years in prison.

Rory McIlroy believes he will inevitably win the Masters to complete his career Grand Slam, joining only five others who have achieved this. He considers his 2011 final-round collapse at Augusta—where he lost a four-shot lead and finished ten strokes behind the winner—his most important career lesson, as it taught him how to handle major-pressure situations. Since then, McIlroy has won several majors and feels Augusta suits his game well, aiming not just for one green jacket but potentially multiple. He acknowledges media hype will be intense, but he views the golf course as a sanctuary from external pressures—an approach he credits for past successes despite personal and legal challenges.

The passage highlights multiple trending stories, including a quadruple rainbow in the New York area following heavy rain, a crackdown on hiring exotic dancers for wakes in rural China, Robert Downey Jr. growing agitated during a UK interview, and the viral #kyliejennerchallenge involving lip plumping. It also covers 102-year-old Alice Barker rediscovering her past through old film footage, controversy over a prom-posal referencing bombs, Ewan McGregor being cast as Lumiere in “Beauty and the Beast,” Johnny Depp’s dramatic transformation in the “Black Mass” trailer, a pregnancy announcement referencing “The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air,” and a military father photobombing his son.

Alarming new data shows 272 children with foetal alcohol syndrome (FAS) were hospitalized in England over the past year, though the true figure may be higher. WHO research suggests at least 1 in 100 UK babies (around 7,500 a year) could have learning, behavioral, and physical problems due to alcohol exposure in the womb. Fifteen-year-old Niamh Brown’s experience illustrates severe challenges: she requires daily assistance and cannot live independently. Medical issues linked to prenatal alcohol use include liver, kidney, heart problems, and cerebral palsy. While current government advice is to limit intake to a maximum of two units twice a week, some experts advocate for complete abstinence during pregnancy.

Shaun Andrew McKerry, nicknamed “boomerang boy” or “homing pigeon boy” for always returning home after crimes, attempted to rob Shildon Post Office and Stores in County Durham on March 15. Wielding an axe and demanding cash, McKerry was tackled by owner Sab Dhillon, knocking him to the floor. Dhillon’s wife, Sam, assisted by striking McKerry twice with a baseball bat until he dropped the weapon. The police arrived shortly thereafter and arrested McKerry. He pleaded guilty to attempted robbery at Durham Crown Court and was sentenced to six years in prison. Known for extensive criminal activity from the age of 12, McKerry had previously committed burglary, vehicle theft, and stole charity boxes, leading to his repeated arrests and the “boomerang” moniker.

Four Royal Navy sailors—named as Joshua Finbow (23), Craig Stoner (24), Simon Radford (31), and Darren Smalley (35)—have been charged with gang raping a young woman at a party on a Canadian barracks near Halifax, Nova Scotia. As part of their bail conditions, they must remain in Nova Scotia, live on the Stadacona naval base, surrender their passports, avoid contact with the victim or named witnesses, and continue to serve in the Royal Navy while awaiting trial. The alleged incident took place after the group had returned from playing in a Royal Navy ice hockey tournament. The men will appear in court again on May 27. Canadian military authorities continue to investigate the case, including conducting forensic tests, and additional charges may be considered.

Valerie Jackson from Las Vegas cares for her four-year-old son, RJ, who has Netherton’s syndrome—a rare congenital skin disease that makes his skin appear red, inflamed, and scalded. As one of only about 70 people worldwide with this condition, RJ requires frequent application of creams and Vaseline to prevent his skin from drying out. Despite careful management, RJ and his mother face significant ignorance from the public: they have been unjustly accused of child abuse, surrounded by armed police while shopping, denied entry to play centers, and subjected to hurtful comments—mostly from adults. Although Netherton’s syndrome causes ongoing pain and leaves RJ vulnerable to infections, the family remains focused on his well-being, finding support through a Facebook group dedicated to this rare condition.

The passage describes the controversy surrounding Protein World’s “Are you beach body ready?” advert campaign featuring a bikini-clad model. Feminists and body image campaigners objected that the ads promote an unhealthy or narrow beauty standard, leading to a petition that gained over 50,000 signatures. Some posters were defaced, and over 200 formal complaints were lodged with the Advertising Standards Authority (ASA). Transport for London (TfL) announced removal of the ads, explaining that the paid advertising period had ended. Protein World defended its campaign on social media, at times responding bluntly to critics. A planned protest in Hyde Park on May 2 drew further attention. Separately, Protein World reported receiving a bomb threat, which was under police investigation. While many criticized the adverts, some notable figures, including Katie Hopkins and Samantha Brick, expressed support, arguing that the campaign helped motivate people to improve their fitness.

Rail companies plan significant fare increases—some as high as 87%—shortly after the general election, despite party leaders pledging fare freezes. Prime Minister David Cameron has asked First Great Western (FGW) to “urgently review” nearly doubling certain off‐peak returns between London and his Witney constituency area, from £33.30 to £62.40. Both main political parties had promised to freeze or cap fares, and constituents are angered by the hike. Train companies note these are “unregulated” fares (about half their revenue) and say the changes align prices with other routes, offering cheaper advance‐purchase options. Other reported increases affect routes served by London Midlands and Virgin, though Virgin defends its overall average increase of 1.65% and stresses that many of its fares start 20% lower than rivals.

John Young, a 66-year-old former soldier, was at home in Oldham, Greater Manchester with his new wife, Elaine, when a group of vandals began throwing stones at their windows late at night. After a brick smashed the glass panel in the front door, Mr. Young opened it to confront the attackers and was struck in the left eye by another brick. Despite emergency surgery, doctors could not save his eyesight in that eye. The couple, who married just three weeks earlier, were writing thank-you cards at the time of the incident. Police say there is no apparent motive behind the assault and are conducting an investigation. Frightened by the attack, Mr. Young and his wife plan to move away from the area.

Tom Poynton, Derbyshire’s 25-year-old wicketkeeper, missed the entire 2014 season due to injuries sustained in a road accident that claimed his father’s life. After an ankle operation and a successful playing comeback during the county’s pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi, he has signed a one-year contract extension running until the end of 2016. Derbyshire’s Elite Performance Director, Graeme Welch, praised Poynton’s resilience and hard work, expressing confidence in his form and readiness for the upcoming season.

Five-year-old Harley Renshaw was diagnosed with neuroblastoma, a rare and aggressive childhood cancer affecting his kidney, lungs, bones, and neck. To cope during radiotherapy, he decorated his protective mask as a Ninja Turtle, helping him feel stronger and more courageous. Harley underwent 80 days of intensive chemotherapy, surgery to remove the kidney tumor, a stem cell transplant, and weeks of radiotherapy. Despite complications, he has now been declared cancer-free and is resuming an active life, with hopes of returning to school full time. His story gained international attention, leading to gifts from Nickelodeon, and he was honored with a Little Star award by Cancer Research UK. Harley also became the face of the charity’s Kids & Teens campaign, which raises funds for research into childhood cancers, including neuroblastoma.

Tim Sherwood praises Jack Grealish’s recent performances for Aston Villa and advises him to focus on establishing himself at club level rather than rushing to choose between representing the Republic of Ireland or England. Grealish’s father agrees, saying Jack should maintain his progress at Villa first and that the international decision—which will ultimately be Jack’s choice—can be made later. Sherwood draws on his experience with Nabil Bentaleb, who had a similar dilemma but followed his heart. Both England and Ireland want Grealish, who has played for Ireland’s youth teams, but any final decision is expected after the season.

Private jet travel is large and growing, with millions of flights each year in the US and Europe. Costs are high, especially landing fees, which can run into the thousands per landing. Japan’s Haneda, Narita, and Kansai airports top the list for the most expensive fees, followed by Toronto Pearson, Darwin (Australia), Bristol (England), Chūbu Centrair (Nagoya), Dublin, LaGuardia (New York), and Salzburg. Big sporting events, such as the Super Bowl and the Monaco Grand Prix, drive some of the busiest and costliest private jet traffic. Overall, the market is significant, worth trillions, and continues to grow among the wealthy who can afford both the jets and their high operating costs.

Cooper the Labrador and Daisy are two dogs cared for by Katie Gallegos in Clackamas County, Oregon. In a widely viewed video (over seven million views), Gallegos treats them to a McDonald’s ice cream cone: Daisy takes polite licks, while Cooper devours it in one bite. Gallegos explains that Cooper always eats quickly, so she typically allows Daisy to have her share first. Some viewers disapprove of feeding dogs ice cream, but Gallegos—who runs a dog resort—insists it’s safe for Cooper, noting she once had a dog live to 19 with similar treats. The pair also enjoys occasional “pup-uccinos” from Starbucks, which consist of a small amount of whipped cream without coffee.

Gary Locke, previously Hearts boss and Kilmarnock assistant under Allan Johnston, took interim charge when Johnston quit in early February. Having lost just once in seven matches, he has now been appointed permanent manager on a three-year contract. Locke, who is 41, will speak at a press conference on Friday morning.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp, alleges that teachers at Seminole County Elementary threatened to remove her five-year-old autistic son, Logan, from class due to the distracting smell of doTERRA essential oils she applies to help keep him calm and focused. While Kemp says Logan has worn the oils (such as lavender, chamomile, and sandalwood) all year, a recent complaint led to a letter from the school board calling the oils a “problem.” Despite talk of suspension, the Lake County School District later stated it would not suspend Logan and described the issue as a health matter. Kemp plans to continue using the oils to aid her son’s focus.

A large fire broke out Wednesday afternoon at the Sandpiper beach-side condominium complex in Westhampton, burning through 90 units before the building collapsed. The blaze was so intense it melted paint on nearby structures, and despite the efforts of 12 fire crews, firefighters could not enter the building. The complex, which is open from May to November, served as a holiday residence for many, including building manager Rob Taber, who lost all his possessions. Officials are investigating the cause, with one report suggesting it began near a car parked by the complex.

The passage describes the Queen, at 88 years old, continuing to ride her favorite fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, despite being close to her 89th birthday and having a knee injury. She has never worn a riding helmet, preferring a silk headscarf, partly because of her hairstyle. A lifelong equestrian, the Queen was first given a Shetland pony at age four and has owned and ridden many horses ever since. While she has cut back on riding in recent years, she remains deeply involved with and passionate about horses, including breeding both thoroughbreds and fell ponies. The fell pony, a sturdy, docile breed originating in Cumbria since the Neolithic period, has been used historically for riding, racing, and pack work by Romans, Vikings, and others. Today, it is still a popular family and riding pony, and the Queen continues to breed them at her Hampton Court stud.

Two North Brisbane neighbors, 55-year-old Leon Yeaman and 28-year-old shift worker and father of three, Phillip Pama, became embroiled in a dispute over Yeaman’s loud music. Pama, who was trying to sleep for a 3 AM warehouse shift, confronted Yeaman. During the altercation, Pama allegedly delivered a single punch to Yeaman’s head. Yeaman, who reportedly suffered from schizophrenia and was known for playing loud music while intoxicated, was pronounced dead at the scene. Pama, with no prior history of violence, was said to be distraught over the incident. He was granted bail with conditions including the surrender of his passport, adherence to a nighttime curfew, and regular check-ins at a police station. The manslaughter case will return to court on May 18.

A 52-year-old Russian music teacher, identified as Yulia Simonova, attempted to hire a hitman to torture and murder 15-year-old student Damian Vanya after he ended their relationship. An undercover officer posed as the assassin, capturing Simonova on camera requesting severe violence against Vanya—including breaking his arms and legs—before she would “finish him” herself. Simonova had paid the officer part of the 100,000-ruble fee, intended for Vanya’s slow, painful death. Police then arrested Simonova during the sting operation. She now faces up to 15 years in prison on charges of attempted murder. The teenage victim, who reportedly left Simonova for a classmate, expressed relief at her arrest.

Jose Mourinho, pictured with his wife at a fashion show, explains he speaks to God each day—strictly about personal matters rather than football. He highlights his work with the World Food Programme, emphasizing his family’s awareness of poverty. He endeavors to keep family life separate from his career and asserts he is fundamentally a good person, despite his sometimes confrontational behavior on the sidelines. Mourinho acknowledges his strong faith but says he rarely attends church unless in Portugal. He was fined earlier in the season for comments made about refereeing, yet his team remains atop the league.

Bob Barker, the longtime host of “The Price Is Right,” returned to the show on April 1 after an eight-year absence. Now 91, Barker, who originally hosted for 35 years before stepping down in 2007, handled the first game, “Lucky Seven,” then handed hosting duties back to Drew Carey. Despite the long break, Barker showed he remained fully at ease in his former role.

Off-duty Secret Service Agent Arthur Baldwin was arrested around midnight on Friday in southeast Washington, D.C., after allegedly trying to break into a residence. He faces felony charges of attempted burglary and destruction of property. Following his arrest, the agency revoked his security clearance and placed him on leave; Baldwin was assigned to the Foreign Missions Branch, which works with the State Department. Court records indicated he was scheduled for arraignment on Friday afternoon. The arrest comes amid additional misconduct allegations within the Secret Service, including a high-ranking supervisor being investigated by police and the Homeland Security Department’s inspector general, as well as an earlier incident involving two officials allegedly driving into a White House secure area after drinking.

Freelance photographer Atif Saeed, from Lahore, Pakistan, spotted a male lion at a safari park and approached it to within about ten feet. Armed only with his camera, he knelt on the ground to take photos. The lion noticed him when it heard the shutter click, prompting a swift charge. Saeed scrambled back into his car just in time. Reflecting on the close call, he admitted he was attempting to capture the lion’s true character, but now doubts he would repeat such a dangerous approach.

On March 22, a woman believed to be between 25 and 45 years old was found unconscious near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue in Brooklyn’s Gravesend neighborhood. Paramedics were unable to revive her, and she was pronounced dead that evening. She carried no identification but had a distinctive tattoo on her right leg—a heart and rose with a ribbon bearing the name “Monique.” Police released images of the faded tattoo to help identify her and are awaiting a medical examiner’s report to determine the cause of death. Anyone with information is asked to contact NYPD Crime Stoppers.

Hannah and Alex, a New Zealand couple, returned from the UK in 2009 and needed an affordable home. They purchased a 1986 Hino flatbed truck and spent about a year and a half converting it into a two-bedroom wood-and-steel house. Now stationed on their own lot in Nelson, the solar-powered home costs very little to run, with most electricity supplied by panels, water drawn from a nearby spring, and additional heating from gas and a wood-fired stove. The entire project cost about $25,000, and the couple, who cherish its natural feel, hope to build another one later on.

Research by Courtney Blackwell at Northwestern University found that kindergarteners who shared iPads in class scored around 30 points higher in early literacy tests than those who either used their own iPads or had none. The study suggests that the collaborative use of technology is key to boosting literacy. Although there was initial skepticism from a head teachers’ representative about using technology in non-IT classes, Blackwell’s findings indicate that schools might benefit from rethinking how they integrate tablets, particularly in early grades. She is set to present her research at an international communication conference in Puerto Rico.

A piglet, born without hind legs in Qionglai City, Sichuan Province, has become an internet sensation for learning to walk upright on its two front trotters. Nicknamed “super pig,” it wobbles but consistently regains balance, mingles with its four-legged siblings, and forages for food with its snout close to the ground. The farmer, Ms. Duan, noticed the piglet’s missing limbs at birth, and ever since, villagers have flocked to see the remarkable animal. This is not the first two-legged creature in China to gain fame—a rabbit at Liuzhou Zoo also learned to walk on its front paws, drawing many curious tourists.

A pit crew member, Todd Phillips—a front-outside tire changer for Dale Coyne Racing—was injured when driver Francesco Dracone spun after a pit stop on lap 25 during the IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana. Dracone’s car clipped Phillips’ leg, and Phillips received stitches at the infield care center before being released. Rainy conditions contributed to traction issues for many cars, and Dracone did not finish the race, ultimately placing 23rd.

A husband, identified as 32-year-old Milton Vieira Severiano, brutally killed his wife, 29-year-old dancer Cicera Alves de Sena (stage name Amanda Bueno), in Rio de Janeiro just four days after they married. CCTV footage shows him dragging her outside, slamming her head into concrete paving 11 times, punching her 10 more times, then retrieving a handgun and shooting her in the face five times. Severiano later confessed he was jealous of men looking at her. Police arrested him after he crashed a stolen getaway car, finding multiple firearms, a bulletproof vest, and evidence he had carried out the murder. He now faces life in jail.

Sarah Wilson, the journalist and author of the best-selling book “I Quit Sugar,” shared that her severe anxiety, along with stress, thyroid disease, and feelings of isolation, led her to believe life was no longer worth living. In a candid interview, she explained how she “couldn’t see the point of continuing” and felt she “missed out on a guide book to life.” Wilson noted that, in her view, depression and anxiety are deeply intertwined and that anxiety seems to be “the new depression,” particularly among Australian women. She has since found some peace with her mental health challenges and emphasizes the importance of recognizing the link between anxiety and depression to better address rising stress and anxiety levels.

Elena Curtin of Portland, Oregon—who was seven months pregnant—was charged with second-degree assault for striking her boyfriend’s ex-girlfriend with a crowbar after finding her shooting heroin in Curtin’s bathroom in November 2014. Under Oregon law, residents may use physical force against an intruder who refuses to leave. Prosecutors dropped the charges, citing Curtin’s outrage as justified. Before this incident, the ex-girlfriend had allegedly harassed Curtin, stolen from her, and attempted to lure the boyfriend, who is also the father of Curtin’s child, back into heroin addiction. Curtin gave birth in January, and the boyfriend has not been involved in the child’s life. She has since moved in with her parents. If convicted, Curtin would have faced an almost six-year mandatory prison sentence.

Gemma the pit bull, who lives with two children in California, is filmed enjoying treats until her owner slips in a piece of broccoli. Disgusted, Gemma spits out the vegetable, prompting hope that the children won’t follow her example and will still learn to love their greens. When not sampling snacks, Gemma is shown in other videos sleeping and spending time with her family.

HSBC apologized after a link on its official website, meant for a discontinued Young Entrepreneur Awards page, redirected visitors to a pornographic site. The original page was scrapped in 2011, and the domain registration lapsed, allowing the site to be taken over by adult content. Upon discovery, HSBC removed the hyperlink, denied any association with the external site, and assured the public that its own website remained secure.

A Maryland teenager, Marcus, called 911 early Sunday after discovering a fire on the first floor of his family’s home. Trapped upstairs with his nine-year-old sister Aaliyah, he calmly gave dispatchers clear directions for the firefighters. During the 11-minute call, Marcus also reassured his frightened sister and reminded her to stay low and breathe. Firefighters entered through the house, broke a window, and rescued the siblings. One firefighter even gave Aaliyah his gas mask. Other family members escaped on their own, and all were treated for non-life-threatening injuries.

This passage describes stunning images of blue‐glowing algae captured in Jervis Bay on Australia’s east coast. Photographer Andy Hutchinson called it a “beautiful supernatural scene” created by millions of plankton emitting light. Oceanography expert Iain Suthers identifies the algae as Noctiluca scintillans, a single‐celled phytoplankton that preys on diatoms. The algae’s luminous glow serves as a defense mechanism and is most commonly seen in spring and autumn. A similar display was reported at Manly Beach in Sydney in August 2014, but it was deemed harmless.

New genetic tests can analyze tumor samples after breast cancer surgery to determine the tumor’s aggressiveness and the likelihood of recurrence. If the test suggests a low risk (as low as 5%), patients may safely forego chemotherapy, avoiding its significant side effects. One such test, EndoPredict, costs around £2,500 privately, but experts believe its use on the NHS would be cost-effective by reducing unnecessary chemotherapy. For instance, patient Becca Cornford’s test showed only a 5% chance of recurrence, so she opted out of chemotherapy, illustrating how the test can guide more personalized treatment decisions.

More than 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy, including five from HMS Ocean and at least one from HMS Illustrious. Eighteen other ships had similar emergency evacuations. The Ministry of Defence enforces a strict “no touching” rule, suggesting most pregnancies occurred before deployment or during leave. Commander Sarah West, the first woman to captain a Royal Navy warship, was also flown back following allegations of a relationship with a crew member. Women have served on Royal Navy ships since 1990, making up about 9% of personnel in 2014.
