Separately, 99 servicewomen were evacuated from Afghanistan and 102 from Iraq between 2006 and 2013 for pregnancy, in accordance with rules prohibiting pregnant personnel from remaining in war zones.

A small drone containing traces of radioactive cesium was discovered on the rooftop of Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s residence, prompting concerns about possible drone-based terrorism. The device, equipped with a camera, smoke flares, and a plastic bottle holding a small amount of radioactive material, was found on the same day that a court approved plans to restart two nuclear reactors. While the quantity of cesium was not immediately harmful, the incident stoked fears of drone misuse ahead of major events such as the Olympics and the G7 summit. The government is examining how to prevent similar threats, acknowledging that current laws do not restrict drone flights over much of Tokyo. Abe was not present at the time, as he was attending a conference in Indonesia.

A devoted security guard in eastern China, Mr. Lu Xincai, takes his 84-year-old mother—who has Alzheimer’s—to work with him daily. Fearing she might wander off and get lost (as she had in the past), Mr. Lu rides his motorbike slowly for the four-kilometer journey, tying a sash around both of them so she does not fall off. Since his father died, there is no one else to care for her, and his wife works in a different city while his son is still in school. Mr. Lu’s employer, a bank, provides his mother with her own room at his workplace. He explains that his mother once devoted herself to looking after him, and now it is his turn to care for her. By keeping an eye on her throughout the day, Mr. Lu ensures his mother remains safe—and he feels relieved knowing she is close by.

Heavy drinking among Americans rose by 17.2% from 2005 to 2012, driven largely by increases in women’s drinking as social norms shifted, according to a study from the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Binge drinking rates (four or more drinks in one sitting for women, five for men) also surged, especially among women, whose rates increased more than seven times those of men over the decade. Despite these trends, the overall percentage of people who drink any alcohol has remained stable. Factors such as changing social acceptance for women, cheaper alcohol in real terms, increased advertising, and weakened alcohol control policies may be contributing. The study found notable variations by county and highlighted the significant health and economic impacts—alcohol-related deaths reached 88,600 in 2010, and excessive drinking costs over $220 billion yearly.

Doctors are increasingly performing caesarean sections, leading to concerns from the World Health Organization (WHO) that the procedure is used too often without medical necessity. In England, more than a quarter of births are now delivered by caesarean—over double the rate in the early 1990s—partly due to women’s anxiety about natural childbirth. The WHO emphasizes that caesareans should ideally comprise only 10–15% of births because they carry risks such as infection, complications, and even death, and they also cost the NHS more than natural deliveries. Current NHS guidance (NICE) allows women to request caesareans for reasons including fear of childbirth, advanced maternal age, or medical conditions, but WHO officials warn that doctors may underestimate the dangers, with research suggesting up to one in ten caesareans can lead to infection.

A woman, identified as 44-year-old Michelle Filkins from West Wareham, allegedly broke into and lived in a Martha’s Vineyard home for about a week, selling or giving away the owner’s belongings in a yard sale. She was discovered by homeowner Mark Conklin on April 17, fled, and was subsequently arrested that same day. Filkins faces charges of breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property; she is due back in court on May 14. The police report indicates a broken window at the property and a list of missing household items, including furniture and a painting. Authorities are requesting anyone who obtained items from Filkins to return them to the Edgartown Police Department.

Police in Albury received a lost phone belonging to Melbourne resident Bella Crooke and discovered it was unlocked. To locate Bella, officers posted humorous selfies and puns on her Facebook page, showcasing the phone in various “holding cell” scenarios, advising it would be “fully charged” upon collection, and joking about “posting bail.” Bella eventually reclaimed the phone, learning about the officers’ posts in person. She found the situation amusing, has since set a password, and was grateful to the police for their inventive approach in reuniting her with her phone.

A five-day-old hippo calf was fatally caught in a violent fight between two adult males in the iSimangaliso Wetland Park in eastern South Africa. The baby was thrown into the air and dragged through the water after wandering too close to the battling adults. Despite the mother’s attempts to protect her calf, a sub-adult grabbed it, and the calf died of its injuries hours later. Tour operator Stacey Farrell witnessed the entire incident, describing the mother’s distress and her futile efforts to save the baby.

Two Knightsbridge maisonettes are being sold at unusually low prices (starting at £575,000 and £595,000) because each has only three years left on its lease. Despite being “unmodernised,” they offer sizeable interiors (1,990 and 2,500 square feet respectively) and could be worth over £6 million and £7.5 million once fully renovated and the leases are extended. Extending the leases, however, will require negotiation with the freeholder (the Wellcome Trust) at an estimated cost of £3.35 to £4.5 million for a 90-year extension. In the meantime, the annual cost of buying and holding either property effectively matches the going rental rate for three-bedroom apartments in that exclusive area. Property consultants note it is rare for homes with such short leases to appear on the market, cautioning prospective buyers about the significant premium required to secure a longer lease.

Starbucks experienced a register outage on Friday, affecting 7,000 U.S. stores and 1,000 in Canada. As a result, many baristas gave away free drinks, while some stores opted to close early rather than continue offering freebies. The company announced that the issue was a result of a failed daily system refresh and has now been resolved, with stores resuming normal operations. This incident coincided with news of Starbucks posting record quarterly earnings the previous day.

Terrorists have been identified using rural locations across Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire in West Wales to conduct training and radicalization activities, according to an officer from the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit. Incidents date back to at least 1998, when Abu Hamza allegedly sent extremists to train in the Brecon Beacons. The area’s rugged terrain, also used by the British military, has attracted various extremist groups, including individuals linked to the 7/7 London bombings, a Cardiff-based al-Qaeda–inspired cell, and one of Lee Rigby’s murderers, who reportedly studied Arabic locally. Authorities stress that these groups may appear to engage in ordinary activities while harboring an “ulterior motive,” and emphasize the importance of community intelligence to combat the threat.

A rare Omura’s whale, initially thought to be extinct, was discovered washed up on a remote beach in Western Australia after a cyclone, marking the first sighting in the state and only the second in the country. DNA profiling confirmed it as a 5.68-meter juvenile female. Since Omura’s whales were only described scientifically in 2003 and are typically found in tropical and subtropical waters (e.g., Indonesia, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan), this discovery is especially significant. Researchers plan to study the buried whale’s skeleton in the future; understanding its unique features, such as having 53 vertebrae and four digits on each pectoral fin, will help refine field identification and inform scientists about the species’ regional distribution.

The passage addresses claims that women’s hormones disqualify them from the presidency—a view espoused by a Texas businesswoman—and counters that male leaders’ hormones have led to risky or irrational decisions throughout history. It highlights research showing women often take fewer unnecessary risks than men, questions why hormones matter more for women than men, and points out that Time magazine deemed Hillary Clinton “biologically primed” to lead. More broadly, the text emphasizes the pervasive bias women continue to face in the workplace and leadership roles, citing studies that demonstrate how gender bias harms women’s advancement despite their strong representation in colleges, graduate schools, and the workforce. It concludes that true equality—in which half of companies are led by women and half of households led by men—benefits not just individual women, but families, businesses, and society as a whole.

Robert Hardy, the 89-year-old actor known for roles in “All Creatures Great and Small,” his frequent portrayals of Winston Churchill, and as Cornelius Fudge in the “Harry Potter” films, is auctioning more than 200 antiques from his personal collection due to downsizing. The items—estimated to total around £100,000—include furniture, paintings, swords, flintlock rifles, silverware, crystal chandeliers, and a notable 3D diorama of the Battle of Agincourt commissioned by Hardy himself. A keen military historian who studied under J.R.R. Tolkien and C.S. Lewis at Oxford, Hardy is reluctant to part with his treasured pieces but will continue his television work despite retiring from stage acting after an injury. The auction is taking place at Dominic Winter Auctioneers in Gloucestershire, featuring 238 lots gathered over his lifetime of collecting.

Michael Scott Shemansky is wanted in connection with the murder of his mother, Sandra, in their shared Winter Garden, Florida home. Authorities became suspicious when he missed a scheduled supervised visit with his son on the same day Sandra’s body was discovered, and an initial investigation indicated foul play. Shemansky, who has a history of bipolar disorder, a prior battery conviction against law enforcement, and past involuntary psychiatric commitment following a suicide attempt, was reportedly under stress due to pending divorce proceedings. Neighbors believe Sandra may have prevented him from attending the visit with his son. Police have the murder weapon, though its specifics remain undisclosed. Shemansky was last seen fleeing on foot without supplies or medication, and anyone with information on his whereabouts is urged to contact authorities.

The International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF) has granted Eugene, Oregon, the 2021 World Championships without a formal bidding process, citing a unique strategic opportunity to bring the event to the United States for the first time. Eugene had previously lost its bid for the 2019 championships, which went to Doha, Qatar. However, a subsequent presentation convinced the IAAF that Eugene could successfully host the event, with strong support from government, private sector partners, and American broadcasters. The 2007 championships in Osaka were also awarded without a bidding process.

Aspiring model and care assistant, 25-year-old Leonie Granger from Gillingham, Kent, lured professional gambler Mehmet Hassan to his death after befriending him at a London casino. She targeted him for his visible wealth, leaving his flat door unlocked so her boyfriend, Kyrron Jackson, and accomplice Nicholas Chandler could break in. They tied up Hassan, a father of three, and kicked him to death while ransacking his home for cash, ultimately stealing around £3,000 and other belongings. Granger was convicted of manslaughter, not murder, and sentenced to 16 years in prison; Jackson and Chandler were found guilty of murder and jailed for life with minimum terms of 36 years. The court heard that Hassan was considered a “soft target” because he frequently kept large sums of gambling winnings at home. Judge William Kennedy described the attack as “pitiless and wicked,” underscoring its brutality driven by “ruthless greed.”

Cesc Fàbregas began the season in outstanding form for Chelsea, racking up assists and looking likely to break Thierry Henry’s Premier League record of 20. However, consistent with his history of late-season slumps (noted even by former club Barcelona), his performance has dipped since January. Despite remaining happy at Chelsea and playing nearly every minute, fatigue seems to be affecting him. His recent struggles were evident in Spain’s 2–0 defeat to the Netherlands, where he made little impact. Still, José Mourinho is counting on him to rediscover his early-season creativity as Chelsea push to secure the Premier League title.

West Ham are closing in on a deal for 17-year-old Jamaican forward Deshane Beckford, who impressed during a two-week trial at the club’s academy. Despite offers from Belgian clubs, West Ham hope to secure the highly rated prospect from Montego Bay United. Separately, the club announced that season tickets for the Olympic Stadium in 2016–17 will start at £289—the lowest in the Premier League—to help fill the 54,000-seat venue.

Police ended their investigation into Mike Lane’s assault by balaclava-clad hunt saboteurs—despite video evidence, witness details, and a photograph of the main suspect—citing insufficient evidence. Lane, a Tedworth Hunt master who was attacked with iron bars and kicked in the head while trailing an artificial scent, suffered concussion and broken teeth, yet no one has been identified or charged. Both Lane and other hunt supporters are dismayed by the police decision, criticizing the lack of progress and calling for measures such as banning face coverings to help bring attackers to justice. The police maintain they will only reopen the case if new information emerges.

Adam Gadahn was an American citizen who became a prominent English-language propagandist for al Qaeda under the name “Azzam the American.” Born in California in 1978, he converted to Islam in 1995 and traveled to Pakistan in 1998. Over time, he appeared in numerous al Qaeda videos threatening attacks against Western targets, criticizing U.S. leaders, and urging Muslims to conduct lone-wolf operations. He was indicted for treason and providing material support to al Qaeda and was on the FBI’s “most wanted terrorists” list.

The White House announced that Gadahn was killed in a U.S. counterterrorism operation in January, along with another American al Qaeda operative, Ahmed Farouq. Neither was specifically targeted in the strike, which also resulted in the deaths of two hostages, American Warren Weinstein and Italian Giovanni Lo Porto. Among materials recovered from Osama bin Laden’s compound was a letter from Gadahn suggesting al Qaeda media strategies, indicating his growing role within the organization prior to his death.

A five-year-old Chinese boy named Mai Zizhuo has become an internet sensation for his impressive basketball skills, which he has honed since he was two and a half years old. In a viral video, Mai demonstrates a succession of successful shots and adeptly dribbles two basketballs at once. Netizens across basketball-loving China have expressed amazement in online comments, with some doubting the video’s authenticity and others feeling inspired—or even ashamed—by the boy’s talent. His rapid rise to fame follows in the footsteps of other Chinese child prodigies and recalls the national enthusiasm surrounding basketball icon Yao Ming.

Tom O’Carroll, formerly a leading figure in the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE) that campaigned to legalize child sex in the 1970s and 1980s, has joined supporters of the media pressure group Hacked Off. PIE once allied with the National Council for Civil Liberties (NCCL), seeking to lower the age of consent to ten under certain conditions. O’Carroll, previously jailed in 1981 for “corrupting public morals,” attended a Hacked Off rally at the Houses of Parliament in February to advocate for statutory press regulation—an event chaired by John Cleese. Hacked Off, established after the phone-hacking scandal, wants MPs to implement the Leveson Inquiry’s recommendation for a legally backed regulator. O’Carroll’s involvement is considered an embarrassment for the group, though Hacked Off emphasized that the rally was open to the public.

Bondi’s Icebergs Club pool was drained on a warm Thursday and transformed into a unique catwalk for the Ten Pieces presentation during Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. Models showcased the label’s monochrome, unisex collection—ten items designed to be worn in twenty ways—while walking through the empty pool and along the break wall. Ten Pieces is led by restaurateur Maurice Terzini and his partner Lucy Hinckfuss, who easily secured the show-stopping location. Despite a few disappointed lap swimmers, guests enjoyed nibbles, drinks, and sunny weather as they took in the minimalist designs against the ocean backdrop. Beachgoers and passers-by watched from the beach and nearby roads, creating a striking merging of fashion and everyday Bondi life.

Amir Khan, the Bolton-born boxer, spent a day at a safari park in Northern California with his wife, Faryal Makhdoom Khan, and their daughter, Lamysa. They posed with giraffes, sea lions, and fed a rare white tiger at Six Flags Discovery Kingdom. Shortly afterward, Khan announced he would face former light-welterweight world champion Chris Algieri on May 30, having been under pressure to fight Kell Brook and linked to potential bouts with Adrien Broner and Keith Thurman.

A young Palestinian named Mohammed Abu Khdeir was included on an Israeli memorial wall commemorating soldiers and terror victims, but his family objected because Abu Khdeir, who was murdered by three Israelis, did not belong alongside Israeli soldiers. A victims’ advocacy group, Almagor, also opposed his inclusion, characterizing his death as a “rogue attack” rather than terrorism. In response to these complaints, the national insurance institute decided to remove Abu Khdeir’s name from the memorial wall and its website. A legal proceeding against the three perpetrators of his killing began in January.

A young boy repeatedly tries to rest his head on the family cat’s belly while in the garden, causing the cat to move away several times. Despite the cat’s reluctance, the boy persistently follows and attempts to lie on the pet again and again until the cat finally goes indoors. Later, the two make up, and the boy feeds the cat some treats.

Robert Kushner, a former marijuana dealer, testified at a police corruption trial in Philadelphia, alleging that some of the six former undercover officers on trial stole $81,000 and seven pounds of marijuana from him in 2007. Following his testimony, Kushner was dismissed from his job as a varsity basketball coach at the Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy because school officials learned of his past drug offenses, including arrests in 2007 and 2011, a DUI in 2008, and four years of probation. Kushner maintains he did not intentionally deceive the school and has moved on from his earlier actions. Meanwhile, defense lawyers for the accused officers, who face charges of racketeering, argue the case relies on unreliable testimony from 19 drug dealers and a rogue ex-cop.

An explosion at a paraxylene-producing chemical plant in Zhangzhou, Fujian, injured six people (mostly from broken glass). More than 600 firefighters contained the blaze, which began after an oil leak at an oil storage facility. No toxic chemical spill was reported. The same facility experienced another explosion in 2013. Previously planned for Xiamen, the plant was relocated to Zhangzhou following public protests over pollution concerns.

Jack Grealish, an Aston Villa teenager and Ireland Under-21 international, is noted for wearing his socks low and using children’s shin pads—a personal superstition he refuses to change despite requests from referees. He made his first Premier League start in a 3–3 draw against QPR, expressing both relief at finally starting and disappointment in the result. Grealish appreciates his manager’s faith in him and hopes to earn more starts before the season ends.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, is reported by her grandmother and medical sources to have “global and irreversible brain damage.” Although no longer in a medically induced coma, she remains unresponsive. Her father recently claimed she had awakened, but a family attorney clarified that while doctors believe she may have a long life, her rehabilitation will be lengthy and the ultimate quality of her life remains uncertain. She has been moved out of the ICU and has a tracheostomy as part of her ongoing care.

Russia took a 2-0 lead in their Fed Cup tie against Germany after Svetlana Kuznetsova beat Julia Goerges in straight sets, followed by Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova’s three-set victory over Sabine Lisicki. Pavlyuchenkova saved a match point in the second set and ultimately prevailed despite 13 double faults, while Lisicki’s 63 unforced errors proved decisive. Russia needs just one more win from Sunday’s three matches to reach the final and aim for their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

Residents of New South Wales, already recovering from a severe storm and flooding last week, are being warned of another potential east coast low forming from Thursday to Saturday. Meteorologists and the Bureau of Meteorology caution that this weather system could bring further heavy rain, especially to the state’s north-east coastal areas and parts of southeast Queensland. The State Emergency Service (SES) has thousands of unfinished requests for assistance and is urging people—particularly in the hard-hit Hunter region—to prepare for possible renewed flooding and property damage. Although the coming system may move faster and affect different regions than last week’s storm, SES and meteorologists emphasize it still poses a significant threat, with rain likely falling on already saturated ground. SES personnel, supported by teams from other states, are working to complete as many clean-up jobs as possible before the new system arrives.

Nina Moric, a 38-year-old model who appeared in Ricky Martin’s “La Vida Loca” video, was reported by Italian media to have attempted suicide. In response, Moric posted photos of bruising on Instagram and denied any intent to harm herself, explaining instead that she fainted due to low blood pressure and hit her head. She clarified her boyfriend was away in Naples at the time and that she was recovering after hospital treatment. The Croatian-born model, once married to jailed paparazzi photographer Fabrizio Corona with whom she has a son, also referenced earlier rumors about a 2009 suicide attempt. Moric emphasized that the latest claims of self-harm were untrue and that her injuries resulted from an accidental fall.

A recent poll shows that if the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge have a daughter, the most popular choice of name among Britons is Diana (12%), followed by Alice and Charlotte (9% each). In the event of a son, James is favored (13%), with Alexander as the second choice. A quarter of those surveyed hope for a girl, versus only 3% who want another boy. Public sentiment on social media also reflects strong support for naming a girl after the late Princess Diana. Additionally, 68% of respondents approve of Prince William taking six weeks of paternity leave.

A suicide bombing in Khost Province, eastern Afghanistan, killed 17 people and wounded dozens, including an Afghan lawmaker, during a protest. The Taliban denied involvement, and no other group has claimed responsibility. The protesters, led by Parliament member Humayoon Humayoon, were heading to a larger demonstration against the provincial governor when the attack occurred around 10 a.m. local time.

Dani Alves is set to leave Barcelona after rejecting the club’s final offer of a three-year contract extension, which required him to participate in 60% of matches. The 31-year-old Brazilian right-back, who has won four Spanish titles and two Champions League trophies with Barça, failed to agree terms with the club despite seven successful years at the Nou Camp. His agent, Dinorah Santana, confirmed that negotiations have ended and criticized Barcelona’s delay in addressing Alves’s contract situation.

Pablo Osvaldo, on loan at Boca Juniors from Southampton, has called on his former Italian teammates Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at the Argentine club. He believes their playing styles would suit Boca Juniors perfectly and that fans at La Bombonera would go wild for them. Osvaldo, who has already scored three goals in six games for Boca, specifically mentioned Pirlo’s midfield prowess and Totti’s legendary status at Roma, suggesting both would be embraced in Argentina.

Eighteen-year-old amateur jockey Lewis Ferguson took a spectacular double somersault fall from Merrion Square at Wincanton, which became an online sensation. Despite the dramatic incident, he escaped with only a cut on his nose and returned to work at Paul Nicholls’s yard the following morning. Ferguson watched the replay in the weighing room with fellow jockeys and was thankful he was uninjured. Undeterred, he humorously noted he might consider a gymnastics career after racing.

James Haskell, the England flanker and London Wasps captain, joined in the excitement around the release of Avengers: Age of Ultron by posting a photo dressed as Iron Man on his Instagram. Haskell originally joined Wasps in 2002, earning his first England cap in 2007. After stints with Stade Francais in France, Ricoh Black Rams in Japan, and the Highlanders in New Zealand, he returned to Wasps in 2012. Since then, he has surpassed 100 appearances for the club and continues to be a key player for both Wasps and England, with 57 caps to date.

Wide-leg trousers are a key SS15 trend, offering a fresh alternative to long-dominant skinny jeans. They appear in various forms—denim, cropped, printed, striped—and channel a cool 1970s aesthetic. Though the volume can be intimidating, high heels that expose the top of the foot and simple tops help maintain a flattering proportion. Going high-waisted and very long elongates the legs, and denim is the easiest way to try the look, as shown on Gucci’s runway and in high-street styles like Topshop’s Miller jean. Brands such as Celine and Stella McCartney showcase dressier takes for evening, while Finery London offers accessible options. Overall, this silhouette is versatile enough for unpredictable spring weather and updates any wardrobe with minimal effort.

The University of Michigan initially canceled a planned screening of “American Sniper” after over 200 students petitioned against it, citing the film’s negative depiction of the Middle East. The main character, Chris Kyle, was a Navy SEAL portrayed by Bradley Cooper, who received an Oscar nomination for the role. In response to backlash and a counter-petition, the university reversed its decision, with Vice President for Student Life E. Royster Harper admitting the cancellation conflicted with the school’s commitment to free expression. An alternative screening of the family-friendly film “Paddington” was offered, and the decision to reinstate “American Sniper” drew praise from Michigan’s head football coach, Jim Harbaugh.

Two French tourists on Rottnest Island allegedly used a lighter and aerosol spray on April 3, causing a flame to singe a quokka. The animal survived with minor burns. Detectives questioned the men, aged 18 and 24, seized video evidence, and evicted them from the island. Both have been charged with animal cruelty and will appear in Fremantle Magistrates Court on April 17. Quokkas, about the size of a domestic cat, primarily live on islands off the Western Australian coast, such as Rottnest Island.

Alice Barker, a 102-year-old former dancer from the 1930s and 1940s, performed at iconic New York venues like the Cotton Club and the Café Zanzibar alongside stars including Bill “Bojangles” Robinson and Frank Sinatra. Although her filmed performances existed, she had never seen them until Mark Cantor of jazz-on-film.com and volunteers compiled her “soundies”—early music videos—and showed them to her. Delighted by the footage, Barker finally got to see herself dancing after decades without any memorabilia.

The passage describes a decline in Britons washing their own cars, once a traditional Sunday activity. A third of men and three-quarters of women never do it, citing factors such as shops now opening on Sundays, more live football, the availability of affordable hand car washes, and larger vehicles that are harder to clean. A survey of 1,100 adults found only 12% of men who wash their cars do so regularly, and just 5% ask children to help. While some still wash their cars during holidays (15 million over Easter, with one in four admitting it is “an excuse to get out of the house”), the overall trend is downward. Washing is more common in Birmingham, Chelmsford, and Sheffield, and Audis, Toyotas, and BMWs are most likely to be washed by their owners. Andrew Kirkley of the vehicle leasing firm OSV notes that changing lifestyles and convenience have largely replaced the old tradition.

Martin Skrtel praises Steven Gerrard’s immense impact since his own Liverpool arrival in 2008, hailing Gerrard as “one of the best players in the world” and an iconic figure who is intrinsically linked with the club. Gerrard aims to finish his Liverpool career by winning the FA Cup, potentially signing off at Wembley on his birthday. Skrtel credits Gerrard with helping him settle into life at Anfield and acknowledges that Liverpool “will never be the same” without him. However, Skrtel believes the team has worthy players who can step up, provided they receive the necessary support. Both Gerrard and Skrtel are likely to feature against Aston Villa in the FA Cup semi-final after returning from bans.

Jack Nicklaus, aged 75, thrilled the crowd at Augusta National by scoring his first-ever hole-in-one there during the par-3 contest. The shot, on the 130-yard fourth hole, came while he was playing alongside Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw, part of a day that saw five total aces—tying a record from 2002. Camilo Villegas made two of those aces but ultimately lost the event to Kevin Streelman in a play-off. Nicklaus, the youngest winner of the green jacket in 1963, went on to claim six Masters titles and is one of only five men to achieve the career Grand Slam, an accolade Rory McIlroy could match by winning at Augusta.

Several tornadoes were reported in Kansas on Wednesday night, including one near Goddard, west of Wichita, and more sightings in southwestern Kansas. The storms moved northeast, missing Wichita but threatening other communities. Nighttime tornadoes are noted as especially dangerous. Missouri was also impacted, with a possible touchdown in Potosi causing wind damage, flooding, and roof damage. Baseball-sized hail was reported in Farmington. More storms are expected on Thursday across the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the southern Great Lakes.

Robert Bates, a 73-year-old reserve deputy in Tulsa County, pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter for fatally shooting Eric Harris, claiming he intended to use his Taser but mistakenly fired his gun. A judge permitted Bates to travel to the Bahamas, prompting criticism from Harris’s family, who found the timing insensitive. Bates’s preliminary hearing is set for July 2. While Bates and Sheriff Stanley Glanz both apologized, Harris’s family alleges Bates received preferential treatment due to his donations and friendship with the sheriff. The Tulsa World reported some supervisors were told to forge Bates’s training records, an accusation the sheriff’s office denies. Bates’s lawyers released training documents they say prove his qualifications, and two deputies involved in Harris’s arrest have been reassigned due to threats.

Conor McGregor is preparing to challenge Jose Aldo for the featherweight title on July 11 in Las Vegas, where Aldo will make the eighth defense of his belt. McGregor revealed a new tiger tattoo on his stomach (joining the gorilla design on his chest) and suggested it reflects his fierce mindset. Tension between the fighters peaked during a promotional tour in Dublin, where McGregor grabbed Aldo’s belt in front of thousands of Irish fans. McGregor insists he is more motivated than Aldo, claiming Aldo “doesn’t want it the way [he] wants it.”

Tony Abbott’s public skolling of a beer at an Australian rules function drew cheers from onlookers but sharp criticism from anti-drinking campaigners, who argue it glorifies binge drinking and reinforces the idea that heavy consumption is tied to masculinity. Cultural studies professor Julie Robert expressed concern that his behavior and the subsequent media and political reactions help perpetuate a problematic culture of rapid, excessive drinking rather than social drinking. While some, like Bill Shorten, made light of the incident, others, including Health Minister Sussan Ley, defended Abbott by pointing to his overall fitness. Critics, however, contend that in an era more alert to the dangers of binge drinking, the prime minister should set a better example instead of reviving a dated stereotype that real Australian men must drink heavily.

Indiana is experiencing a significant HIV outbreak centered in Scott County, where 120 cases have been confirmed and 10 more are preliminarily positive—primarily among intravenous users of the painkiller Opana. In response, Governor Mike Pence authorized a 30-day needle exchange program on March 26; it has so far distributed over 5,000 clean syringes and collected around 1,400 used ones. The program’s future beyond April 25 is uncertain, as Pence and lawmakers debate extension and broader legislation that would allow more counties to conduct similar exchanges. Opponents worry needle exchanges might encourage drug use, while supporters view them as an essential harm-reduction strategy. The challenge also involves federal funding restrictions, as federal money cannot be used for such programs.

An Arsenal fan created a formal exam for his girlfriend to test her knowledge of his favorite football club. She scored 43.5 out of 50 (87%) and posted the results on Twitter, joking she was unsure whether to laugh or cry. The quiz included multiple-choice questions, tables, and essays, with instructions reminiscent of a school exam. Her boyfriend marked answers in red ink and offered “feedback,” teasing that he would have dumped her had she failed. Highlights included questions about Arsenal’s 2014 FA Cup final result, the starting lineup, and why Alexis Sánchez is better than Eden Hazard. She earned double marks for calling Hazard a certain rude name, and though she mixed up some player positions, the boyfriend still awarded her an A. Twitter reactions ranged from admiration—calling the boyfriend a “legend” and hailing her as “proper girlfriend material”—to mockery, with some users accusing him of taking things too far. Overall, people saw it as a lighthearted stunt, albeit an extreme one.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former mid-level member of the Medellin cartel, became an undercover DEA informant after fleeing Colombia due to a dispute with his boss. Over 27 years, he played a pivotal role in operations that helped take down figures like Colombian drug lord Carlos Lehder and former Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega. Although he was promised U.S. citizenship in return for his services—which were unpaid—Toro never received legal status. Now in poor health, he cannot collect Social Security or secure proper documentation and faces deportation back to Colombia, where he fears for his life. The DEA has not assisted Toro since he went public with his situation, leaving him in limbo and prepared to go into hiding if necessary.

A 14-year-old girl in Kosi Kalan, Uttar Pradesh, was allegedly gang-raped by five local men and then, after her family reportedly told her to remain silent, set herself on fire using kerosene. She was hospitalized in Safdarjung Hospital in Delhi with grave burn injuries. The accused men were arrested. The incident arises amid heightened concern in India over sexual violence, reflected in widespread protests and the banning of “India’s Daughter,” a documentary about the 2012 Delhi gang rape and murder of Jyoti Singh. The passage also references instances of vigilante justice, including an 18-year-old man beaten to death over a separate alleged rape and murder case, and the broader issue of misogyny and violence against women in India.

Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal is preparing for Sunday’s derby against Manchester City at Old Trafford without Robin van Persie, whom he deems not fit enough to play despite the striker’s claim to be ready. Luke Shaw is similarly ruled out, as Van Gaal does not feel he has reached the required match fitness level. Van Gaal says this fixture provides a big opportunity for United to solidify a higher league position—either second or third—to avoid a Champions League qualifier later in the summer. While he acknowledges the difficulty of facing City, Van Gaal emphasizes maintaining composure, recalling that a lack of control contributed to United’s 1–0 loss in the earlier fixture. He also praises the dedicated support of the fans and admits he has been “dreaming” of a victory that could move the team closer to achieving its season objectives.

Fans of both Arsenal and Liverpool staged a 10-minute empty-seats protest at the Emirates Stadium to highlight the continually rising ticket prices—starting from £64 for this match—especially following the Premier League’s £5.14 billion TV deal. Banners reading “£5bn and what do we get? £64 a ticket” were displayed, and organizers from both clubs’ supporter groups called the prices “extortionate.” They warned that escalating costs risk alienating working-class fans and urged football authorities to consider tangible ticket-price reductions. Additional protests were planned to continue after the match.

A newborn, named Star, was diagnosed with biliary atresia shortly after birth. Attempts to unblock her bile ducts were unsuccessful, and she needed a liver transplant to survive. Neither parent was a suitable donor, but Star’s mother’s twin sister, Shanell, proved an ideal match. Shanell donated part of her liver, saving Star’s life. Biliary atresia can be fatal if untreated and often presents with jaundice. Star’s surgery took place in November, and she spent six weeks in the hospital. Now home and on anti-rejection medication, she is recovering well, as is her aunt.

Chelsea players Eden Hazard, Nathan Ake, Loic Remy, and Willian take on a series of car-themed football challenges sponsored by Audi. Hazard and Ake win the first two rounds—initially by firing balls into a car boot (5–3) and then by playing a makeshift tennis match over an Audi R8 (gaining a 6–0 lead). In the final challenge, which involves sinking balls into a convertible Audi from long range, Remy and Willian emerge victorious. However, Willian accidentally smashes a wing mirror with a misplaced shot, prompting a humorous reaction from Remy and no apparent penalty for damages.

Robert Dellinger, a former Fortune 500 executive, caused a December 2013 highway crash in New Hampshire that killed a Vermont couple, Jason Timmons and Amanda Murphy—who was eight months pregnant. Although prosecutors said Dellinger claimed he was trying to kill himself by driving across the median at over 100 mph, Dellinger asserted in court that he was never suicidal. He pleaded guilty to negligent homicide (for the deaths of Timmons and Murphy) and assault (for the death of the fetus) and faces 12 to 24 years in prison. His defense argued that complications from medications, including Ambien and Prozac, as well as health issues, contributed to his impaired state. Dellinger’s wife testified on his behalf, expressing remorse to the victims’ families and describing her husband’s previously exemplary life and ongoing medical struggles. A wrongful death lawsuit was also filed against Dellinger by Murphy’s estate.

Lacey Spears was convicted of second-degree murder for poisoning her five-year-old son Garnett with salt. She received 20 years to life, sparing her the maximum sentence. Prosecutors argued she inflicted multiple unnecessary medical procedures on the boy to gain attention. Garnett’s father, Chris Hill, strongly condemned Spears on Facebook, expressing hope she would be harmed in prison. The presiding judge deemed her actions “unfathomable in its cruelty,” indicating mental illness played a role. Spears’s lawyer maintains her innocence, blaming hospital negligence and announcing plans to appeal.

Australia is receiving a delayed flu vaccine designed to combat newly problematic strains (H3N2 and B/Phuket) that caused increased deaths in the Northern Hemisphere. These strains were not well-covered by the previous vaccine, prompting a revision. Free shots for high-risk groups (e.g., the very young, elderly, and most Indigenous Australians) commence on April 20. Experts, including Dr. Alan Hampson, emphasize that everyone should get vaccinated, both to protect themselves and to shield vulnerable populations. The updated vaccine also includes protection against H1N1 and will match what is used in the Northern Hemisphere next season.

Caretakers of Abraham Lincoln’s tomb in Springfield, Illinois, face budget threats from Governor Bruce Rauner’s proposal to restructure the state’s historic preservation agency and criticism from a National Geographic magazine piece calling the tomb’s interior bland. Marking the 150th anniversary of Lincoln’s assassination, supporters point out that extensive renovations—totaling over $2.5 million—have recently been completed to improve the structure’s plaster, paint, and interior lighting, and another project to protect the receiving vault is underway. While historian Adam Goodheart finds the reconstructed, Art Deco–style interior disappointing, many visitors disagree, describing the site as impressive. Despite reduced operating hours due to budget cuts, local advocates fear further funding reductions could jeopardize the tomb’s upkeep and public access.

The passage highlights the resurgence of various 1990s and early-2000s fashion trends—such as choker necklaces, berry lips, round sunglasses, and JNCO wide-leg jeans—and presents examples of each now and then. Specific returning styles include bucket hats (once worn by Christina Aguilera, now by Rihanna), camouflage prints (like Destiny’s Child wore, now loved by Jourdan Dunn), over-the-top looks such as double denim (famously on Britney Spears and Justin Timberlake, now on Kylie Jenner), Ugg boots (Paris Hilton then, Kristen Bell now), Daisy Dukes (Jessica Simpson then, Miley Cyrus now), Juicy Couture velour tracksuits (Britney Spears then, Nicki Minaj now), colored sunglasses (Britney Spears and Justin Timberlake then, Cara Delevingne now), corsets as outerwear (Victoria Beckham then, Selena Gomez now), and harem trousers (Kim Kardashian then, Elle Macpherson now). Though these items are reappearing, the passage suggests some trends might be best left in the past.

It was a notable week for trending news, with stories ranging from a rare quadruple rainbow spotted in New York—captured by Amanda Curtis—to China’s new crackdown on hiring exotic dancers at wakes. Robert Downey Jr. grew upset over personal questions during a Channel 4 interview, while the Kardashian family’s latest lip-plumping trend, the #kyliejennerchallenge, also made waves. Other highlights included 102-year-old Alice Barker revisiting her dancing days on film, a prom invitation referencing bombs that sparked controversy, Ewan McGregor’s casting as Lumiere in “Beauty and the Beast,” and Johnny Depp’s dramatic transformation in the “Black Mass” trailer. Rounding out the week were a creative “Fresh Prince” pregnancy announcement and a military dad’s amusing photobomb of his son.

Serena Williams notched her 700th career victory at the Miami Open by defeating Sabine Lisicki in three sets, securing a spot in the semifinals where she will face Simona Halep. Andy Murray also celebrated reaching 500 career wins. Williams’s chance to meet her sister Venus ended when Venus lost to Carla Suárez Navarro, but with this milestone victory—and her celebratory cake—Serena remains focused on advancing in what is effectively her home tournament. Simona Halep earned her place in the semifinal by defeating Sloane Stephens.

Sabeen Mahmud was a prominent Pakistani activist and founder of a second-floor café called T2F in Karachi, where she hosted discussions on technology, human rights, and social issues. Despite receiving death threats, Mahmud refused to remain silent—most notably on the topic of possible mass abductions in Baluchistan. Shortly after leading a discussion on this issue, she was shot and killed by two gunmen, and her mother was wounded. Mahmud’s fearless commitment to free speech and openness made her a beloved figure among progressive and secular voices in Pakistan, where such public discourse is often suppressed. Tributes poured in from friends and supporters, highlighting her bravery, determination, and undying hope for a more inclusive, tolerant society.

Since India’s 1947 partition, around 100,000 “West Pakistan refugees” have been living in Jammu and Kashmir without rights granted to citizens of the state. Despite most having been born and raised in India, these families are barred from owning property, voting in state elections, or working in state government due to a pre-independence law that only recognizes those descended from residents of the former undivided kingdom of Kashmir. Fear of changing the region’s Muslim-majority demographics is cited as a key reason why state governments have repeatedly refused them full rights. However, with the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party recently joining the governing coalition, refugees like 82-year-old Mangu Ram hope that citizenship rights, including property ownership and access to state jobs and education, might finally be extended to them after decades of poverty and marginalization. Despite ongoing regional unrest, activists warn they are prepared to take forceful action if their hopes are disregarded yet again.

Yoshinori Muto, FC Tokyo’s 22-year-old forward, is weighing an offer from English club Chelsea, reportedly worth around £4 million. While Chelsea would consider loaning him out to their partner club Vitesse Arnhem, Muto is focused on finding a team where he can play regularly and develop. His former coach Ranko Popovic praises Muto for his intelligence, speed, strength, and confidence, seeing him as a standout talent. Chelsea manager José Mourinho acknowledges both the player’s ability and the club’s commercial interests—highlighted by their recent £200 million sponsorship deal with Yokohama Rubber—while emphasizing that they only sign players they believe are genuinely good prospects.

Australia has overturned its ban on selecting overseas-based players, prompting criticism that England is refusing to do likewise. The author argues that Stuart Lancaster should be free to choose his strongest England squad, regardless of where players are based. Several examples—such as Matt Giteau, Drew Mitchell, Steffon Armitage, and Nick Abendanon—show improved form while abroad, and the author likens their situation to star footballers who would never be excluded for playing overseas. Citing Jonny Wilkinson’s success after moving to France, the author insists that, for a home World Cup, England must pick its best talent without restriction, to give the team the greatest chance of victory.

Open Garden’s FireChat app enables users to chat without internet or mobile signals by forming a wireless mesh network that connects phones via Apple’s Multipeer Connectivity Framework or equivalent Android features. Messages are passed along nearby devices (nodes), letting users communicate even on planes, in subways, or at crowded events where networks can fail. To expand the 200-foot limit for FireChat, Open Garden developed Greenstone, a small egg-shaped booster device that stores messages until another FireChat device comes within about 20 feet. Greenstone can operate for up to a year without charging, holds up to 1,000 recent messages, and is intended for areas or situations lacking reliable connectivity. Open Garden is collaborating with manufacturers to refine and produce Greenstone for public use.

Burlesque performer Lillian Bustle uses the word “fat” as a simple descriptor of her body—just like “short” and “wife”—rejecting its usual negative connotations. In a TED Talk, she emphasizes that “fat” need not mean “ugly,” pointing out that body-size discrimination has risen 66% over the past 30 years and starts early in girls’ lives. However, she notes that exposure to diverse body types increases acceptance, which motivated her to showcase her own 240-lb body on stage in a confident and glamorous way. She describes her first performance in 2012 as empowering and advocates finding a “courage reference” to overcome self-consciousness. Though some online commenters have been unkind, Lillian’s TED Talk has received predominantly positive reactions, leading her to believe that body positivity is gaining ground.

Theo Walcott has frequently been on the substitutes’ bench for Arsenal this season. Despite this, he joined teammates Chambers, Wilshere, Arteta, Ospina, Flamini, and Özil—alongside model Olga Sherer—for a Lanvin photoshoot. Arsenal’s players will wear similar attire for the FA Cup final against Aston Villa on May 30. Walcott, who has been named on the bench for 17 of Arsenal’s 33 league games, made a brief substitute appearance against Chelsea and hopes to start again soon, possibly in the upcoming match against Hull.

Renowned makeup effects artist Rick Baker is auctioning over 400 original props and costumes from his Cinovation Studio on May 29 at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles and via propstore.com. Spanning more than 50 productions—including Men in Black, Batman Forever, How the Grinch Stole Christmas, Gremlins 2, Mighty Joe Young, and more—the collection is collectively valued at around $746,100. Individual highlights, some valued at upwards of $40,000, include iconic items like the alien Edgar Bug (Men in Black), the Grinch costume (How the Grinch Stole Christmas), and various Gremlins puppets. Baker’s 30-plus-year career also featured work on titles such as An American Werewolf in London, Planet of the Apes, Hellboy, and Michael Jackson’s Moonwalker, with memorabilia from these projects also up for sale.

Seven-year-old Carwyn Scott-Howell, a competent skier since the age of three, died in the French Alps after becoming separated from his mother and veering into dense woodland, where he fell 164 feet. His family, who describe him as a caring, adventurous child with a “handsome smile,” had been enjoying their last run of a ski holiday in Flaine. When his sister’s ski came off, their mother stopped to help, and Carwyn skied on alone. Investigators traced his final steps by footprints and sliding marks, believing he mistook a slope through the woods as a direct route back to the resort. His devastated family, well-known in their Welsh community for their farm shop, remember him as a lively boy who brought constant laughter and possessed a strong love for the mountains.

Laura, a teenager from Whitley Bay, initially felt heavy at nearly 13 stone and was bullied about her weight. Determined to be thinner, she restricted her diet to as few as 100 calories a day—often just one piece of fruit—and hid uneaten food to disguise her behaviors. Over time, her health deteriorated severely: she collapsed, was taken to the hospital, and spent a week on a heart monitor as her body began shutting down. 

Following her hospitalization, Laura received support through eating disorder organizations, which helped her understand and manage her anorexia. She describes the intense pressures—coming not just from peers but also widespread media messages—promoting a “size zero” ideal. Now in recovery and with healthier body image, Laura has advanced to the semi-final of Miss Teen GB, a competition that aims to foster confidence rather than encourage extreme thinness. The passage also highlights information from the NHS regarding anorexia, emphasizing its seriousness, common behaviors (such as calorie restriction, excessive exercise, and laxative use), and the importance of seeking professional help or reaching out to organizations like Beat if someone appears to be struggling with an eating disorder.

Liverpool unveiled their new 2015/16 home kit—created by equipment sponsor New Balance in a record-breaking £300million deal—at Anfield. Raheem Sterling, Daniel Sturridge, Martin Skrtel, and Simon Mignolet were among the players modeling the strip, and fans loudly encouraged Sterling to remain at the club despite recent contract and transfer speculation. Liverpool management is adamant Sterling will not leave this summer and highlights the player’s importance. The kit launch also served as motivation ahead of the FA Cup semi-final, with Sturridge and Sterling voicing their desire for cup success. Departing captain Steven Gerrard’s hope of bowing out with a potential cup final victory remains alive. Notable features of the new kit include an all-white logo design and a memorial tribute to the Hillsborough victims. Club legends Robbie Fowler and Ian Rush were also present to celebrate the launch.

Researchers have produced the largest-high-definition map of dark matter, covering 0.4% of the sky using the Dark Energy Camera (DECam) on the Victor M. Blanco Telescope in Chile. Led by Dr. Sarah Bridle of the University of Manchester, the team spent two years measuring galaxy shapes in 130 million telescope images to detect subtle distortions caused by the gravitational pull of dark matter (a process called gravitational lensing). This work is part of the five-year Dark Energy Survey, which aims to create a 3D map of dark matter and dark energy across 12.5% of the sky by 2018. Early results show that dark matter forms clumps and filaments where galaxies cluster, supporting current cosmological theories that galaxies form where concentrated dark matter boosts gravitational forces. Through further mapping, scientists hope to better understand not only dark matter, which accounts for about 80–85% of all matter in the universe, but also the mysterious “dark energy” believed to be causing the universe’s accelerated expansion.

Manchester United have made an official move to sign 21-year-old Memphis Depay from PSV Eindhoven. Manager Louis van Gaal, who coached Depay at the 2014 World Cup (where the Netherlands finished third), is eager to bring the winger to Old Trafford as one of his key summer signings. PSV’s technical director confirmed contact with United, Paris Saint-Germain, and another major European club, noting that Depay’s value has increased since Tottenham had a £15 million bid rejected last year.

Depay has been prolific this season, scoring 20 goals in 26 league appearances and helping PSV win their first Eredivisie title in seven years. Known for his pace, dribbling, and powerful right-footed shot, Depay draws comparisons to Arjen Robben and a young Cristiano Ronaldo. Originally joining PSV at age 12, he has since made over 100 appearances for the club and impressed at the World Cup—earning two goals and a nomination for the tournament’s Best Young Player award.

Chelsea took a 3–1 advantage over Manchester City in the Youth Cup, with goals from Tammy Abraham (two volleys) and Dominic Solanke. Abraham’s firepower and Solanke’s late strike proved decisive, as City’s only goal came from Isaac Buckley. Chelsea’s defense—particularly Fikayo Tomori and Jake Clarke-Salter—was generally commanding, while full-backs Ola Aina and Jay Dasilva provided width. Midfielders Ruben Sammut and captain Charlie Colkett helped Chelsea control play.

For City, Brandon Barker showed promise on the wing and created opportunities, though he sometimes tried to do too much. Defender Tosin Adarabioyo led City’s back line strongly but struggled at times with Chelsea’s attacks. Kean Bryan, Aaron Nemane, and Bersant Celina each had moments but lacked finishing touches. Ultimately, Chelsea’s clinical finishing and solid defending made the difference, giving them the upper hand going into the return leg in west London.

Marco Rubio, a Republican senator from Florida running for president, stated that people are born with their sexual preference but does not believe same-sex marriage is a constitutional right. He insists that the definition of marriage should remain between one man and one woman, and any changes to this should be decided by state legislatures, not the courts. While Rubio disagrees with same-sex marriage, he has said he would attend a gay wedding for someone he cares about. He also acknowledged his Catholic belief that divorce is wrong but emphasized he would not stop loving someone who gets divorced. Rubio has reportedly secured financial commitments exceeding $51 million for his presidential primary campaign.

Pablo (27) and Ilze (31) quit their restaurant jobs in Manchester to travel the world by bicycle, with no fixed plans or schedule. In their first 356 days, they covered nearly 7,000 miles through 16 countries, living on less than three euros each per day. They keep costs low by camping most nights or using free hosting sites such as Couchsurfing and Warmshowers, and spend only about 2.74 euros each per day on food. After starting in London, they have cycled through Western and Eastern Europe, Turkey, Georgia, and Armenia. Their journey continues into Asia and beyond, aiming eventually to cross the Pacific and traverse the Americas.

A Texas couple alleges that their wedding photographer printed racist language—“poor n ***** party”—on photo booth images at their 2012 celebration. They were informed months later by the bride’s sister, who had hesitated to ruin the day at the time. When approached, photographer James Evans of Premiere Photos reportedly did not apologize and told them to sue him. Represented by attorney Cathy Hale, the couple is suing under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act, claiming negligence and breach of contract. Evans denies the allegations, citing no proof among the 103 guests. The couple is primarily seeking an apology, and mediation is scheduled before a July trial date.

Mike Brown, England’s full-back, is taking a cautious approach to his return from concussion, acknowledging uncertainty about when he will play again for Harlequins. He cites the need to avoid rushing back prematurely—particularly given high-profile cases such as George North, Johnny Sexton, and Geoff Parling, who have each missed extended periods due to repeated head injuries.

Brown explains that although there was no single collision after England’s match against France, he experienced lingering headaches and decided not to risk aggravating his condition. He similarly chose to withdraw from England’s crucial Six Nations match against Ireland after recognizing ongoing symptoms. Emphasizing the value of recent online concussion-awareness modules, Brown encourages honesty about head injuries and warns teammates against pushing through potential concussion signs. He spoke in support of Land Rover’s “We Deal in Real” campaign, highlighting the importance of grassroots rugby and player welfare.

Britons’ monthly sexual frequency has declined from five times in 1990 to four in 2000 and now three. Professor David Spiegelhalter attributes this drop partly to increased internet and smartphone use, which erodes the separation between work and private life. As people spend more time on devices—checking emails and staying connected—sex falls lower on their list of priorities. Additional factors include more people living alone and the blurring of boundaries between home and work, leaving less time and focus for intimate relationships.

Tibetan mastiffs, once sold for as much as £1.2 million each and given as lavish gifts to officials, have dramatically fallen out of favor in China. The government’s anti-corruption crusade has deterred gifting, and city bans on large dogs (over 50 kg) have reduced demand. Overbreeding weakened the breed’s quality, creating a surplus of unwanted mastiffs. Many of these dogs now end up in slaughterhouses for meat and leather, with some stolen off the streets or sold by breeders disposing of “imperfect” specimens. Rescuers have found Tibetan mastiffs in grim conditions, reflecting the breed’s abrupt shift from luxury status symbols to animals tragically cast aside.

A recent survey of 600 women in the Paris area found that every respondent had experienced some form of sexual harassment on public transport, with half reporting their first incident before age 18. Many have been “conditioned” to accept low-level abuse, and six in ten women fear being attacked, compared with three in ten men. The findings highlight how this underreported problem restricts women’s freedom, forcing them to alter routines or clothing to feel safer. In response, officials call for greater awareness, campaigns against sexist behavior, and stronger recognition that acts like unwanted touching constitute sexual assault with severe legal penalties.

A competition named #everydayfix, run by Direct Line, asked designers to create prototypes that solve “everyday emergencies,” based on a survey of 2,000 people. The top everyday problem was insomnia (46%), prompting a team called Instruments to make “Snooze,” an alarm clock that silences phone notifications. “Forget Me Lock,” designed by Onn Studio, confirms whether a door is locked by changing color (green or red) on the key, while “Nipper,” by Impulse, is a tiny phone charger powered by any household battery. One of these three prototypes will be chosen for Kickstarter funding based on Twitter retweets with the #everydayfix hashtag. Other contest ideas that did not make the shortlist included a helmet with bone-conduction directions, a parking pin that alerts users of available parking spaces, and an app to pass on messages when a phone dies.

Police and Crime Commissioner Vera Baird allocated over £500,000 of public money to a victims’ charity—Victims First Northumbria—of which both she and Northumbria Chief Constable Sue Sim are directors. Critics, including MP Keith Vaz, allege a conflict of interest and have labeled the situation a “soap opera.” The Ministry of Justice is investigating whether conflict-of-interest rules were breached and can halt the funding if so. Baird maintains that the funding followed proper procedures, while Sim, previously accused of bullying, is scheduled to retire soon.

A 53-year-old man named Greg Valecce was violently assaulted for 42 hours in the basement of Corry “Corey” Campbell’s mother’s house after Campbell believed Valecce had harmed his cat. Campbell (21), accompanied by Sandra Ng (19) and Carl Halin (18), repeatedly beat Valecce, filmed parts of the abuse, and forcibly tattooed offensive symbols and phrases onto his body. Valecce sustained broken ribs, fractured wrists, and facial injuries before escaping. Campbell and Halin each received 20-year prison sentences, Ng was sentenced to 23 months, and two other individuals—David Thomas (28) and Jennifer Pratt (40)—are awaiting further legal proceedings. The assault left Valecce traumatized, and he has since undergone free tattoo removal.

Manchester United have officially approached PSV’s 21-year-old winger Memphis Depay, a prolific talent who has scored 20 goals in 26 league games this season. Louis van Gaal, familiar with Depay from the Netherlands’ 2014 World Cup squad, is eager to make him one of his first summer signings. PSV, having rebuffed a £15 million Tottenham offer the previous year, now values Depay more highly amid interest from other major clubs like Paris Saint-Germain. Recognized for his speed, dribbling, and powerful right foot—often drawing comparisons to Arjen Robben and a young Cristiano Ronaldo—Depay recently helped PSV win their first Eredivisie title in seven years. Despite his promising displays, he is still honing his decision-making and learning the game.

Chelsea’s youth side earned a 3–1 advantage over Manchester City in the first leg of the Youth Cup final, with Tammy Abraham scoring twice in the first half and Dominic Solanke adding a late third. City managed to level once through Isaac Buckley-Ricketts, but Chelsea’s defense, marshaled by Jake Clarke-Salter and Fikayo Tomori, ultimately contained City’s attacks. Several notable performances came from both teams: Abraham led Chelsea’s front line powerfully before going off injured, while City’s Brandon Barker was a persistent threat but unable to overturn the deficit. Solanke’s late goal gave Chelsea a commanding position heading into the second leg.

Marco Rubio, while announcing his presidential candidacy, stated that he believes same-sex marriage is not a constitutional right and should be decided by state legislators rather than the courts. He also asserted that most people are born with their sexual orientation. Despite opposing same-sex marriage, Rubio said he would still attend the wedding of a loved one who is in a same-sex union, explaining that he does not stop caring for people just because he disagrees with their decisions. As a Catholic, he similarly believes divorce is wrong, but emphasized that he would continue to love family or friends who are divorced. His campaign has already received substantial financial backing from donors.

Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde left their restaurant jobs in Manchester and are cycling around the world without set plans, traveling purely by pedal power. After nearly a year on the road, they’ve covered around 7,000 miles through 16 countries, relying on camping, hospitality websites, and the generous help of strangers for accommodation. Living on less than three euros each per day—mostly spent on food—they prepare simple meals, accept free produce where they can, and occasionally dumpster dive. Having started in London and journeyed through parts of Western and Eastern Europe, Turkey, Georgia, and Armenia, they intend to continue into Asia, eventually crossing the Pacific and cycling the Americas. Their journey remains open-ended, driven simply by the goal of seeing different parts of the planet “one pedal at a time.”

England full-back Mike Brown is unsure when he will return from a recent concussion and is taking a cautious approach to avoid a long-term absence. He references other players (George North, Johnny Sexton, Geoff Parling) who have dealt with multiple or severe concussion issues. Brown withdrew from key matches, including England’s clash with Ireland, after recognizing symptoms and stresses the importance of short- and long-term concussion awareness. He credits World Rugby’s online modules with helping him better understand the risks and believes it is critical for players to be honest about symptoms and not push through potential head injuries.

Research by Professor David Spiegelhalter of Cambridge University indicates that the average heterosexual couple in Britain now has sex three times a month, down from four times in 2000 and five times in 1990. Possible reasons for this decline include increased solo living and, more prominently, the rise of smartphones and the internet. Because technology enables constant connection to work and social life—such as checking emails late into the evening—couples have less uninterrupted private time. As a result, sex has fallen lower on people’s list of priorities.

Once prized as status symbols fetching up to £1.2 million, Tibetan mastiffs—large dogs weighing up to 80 kg—have fallen sharply out of favor in China. A key factor is the government’s anti-corruption crackdown, which ended their use as luxury gifts to officials. Additionally, several cities have banned dogs exceeding 50 kg, making mastiffs less practical for urban owners. This collapse in demand has led to dogs being sold to slaughterhouses, where their meat and hides are used for hotpot and leather. Some are found in dire conditions, lacking food or water, and suffering injuries. Overbreeding and crossbreeding have also produced low-quality mastiffs that cannot be sold. The breed’s unsuitability for city living further contributed to their sudden and drastic decline from a once highly coveted status dog to an unwanted commodity.

A Leeds-based company, Direct Line, ran a #everydayfix competition asking designers to tackle common “everyday emergencies.” From a survey of 2,000 people, the top stressors included not being able to sleep, losing keys, and running out of phone battery. Three shortlisted prototypes emerged:

• Snooze, an alarm clock that connects to a phone and silences notifications to improve sleep.  
• Forget Me Lock, a key attachment that displays red or green to indicate whether a door is locked.  
• Nipper, billed as the world’s smallest phone charger, powered by everyday batteries to boost a phone’s charge.  

People can vote via Twitter retweets, and the winning product will be funded through a Kickstarter campaign. Other prototype ideas—such as a parking pin for reserving and notifying about free spaces, an app to forward messages if a phone dies, and a smart helmet with built-in navigation—did not make the final cut.

The passage states that over 512 guests and musical performers attended the 2009 convention, including notable figures such as Patrick Stewart, William Shatner, Leonard Nimoy, Terry Gilliam, Bruce Boxleitner, James Marsters, and Mary McDonnell.
